summary: After rising through the ranks of her male-dominated profession, idealistic FBI agent Kate Macer (Emily Blunt) receives a top assignment. Recruited by mysterious government official Matt Graver (Josh Brolin), Kate joins a task force for the escalating war against drugs. Led by the intense and shadowy Alejandro (Benicio del Toro), the team travels back-and-forth across the U.S.-Mexican border, using one cartel boss (Bernardo Saracino) to flush out a bigger one (Julio Cesar Cedillo).

reviews.content: " you're not a wolf and this is the land of wolves now"; Alejandro.
Overrated. Too bad it can't be re made.

What is good? What is evil? Seems self-explanatory, until you dig a bit deeper. Truth is, we all live our lives in moral shades of grey. Everything in life is on a spectrum. Killing someone is wrong and generally thought of as evil until it's someone you care about that's been killed. Suddenly, it seems like a logical choice.

As in life, this movie doesn't have heroes and villains, protagonists and antagonists. Instead it tries to make the point that we are all capable of both good and bad deeds. This is emphasized heavily in the movie through the use of color. The movie is primarily told through the viewpoint of Kate Macer (Emily Blunt) who starts the movie as an idealistic FBI agent. Director Denis Villeneuve chose to represent Macer's initial naivety with vibrant blues. Though as the character interacts with Matt Graver (Josh Brolin) and Alejandro Gillick (Benicio del Toro) she slowly becomes jaded and her clothing slowly fades to grey. So if you're looking for a movie with a happy ending, or one that makes you feel good, this ain't it.
I liked the movie except for Emily blunt and her sidekick...both are shifty actors.

Nesse filme temos o FBI, tem a CIA e o exército, contra a guerra do tráfico humano e de drogas; um filme de ação que era para ser recheado de ação, mas que foi de estratégia. 
Quando você achava que ia acontecer algo de bom, nada acontecia. O filme não te conecta a nada, nem carisma os personagens conseguiram passar para o público. 
Para que serviu a personagem principal e o seu parceiro (Kate Marcer) e (Reggie)? Foi para ficar em segundo plano com dor de estômago ou para ficar questionando as ações em campo? Na guerra existe danos colaterais, me poupem desse mimimi. 
O filme é batatão, mas não consegue ser pior que tudo, pois é melhor que os filmes brasileiros do mesmo gênero.

Expected a lot after reading the plethora of positive reviews. That I am disappointed would be  an understatement. Dialogues are dull and fail to build any depth that goes beyond romanticizing violence, and while Kate blunt acted phenomenally in the lead role, her character is non-faceted and had less depth than a puddle of rainwater. Takes ages until the plot goes anywhere, but after 2h of waiting for action, you're at least blessed with an end to this tantrum of boredom.

The Bestest 

Absolute Must See

Dark, Gritty, Evil. This movie fits them all. A scary look into murder, drugs, and off the book missions. The acting of this film is one of the film is one of its highest praise points. The entire cast is fantastic. From Emily blunt and Benicio del Toro, to Jon Bernthal and Daniel Kaluuya. The cinematography is smartly executed and the lighting is used immensely well to work realistically but also to work for the audience to portray fear and suspense. A very depressing movie that knows what it's doing, and I'm all for it.

This film is really good. The story is intense and grim, it reminds me of the show Narcos. The cast is very good. Benicio del Toro's character is dark and haunting and his solo mission near the end is gripping to watch.

Great movie on all levels. Very powerful. It is not easy to make a great 2 hour movie. This movie is also 8 years old and is fairly original. The dialogue, script, plot, acting, and filming is really good. I will definitely watch the sequel.

It was a solid movie. The acting was terrific the story was okay and simple. 
A few disturbing scenes like a certain interrogation scene that was quite confusing.
I also felt Emily Blunts character was most of the times helpless but that made it feel more  realistic. Maybe if I watch the second part, I'll appreciate the first one more
Its good. Realistic from most aspects and the characters are good.
You should believe the hype for this full tank fueled ride that'll have you thinking about it if not days then weeks to come.

exciting and riveting,, really holding your attention. Fairly realistic picture of the Mexican drug cartels and what it takes to stop them.
 Only negatives are excessive both profanity and smoking, both of which principle characters engage in continuously, adding little to nothing and actually distracting from the main action.
  When one sees the main characters smoking constantly, in virtually every scene in an era we're nearly every intelligent person I know has stopped smoking, this is both not realistic and actually offensive—as is constant insertions of the "F-bomb" in the dialogue. At one point I counted four consecutive sentences by the main female character in which she dropped the F word!
  As for the smoking, it was so pervasive and gratuitous I really began to wonder if some  films receive financial incentives from tobacco companies to show so much smoking? (which I have read they do!)
This movie is an absolute must watch, the way it depicts the brutal war on cartels so accurately is just amazing

Villeneuve winds the tension so tight in this cartel thriller. The viewer gains good insight into the intricacies of the war on drugs and just how ugly it is. The end shifts main character focus which some main find jarring, but it feels earned.

Sicario is fantastic! It's one of the best movies I've ever seen about cartels and it's certainly one of Denis Villeneuve's best projects, a great masterpiece. It's a tense and beautifully written story, with impeccable cinematography and fantastic characters.
It might not be the action-packed movie some are looking for, but it's brilliant, extremely realistic as well as suspenseful, and serves as an entertaining "chronicle" about the Mexican cartel.
Simply a terrific movie. The hallmark of a classic is one you can watch over and over and never be tired of it .
Awesome. Surprising and liberatingly free fin cliches
Fantastic movie, very tense throughout and some great acting.

A gripping look into the worst of humanity. Sicario is tense and dark, with good performances and strong writing. I like how quickly the curtain is pulled back on the terrible things the movie explores, only for it to grow even worse from there. The score and directing also add a lot to the experience.
One of the best movies of all time
Amazing movie. A window into a piece of the larger world

Excellent movie, easily top ten movie the year it came out. re watched it again specifically for this review, now on my second viewing in 2 days. Brooding, well paced, well shot, well acted and a brutal ending. Great set pieces also make this movie thoroughly watchable.

Sicario is one of the best thrillers from 2015 and held my attention from beginning to bitter end.  Even though the film is much more than just an action film, it still manages to keep your undivided attention.  The film is smart, thought provoking, and incredibly suspenseful and it isn't surprising that it is so well received, garnering three Oscar nominations.  Sicario has solid performances from everyone involved and Emily Blunt does a good job at taking on the role of the audience, who like her, are new to the crazy drug world of Mexico.  After a grisly discovery in the opening sequence of the film, she is quickly drafted into service by higher ups to dive in to this new and brutal landscape filled with murders, drugs, money, and assassinations.  Benicio Del Toro gives a commanding and complex performance as a government consultant with a mysterious and violent past.  We learn midway through what has happened in his life to lead him to this point, and it's got him  focused and lethal throughout the film.
     Anyone who is is not able to view grisly images and intense violence, may not wish to proceed as the film is obviously dealing with some very serious and exceedingly violent themes.  The film has a couple moments that hold it back from perfection, some overly contrived dialogue and some of Blunt's character traits are at times annoying.  What I mean by this is that when you are in this world, even if being thrust into it, you have to adapt quickly or die.  Her character is so focused on doing things by the book, she doesn't see the bigger picture, and at times this gets frustrating.  Looking past these minor shortcomings, the film delivers on the drama and character development as well as the suspense it generates as you are pulled into this new dangerous world.  If not easily upset and don't mind dealing with the heavy themes, this is an amazing film that is both gripping and complex!
Absolutely intense, this film explores cartel violence along the border and the moral sacrifices and betrayals brought in to fight a foe on their level.  Excellent.
Only 3 stars as the entire film was so frecking bleak that it was hard but also boring, to watch.  Blunt's acting was outstanding and what kept me viewing to the bloody end.

I wasn't really into this movie at first as all the names and places people were talking about were hard to keep track of and I was really confused about what exactly the mission they were going to do was about until I realized that was the point. The movie did an amazing job keeping me in the eyes and mindset of the main character, making me paranoid, confused, angry, and depressed. Excellent movie
6 years ago- Beautifully filmed, superbly acted by the three leads, and reminiscent of Apocalypse Now to describe the endless battle of the war on Drugs. The climax will leave you floored.
Benicio Del Toro is (as usual) the best part of this movie.
Insane tension backed up by top tier acting make Sicario one hell of a ride.
Incredible. One of my favorite movies for sure.
Great movie. Great actors portraying the characters.
I've heard so much praise for this film. I finally made time to watch it, and... I was not impressed. In fact, I kept rolling my eyes.

When FBI agent Kate (Emily Blunt) is recruited into a special task force to assist in the apprehension of a high-ranking member of a Mexican drug cartel, she finds herself immersed in a world of intense violence where nobody can be trusted.  Director Denis Villeneuve wisely avoids the trappings one would usually expect from a crime thriller of this nature.  There is no pulse-pounding music score.  There is no rapid- fire editing. There are no prolonged action sequences or car chases.  It's a slow burn of a film with great cinematography from Roger Deakins, one of the best music scores imaginable, and solid but restrained performances from Blunt and Benicio del Toro as a mysterious member of the task force.  Does it provide any answers to the issues presented? It doesn't, but that was never its intent.

What a heart racing, thrill ride, brilliantly casted, (Josh Brolin and Benicio Del Toro were superbe), Denis Villeneuve delivers the goods, with abundant tension, and suspense, so thick you could cut it with a knife. A long with its soaring, somber musical score that takes hold of you, and never lets you go, till the end credits.

This was just dumb. How in the world did anyone give this a positive rating. The script does not have one fresh idea in it. The actors all seem tired and sad as if that's supposed to convey the futility of the 'drug war' or people who kill for a living... it just made them look like bad actors. It's not entertaining, it's not interesting, it's not educational (just reaching for _some_ reason to produce this movie! haha).
Keep away.

The sense that within Sicario there is a truly great movie lurking somewhere is at once a source of enjoyment AND frustration. The film struggles with clarity throughout, and fumbles to properly execute several of its key moments. Nonetheless, it is thrilling, beautifully filmed, and expertly acted. The plot is great, but is ultimately restrained by its inconsistent execution.

While not as great as a similar movie that it reminded me of (No Country For Old Men), the ending really hit it home and throughout the film Benicio Del Toro did a really good job with his performance and part. Emily Blunt did as well and the film became something bigger than what was originally expected. I give Sicario a solid B!
Nice cinematography in some outdoor and night portions. Pretty solid but honestly we should just be thankful to have a reasonable non franchise action movie.
Perfectly balanced crime and action. Likewise the opposite nature of main characters.

A taut revenge thriller with some good set pieces and direction, but it lacks any real tension between the bad good guys and the bad guys. The dynamic between the good guys (primarily, Blunt) and the bad good guys (Brolin; Del Toro) works well enough, but could have been more emotionally charged, somehow. It's enjoyable viewing, but should have been more engaging
For anyone who as ever lived on that side of the border, this is about as realistic as we’ve seen depicted in cinema.

Perfect in nearly every way, "Sicario" is one of the best action/thriller/crime movies that we have ever gotten, all thanks to incredible performances throughout and the flawless direction of Denis Villeneuve. Blunt, Del Toro, and Brolin are the major standouts, giving some of the best performances of their careers (especially Del Toro), and giving emotion to every scene that they appear in. The entire film keeps you on the edge of your seat expecting the worst, with great action that follows. The ending also has incredible payoff and sets up a sequel perfectly while also being a fantastic stand-alone film. The characters are all memorable and pack emotion with them. The film also never feels longer than it needs to, and never got boring. Overall, I loved "Sicario" and hope to see more from the creative mind of Villeneuve.
Muy buena película, sin hacer de criminales figuras glamurosas.
Probably the most suspenseful thriller you'll ever see. The score really drives the film and makes you feel like anything could happen at any moment.
one of my fav movies, very very underrated
Die Geschichte, auch wenn sie schon einmal gehört wurde, wird völlig neu erzählt. Kombiniere das mit der phänomenalen Schauspiel- und grüblerischen Filmmusik und das ist ein absoluter Klassiker!

Another brilliantly crafted film by Denis Villeneuve.  Sicario is a brutal and gripping look at an FBI agent's crossover into the world of covert US Government operations to break up Mexican drug cartels.  I do not know how much of this is real and how much is fiction but it is 100% scary as hell.   Emily Blunt is terrific as the patriotic but naive FBI agent who volunteers to help apprehend Cartel kidnappers and killers.   She is perfectly vulnerable and human in this difficult role.  Her eyes are opened as she becomes embedded with Josh Brolin, and the mysterious Benicio del Toro.  Daniel Kaluuya is very compelling as Blunt's partner and friend.  Jon Bernthal is always good to watch-whether the part is big or small, and this part is no exception.  This film is riveting, violent, and well done.   It is one of the most visually engaging and visceral movies I have seen in a long time.   The Direction and Cinematography are masterful-but I have come expect nothing less from Villeneuve.

Sicario, one of my all time favorites. A perfect film that is impossible to not enjoy. It's action packed from the beginning and will leave you on the edge of your seat until the very end. 

Denis Villenueve has PROVEN he's one of the best working right now through so many films, but in my opinion this is his best. The directing is perfect and I feel if there was anyone else working with this script it wouldn't have had quite the same results. The casting is perfect too and these characters have such great chemistry that it's hard to believe they haven't known each other and worked with each other their entire lives.

For those of you that know me, camerawork is very important to me. Cinematography can make or break a film, and I mean come on it's Roger Deakins. How could I complain?? The shots are gorgeous and the lighting in EVERY scene is perfect (You're going to hear the word perfect a lot in this review). Landscapes are gorgeous and colors are all beautifully matched in every scene. In action scenes, quick camera flips and shaky camera effects are put to use and it really brings you into the scene. Also, he used night vision. WHO IS AMBITIOUS ENOUGH TO DO NIGHT VISION??? Only Roger Deakins. He's a master at his craft and Sicario is a prime example of that.

Across the board, the writing is amazing. The characters are written to perfection and this script is jarring. A good jarring though, like it's so shocking to where ur jaw drops open but you love that it happened. Some of the lines are like wow. It's emotional and it's suspenseful and it's terrifying at points… what's not to love? These characters (Alejandro to be exact) are insane. Alejandro is the coolest character I've ever seen in a movie. He is BADDDDD!

The acting is something to note too because while not all of it is stand out phenomenal, certain characters deliver their roles like no other. Benecio Del Toro and Emily Blunt specifically. Blunt is one of my favorite actresses and Toro is one of my favorite actors of all time so how could I not find their performances outstanding? From facial expressions to combat, to even body posture, the acting is wonderful from everyone. They all do exactly what they need to do but as stated before, Benecio and Emily really stand out in this crowd. 

There's no other words to be said besides this is a masterpiece. Sicario is (as stated earlier) one of my all time favorites, and it gets better with every rewatch. This is a must see film. Absolutely perfect and so entertaining.

Also, Benecio Del Toro <3

Dull revenge thriller. Middle aged lawyer turns into Bourne. Macho men heroically shoot everyone when they're not beating Emily up because she's a wimp and doesn't want to shoot everyone. Not an action movie just a lot of swaggering.
Why does every film have to be about every MF shooting each other?
Although it dragged in parts overall a good movie. Worth watching.
A movie of excellent character portrait (though little development, as it is in this kind of mivie), tense environment, background music and beautiful scene of aridity and despair.

One of the best movies of its kind I've seen. Slickly filmed and directed with outstanding performances from all the leads. But, Del Toro steals the show as his murky character (and history) are revealed near the end. Excellent production.
A thriller that keeps you at the edge of your seat at first, it continues the build up just to end in a whimper.

Film to be honest very banal and without surprising twists as even the most surprising are predictable. The film entertains a lot with good action scenes but in the end it does not differ from being simply a very banal and already seen mediocre action film
Villeneuve = Quality Movies
great movie. the tension it builds is amazing

Well-performed and well-written. While it's admirably gutsy, we never again reach the level of excitement we enjoy in the beginning. When it does get exciting, it's often too heartless to want to invest in.

NO words can describe the experience into the world of Sicario, it's definitely brutal and cruel, but still beautiful and heartfelt, both merciless and warm exist in it. I love how they make it look so calm but so shock in the same time, its multi-perspective narrating meanwhile is the best thing that fill Sicario with all the great things I just wrote......I haven't even mentioned the one and only Roger Deakins! God help us all.

Summary: The word "Sicario" is Spanish for hitman. In the film, an eager female FBI agent joins the team assigned to the U.S.-Mexican war against drugs.

Takeaways: As someone who needs action movies to have a plot (not just 90 minutes of things blowing up), I appreciated this crime movie centered on a true societal issue.
It is really a different type of action/revenge/thriller. I had a blast watching it.

Sicario is certainly one of my favorite movies of all time. It has a fairly complex plot but what really delivers are its troubled characters and environment helped by extraordinary acting (especially from Benicio Del Toro). The movie is undoubtedly dark with the story being based around the ongoing war on drugs and specifically the larger cartel warlords with their hitmen. This dark theme is presented effectively through the characters and soundtrack. Josh Brolin plays a typical anti-hero who is on the side of the law but goes to questionable measures to get things done and Del Toro plays a man who has been scarred by tragedy and has turned to be a hitman for hire. None of the characters in this movie are objectively heroic or moral and this is what makes it so good. Even Blunt's character is flawed in parts, seeming like the heroine but in terms of the story's direction, lacks any kind of relevancy or conviction. However, this is used as a device for the audience to place them into this environment of fear and confusion through the seeming protagonist. For me what also pulls Sicario into one of my favorite movies is its action scenes and set-pieces. They are exciting and tense but not completely unrealistic either with scenes of combat being slightly exaggerated only to make scenes more shocking, to good effect too. The set-pieces in this movie are also very memorable and are well done to fit within the plot seamlessly. Overall, I really like this movie and can't recommend it enough. The sequel isn't too bad either but not the same level as the original.
Denis through and through.... awesome film! Powerful and moving and stellar performances all around!
Was expecting a movie more in the line of Traffic, which I couldn't get into. Turns out this was a very good movie. Great acting. Tense action scenes. Overall pace was very good.
Not a single wrong note in this whole movie...I am ambivalent about Bladerunner and Arrival but watching Sicario has made me hopeful for Dune.

Worst movie
Boring screenplay 
Overacting
Almost prefect. All narco movies will be measured against Sicario
It's repulsive see the work of camera of Roger Deakins beside to this stupid film. Another Villeneuve's movie that I hate. 1/10
Everything in this movie is intense - the music, the acting, the story - just incredibly raw.

With its slow/dynamic cinematography, show/not show direction and just brilliant, brilliant performances, this is clearly one of the best movies of the decade, especially concerning the 2 faces of justice.

Every single shot of the film has a lot of elements to pay attention and appreciate its. The script has a great development but that you can't understand it at first, it's until the end when you have understood what kind of way took this film. The performances were great and Denis Villeneuve mark his personal seal of him in the Crime Films.
Great movie but feels kind of slow after the beginning at some points.

Sicario is a very serious movie. So serious that it leaves next to no room for respite throughout its 2 hour run time. It was very good, but at the same time, it is quite a predictable action thriller that doesn't allow for much imagination while watching.

Beautiful in terms of the cinematography, editing, visual effects, sets/props/costumes, and soundtrack, but unfortunately, the plot turned out to be rather unrealistic and wishy washy, with a simple revenge subplot. The story started out strong with a nice shootout that had some suspense and an intriguing voluntary job offer for the main character, but then not as much happened in the middle, with the suspense and tension mostly disappearing, and the ending was solely focused on the revenge subplot, with a side character taking over for 10 or 15 minutes. I expected lots of action, but a sizeable amount of time was spent on dialogue, which worsened the pacing, although the film was by no means boring overall. The action towards the end of the film was also rather silly because I can't imagine people from different departments getting into physical fights, being pinned to the ground at gunpoint, or getting shot at by friendlies whilst wearing a bulletproof vest. Then there was an unexpected lack of emotion and emotional impact considering the seriousness of the topic, and the writers clearly favoured the popular 'the war on drugs can't be won' viewpoint. The main character was overly naive (e.g. her decision to point her gun at the assassin was moronic) but largely likeable and received some development, but her partner and several side characters could've been developed more, with the assassin coming across as unrealistically overpowered and skilled, the partner lacking brains, and the boss being a cowboy. Lastly, the acting felt authentic, especially from Emily Blunt and Benicio Del Toro.

Denis Villeneuve produce un gioiello del cinema di azione; difficilmente l'asticella per un film del genere può arrivare più in alto.
Viene esplorata meravigliosamente la sottile linea che divide la giustizia dalla vendetta personale.
Il cast è coeso e crede totalmente nel film, il contorno di musica e fotografia è meraviglioso; anche le sequenze di azione sono buone.
Probabilmente il personaggio meno riuscito è proprio quello della protagonista Emily Blunt, un po' noioso nei suoi "classici" dilemmi morali.
Es una buena película de acción y suspenso; la trama es muy buena y las actuaciones de Emily Blunt, Benicio Del Toro y Josh Brolin son excelentes, es muy recomendable.

At the beginning of Sicario, the definition of the title is explained. Sicario is the Spanish word for contract killer - a title that makes little sense for large parts of the film, as there is little or no hint of a hitman. But when the strands come together at the end and the final showdown takes place, you realise: this title is a bull's eye. Until it comes to that, an FBI agent is assisted by a mysterious association hired to help fight a Mexican drug cartel.

Director Denis Villeneuve has done a great job with the cast. Emily Blunt finds herself in a moral dilemma over the mission as the ambitious but little respected Kate Macer within the male-dominated Force. The more she finds out about the organisation, the more suspicious and antagonistic she becomes. This leads to the point where, in the final act, she finds herself walking a fine line between life and death, entering interpersonal spirals. Blunt's performance is serious and tough, which makes Kate stand out as the only relevant female character. This is partly due to her chemistry with Benicio del Toro. He plays Alejandro, one of the group's top commanders. The two share great moments. Every dialogue and confrontation is tense and you never know what's coming next. Del Toro once again completely lives up to his reputation as a specialist in crime films. Like Blunt, he is very serious and at the beginning pretends to be the taciturn and mysterious justice fighter. Towards the end, however, the character takes on a new facet that makes him even more intriguing and fascinating. Alejandro's real intention is only revealed in the very last sequences of the film, resulting in the most memorable scenes and performance in the person of Del Toro. Josh Brolin, as the slightly lazy head of the organisation Matt Graver, stays rather in the background of the action. He is responsible for the comedic patter and wages a subtle small war of toxic masculinity against Blunt's character. Nevertheless, Graver is surprisingly likeable and is given additional elements by Brolin's acting, which then makes a basically generic character more remarkable.

The stellar performances of the cast are not even Sicarios strongest points. Villeneuve once again manages to build a unique atmosphere. This time it is the irresistible suspense factor which leaves you riveted after the credits. This intensity is everything that a thriller should be about. In addition, there are brilliantly staged action scenes, most of which are very brief but insanely effective. Villeneuve does not skimp on bloodthirsty executions, but authentically presents the stark reality. The fact that these images have such an effect is also due to Roger Deakins' phenomenal camera work. Long shots of the Mexican desert mixed with quick cuts through hectic fight scenes. The only point where Sicario lacks something is in its story. As stirring and realistic as the protagonist's emotional conflict may be, the film often omits not unimportant details that could have made the plot more tangible. There is a need to catch up here, so I'd like to see more of it!
Amazing film with strong performances and terrific writing makes for a realistic, gritty and raw film, that presents what the book says and how it goes out practically !!

[⭐️88%]

Denis Villeneuve dives into a content-heavy genre and manages to fish out a memorable and fantastic story filled with shocking twists, huge tension and award-worthy performances from Benicio del Toro, Emily Blunt & Josh Brolin, not to mention a strong side cast.

It may take a while to be fully engaged in this movies plot as it feels familiar in a few areas, but once it gets into the flow of things, the story and it's elements just blow you away. Where a scene can already be filled with tension, the miraculous score just piles on twice as much tension, only when necessary, it's very noticeable that there is a lot of silence and only noise when needed, making for an impactful effect.

As mentioned, Sicario (2015) tackles a realistic plot and highlights many problems with the world today, not to mention the fantastic cinematography which propels this films quality to new heights

Don't hesitate to privately message me if you have a problem with two Denis Villeneuve films in consecutive weeks. Sicario is really what put Villeneuve on the map for me personally, I went to see it on a whim at a preview screening and was stunned at the tightening degree of menace and tension that is ever present throughout the film. Tackling similar themes within the world of the Cartel on the American/Mexican border that Steven Soderbergh's top notch Traffic (2000) also dealt with, Sicario is a tighter film, and is a more doom laden depiction of the depravity and realism that faces law enforcement when tackling the drug war on the front line. There's staggering cinematography to boot from frequent collaborator Roger Deakins, and the border scene (watch it and you'll know what i'm talking about) is one of the best in recent cinema.
Nerve racking just wow….a really really good movie and probably Denis's most accessible movie, though I think the writer could've worked some things out more like character motivation!
The movie seems very credible. Even if it's a fiction, it makes you understand that reality is worse than fiction.

Extremely good score, music, and equally good cinematography. Great acting too boot. But some lines too mumbled for me to tell the words. For that reason I got the script. Now the movie story is fine, gets the job done. But the script is different in enough ways to make it a better one. Most glaring in the movie  is Alejandro ending his quest. That really disjointed my 'always be a better person' DNA. Too the encounter between Kate and the crooked cop Ed is a better cameo than the movie version. Hey go read the script, you will be glad you did!

Just a straightforward no brainer drug war, effectively entertaining & bullets on a fire-sales. It's like CSGO, shoot to kill at sight even friendly-fire, Just wondering who is the biggest or always only the bigger

It is undeniable that 'Sicario' has various well executed performances, as well as a realistic grip arround sensitive topics. However, you can't help but wish for a more envolving plot while you wacth it...

Very good in the building up, until it loses its ground based realism. Then the main characters fall out of frame, one in particular, and the plot becomes cliché. However, the acting is generally good, the cinematography is awsome, and the music is amazing, but occasionally exaggerated and partly used before.

This movie is so good, it makes a very tense atmosfera, you be immersed on the on his history. He know when and how show to us informations and dont uses of boring and long explanetions. Oter than that have Emily Blunt in a amazing perfornmance.
Wonderfully paced and full of stunning sequences. This movie is about as tightly crafted as you can get while still feeling intelligent and impactful.
Very good movie, with a good story, it's pretty violent but retreat very well of how it works...
I somehow missed this movie and was bummed out when people wanted to watch it over another movie i had in mind but it turns out it is a really well done movie.

Sicario is a smooth, steady ride that doesn't need to be slick. Denis Villeneuve's work doesn't require varnish. It thrives on the hot, dusty desert look of Juarez and the dingy bars, rooms and tunnels that surround the area. It's also got solid performances from Benicio Del Toro and Emily Blunt.

Nearly a perfect film. Excellent directing by Villeneuve with perfect cinematography and score. The sunset tunnel approach scene should be made into a poster. The use of the filters from night vision to thermal vision was excellent. The casting and performances were exceptional and very convincing, especially del Toro, whom I feel was the cherry on top. Just his simple "ssssssth" during the choking rescue scene is enough to make your hair stand on end. The writing had some plot and technical issues, and needed more clarity in some scenes. But the non-stop tension, suspense and scenes that will make you gasp with disbelief, along with the perfect pacing and 121 min runtime, makes you overlook those little flaws. It just all feels so real. An astonishing film that will impress even if this isn't your genre.
Sicario is a very grim look at a very grim and gruesome world thanks to outstanding performances from it’s leads and typical smart writing from Taylor Sheridan.

I expected Sicario to be yet another run-of-the-mill action movie, with no investment in story telling or enriching characters. Sicario is not that action movie. Instead, I was pleasantly surprised to find that Denis Villeneuve has successfully created a high octane and tension filled film which successfully explores and exposes the viewer to the untold side of 'The war against drugs'. 
Emily Blunt takes on the role of the film's protagonist, Kate Macer, a young idealistic FBI agent whose will and self beliefs are pushed to the limit as she finds herself amongst those who will utilise any means necessary to achieve a 'controlled' level of order within the drug trade. Josh Brolin's sly and charismatic character helps to shed light on the motives and reasoning for the unorthodox methods used to achieve the 'controlled' order. However, Benicio Del Toro becomes the real star of the show as the mysterious and nonchalant, Alajendro, a hardened South American agent whose revealing past propels the film's themes and motives forward in a believable way which effectively resonates with the audience. 
However, regardless of its two hour runtime there were some noticeable pacing issues which arose following the conclusion of the first major act. Unfortunately, it was clear when the story began to deter itself from its previous tense rollercoaster ride to fall into the stereotypical blockbuster ending. This is not a bad thing, in fact I believe it was executed extremely well. I enjoyed the film's serious tone, and was pleased to find that what bombastic action sequences it contained, were not used to overwhelm the audience. 
Denis Villeneuve's directing styles were used to effectively captivate the audience into what would ordinarily be a very dull and somewhat monotone setting. The filmic techniques and the selected visuals coincide to create a tone and theme which greatly enhances the setting, while maintaining a strict emphasis on the film's grim and bleak tone. The choice for the film's musical score is also excellent, providing a foreboding sense of dread which can strongly resonate with the audience. The timbre of the low notes help to elevate the tension within certain scenes. I was pleased to find that all of these elements are used as the true driving forces behind the pacing within the high-tension scenes, and in creating the atmosphere and tone that is noticeable throughout the films duration.
Sicario is a film that sets out to redefine the action movie genre and set aside the typical stereotypes. Looking past the minor hiccups in the form of inconsistent pacing and alternating story goals, Sicario contains a fantastic cast, a (mostly) well written script, and gorgeously effective Cinematography. It reveals itself to be a true reinvention of the action movie genre, and I look forward to more following in its footsteps.

Sicario is a brutal, intense, thrilling movie with some real things to say. First off, the camera work of Roger Deakins is absolutely stunning here. The use of overhead cameras to track the movement of characters weaving through the city in SUVs is mesmerizing. Performances are amazing all around, Blunt is a great audience surrogate and it's easy to sympathize with her character. Del Toro and Brolin are both forces of nature, playing characters that are mysterious and fascinating to watch even as they carry out acts of serious brutality. The writing is brilliant, and the directing is fantastic- this isn't an overly complex story but it is told extremely well. It is a very thoughtful film that opts to allow viewers to make their own judgements, without interjecting hammy dialogue to make their point- they often show rather than tell. **SPOILERS** Basically what I took from it is that the War on drugs, and the behavior of the US and other actors, isn't a black and white situation. The drug traffickers are clearly evil, violent, brutal people who will do anything to increase their profits & power. On the other hand, the government officials (and those working with them) have no restraint in the way they fight back against the cartels. They resort to tactics that could be considered war crimes- torture, murdering civilians, threatening innocent families- all in the name of their "just" cause. In the end their goal is revealed to be simple to "restore order". In other words, taking out a major Mexican cartel leader so that the Colombian cartel can reassert dominance and bring an order to the drug industry. They admit they can't stop drugs from being trafficked, and they aren't really even trying to do this. In the end Del Toro's character is revealed to be a hitman, hired by the US government, who is out for revenge for the murder of his family. He doesn't care about the drug war, or the innocent lives he ends- he simply wants payback. The US government hires him because he is effective at what he does, but all they really did was to unleash reign of destruction on countless innocents. He completes his mission of killing the drug lord- but only after he murders the family of the Drug lord in front of him in cold blood. The final shots, in which gunshots continue to plague Juarez during a kids soccer game, are a poignant reminder that the cycle of violence will continue- regardless of which kingpin sits on top. And it seems to suggest that the "War on Drugs" is a futile effort that doesn't solve any of the real problems behind the violence

On rewatch, this is still an exceptional film. What strikes most - apart from marvelling once again at Deakins' camera work - is the brevity of the film's key scenes; for all that they stick in the memory - and they really do - and for all that individual scenes and the film as a whole are all replete with tension and uncertainty - it races by. Not one scene is a moment longer than it needs to be, and the result is an unforgettable, coherent whole. Del Toro and Blunt are both outstanding, of course. I remember when we first saw this in the cinema my wife felt the ending let down the way the narrative is centred on a woman, forced as she is to compromise. For me, that remains an open question and one I haven't seen addressed elsewhere - but whatever the answer there, it's a remarkable film.

Sicario is in my opinion one of the best cast, scored, and written films of the period. The gritty authentic backdrops along with the perfect casting set it up well from the start. 

Emily Blunt is perfect for the role, physically credible and real as a door kicking FBI agent, she carries the innocent and law abiding side of the cast perfectly, showing a genuine confusion and disbelief of the situation she finds herself in! Playing opposite her is Benicio Del Toro who has mastered the ability of saying everything without even needing to open his mouth, a skill many actors never achieve. A strong performance which makes you really understand his character and also by the end of the film fear him. Josh Brolin is the link between them both, perfect casting again confident in his own ability as to not over act (and ruin) the part and he has great hair.

The soundtrack is nearly always there phasing in and out, the deep drumming horn noise creates this dark fear around the story making you feel tiny in the scale of the whole plot, try watching this film without the sound on and it has a completely different feel. Finally the technical advisors were spot on, weapons, looks, drills looked all pretty authentic. 

Hats off to the director Denis Villeneuve for bringing it all together! Amazing film, one of my favourites!

‘Sicario' is a movie that provides a gritty, grimy, and realistic story of Mexico's drug cartels that is shown from the eyes of a new coming FBI agent, Kate Macer (Emily Blunt). The story is one of tracking down a cartel leader by any means necessary, as proved later when Kate is led by a mysterious assassin who goes by Alejendro (Benicio Del Toro). Everything from the color of the setting, to the few number of cuts shows how the movie was precisely made for the viewer to be immersed in the unpleasant habitat of cartel riddled territory. The film constantly applies suspense to the viewer, the dark lighting and ominous music makes the viewer clutch their seat even in the least eventful scenes. Blunt provides a great performance, as she sells the idea that the severity of the situations she is put through throughout the movie slowly chisel at her mental health and ideals. Denis Villeneuve's directing gave the viewer a chance to see beyond a screen, and to understand the harshness of current events that are not often talked about in American news. This is a movie which was not created to be idealistic or for the feint of heart, it shows real issues delivered in an authentic manner that creates an unforgettable experience.

Sicario is a hot new take on the drug film. It's dark. It's minimal. And it's awesome. It's rare that all forces come together, but when that happens in the making of a film, you get something like this. A combination of wonderful shots, awe inspiring music and worthy performances. An insightful character drama infused on the spiraling backbone of the drug trade infecting the Mexican/ American border. The film reveals the evils at play in a "game" that rewards brutality and refuses empathy a place at the table. What Denis does, is invite us to blink at the unceasing cruelty of which so many of us in small or large ways take part. Drugs arrive at your door from a far away part of departure, and that journey is stained with death, blood and suffering.  The film does not glorify any element of the drug trade, but reveals the venom which is its lifeblood. Sicario is a joy for the eyes and ears, and ushers worthy fear into our hearts. In a broken world, is there place for a human will, willing to do good? What does good even look like in such a scorched terrain? Sicario is less a treatise and more a meditation on this modern day darkness.

This is why Denis Villeneuve is one of the industry's best directors.  He sets your expectations against you -- what you think is happening, and then what you think the twists will be.. well you're just wrong all along.  It's never as obvious as you think, and it's always more insidious.  Villeneuve films live in the gray area, the muck where morality meets expedience/emotion.  You'll feel dirty and beaten down by the end, but yet hopeful, and that's the point.  The action is very good; the acting is superb. Blunt is very credible; Brolin is his usual awesome self; and del Toro is spectacular in a very understated way.

The final 45 minutes or so pick things back up (particularly Blunt's encounter with a cartel worker during a one night stand) with a dinner assassination that was handled with silent brutality that left my jaw dropped.  I loved the cinematography and non-sugarcoated realism coupled with Blunt, Brolin and Del Toro's great performances.  The relatively minor pacing issues in the middle act hold it back from being truly great, so at least it's truly good.  It's like a more condensed version of 'Traffic', which won Del Toro an Oscar.

Non-stop tension — I needed a massage after the tunnel scene — and a menacing score, Sicario is a must-watch thriller. Unlike so many action movies that involve ridiculous car chases, world-ending explosions, and other manufactured badassery, this film centers on the very real, very horrifying threat in the Mexican cartels. The corpses hanging in Juarez were disturbing — even more so when you see civilians playing soccer underneath the decapitated bodies, showing this is nothing out of the ordinary. Emily Blount's character became less tolerable as the film proceeded, as she seemed to make stupid decision after stupid decision. I can appreciate her sticking to her morals/values, but there came a point when I didn't think any person, after seeing what she had seen, after knowing what she had discovered, would continue to stick to those same values. Perhaps she's a better person than I am, in that regard. Alejandro (Benicio Del Toro) performed in his best role since Fear and Loathing in Las Vegas. And God was that dinner-table scene good. Not sure why it took me so long to watch this, but I've already added Sicario: Day of the Soldado to my list.

Sicario is an intense, nail biting, captivating movie. Sicario is a Latin word that means hitman. It tells the story of an FBI agent, Kate Macy, played by Emily Blunt who is brought into an operation that's supposed to help stop the drug war between the U.S and Mexico. The naïve FBI agent Macy doesn't know the actual purpose for the mission and is used by Alejandro aka Medellin played by the Academy Award winner Benicio del Toro. Medellin is a hired hitman, hints why it's called Sicario, for the U.S where he is hired to kill under the radar. The backstory of Medellin is that his family was murdered by a drug cartel and now seeks revenge any way he can. Throughout the whole movie everyone but Macy (Blunt) knows who the actual target is for the mission. Del Toro's depiction of his character Medellin is what makes Sicario such a gawking movie, that tells a story of how dangerous the drug war is on the border. Sicario gives the viewers an eye into the action of what happens when government officials and the infamous drug cartels are put against each other. The character Macy realizes that one should never go up against a Sicario (Medellin) especially the ones that seek vengeance for his/her family. Macy realizes that you are either with him or against him. The ending will leave you with your mouth open, and with the realization that not everything is what is seems, and how some actions are justified and better to keep a secret. Also, that there will always be a Sicario.

This one's a class act, scene by scene, dialogue to dialogue.  The cast is perfect, the screenplay is savage and terrifyingly realistic - or so it seemed to me, here in my ubersafe Scottish home town thousands of miles away from the territory depicted in Sicario.
Benicio Del Toro is a name that's seen increasingly in filmographies over the last ten to fifteen years, but this one has to be up there with his deadly finest work.  He's an angel of death, and assassin without peer.  And underplays this massively - accentuating the aura of menace pervading each of his appearances.  Josh Brolin has an easier time of it overall, but Emily Blunt, the nominal star name in the credits, has a tough gig to handle; and does so very, very well.
But the overal impact with Sicario is the screenplay and the dynamite directing from Villeneuve, where nothing's too hard to show, no mercy is shown to victims on screen or to audiences not perhaps completely ready for the savagery here shown with such graphic intensity.
This is a film that set standards of excellence for those following.  There is, inevitably, a Sicario 2 - without Blunt. Unsure if the other cast members revisited their roles from this, the mk1 version, but if they did then the standard of everything is going to have to remain absolutely at fever pitch for the second generation issue to escape unfavourable comparisons with this cruel and merciless piece of film making.
It's a fireball of a flick. If you don't watch it, you're losing out on an abject lesson in how to fail to put a foot wrong in even a single scene.  It's that perfect.
If this movie would have came out post 2016 it would have been bombed by critics just like Rambo Last Blood. Great film that doesnt even scrape the surface on whats happening in Mexico.

Sicario was first released back in 2015. I just watched it for the first time last week…and I really have no excuse other than I'm an idiot. I knew I'd like it, I'd heard nothing but amazing things, and five minutes into the movie I completely regretted not watching it sooner. Sicario is, hands down, one of the best action/thrillers of the decade. Director Denis Villeneuve manages to create so much suspense and intensity throughout 120 minutes that at times it's almost unbearable. Needless to say, my fingernails did not survive this movie. The plot itself is fairly basic - the FBI teams up with some shady people to fight a brutal Mexican drug cartel. Emily Blunt plays the young FBI agent recruited into the fight, and for most of the movie the audience is just as confused and suspicious as she is. It delivers plenty of wonderful "what the hell?" moments, as you never really get a sense of anyone's true motivations until the end. The performances are universally terrific and the dialogue is sharp, but the main reason the movie works so masterfully is Villeneuve. With the help of some striking cinematography and a brilliant score, he gives us one of the most surprising, tense, and atmospheric thrillers in the history of the genre. If you've never seen Sicario, please don't make my mistake and see it ASAP.
A decent thriller with some pretty intense moments...doesn't always hit it's mark...but when it does, it's truly satisfying!

Denis Villeneuve is an extraordinary director having produced such exciting films as Arrival (2016) and Blade Runner 2049 (2017) and while I wouldn't call this film nearly as good as those he still brings unique vision and scope to a story that could easily be cliché and dull. Having watched this just a day after seeing Zero Dark Thirty (2012) there were a lot of comparisons to be drawn between the two and while Zero Dark Thirty is helped by this comparison as it does not make the mistakes that this film makes it was still fascinating to see how different filmmakers approach material that is in some ways similar. While crime thrillers are not necessary my favorite genre, they tend to be very male oriented, even I could accept that this film can be exhilarating as while as considering the complexities of the drug war more than the average film does.

FBI agent Kate Macer, Emily Blunt, joins a special task force after successfully leading a raid on a house run by a Mexican drug cartel. She is paired with Matt Graver, Josh Brolin, and Alejandro Gillick, Benicio del Toro, both of whom take actions that she disagrees with in attempting to punish those responsible for the deaths of people attempting to stop the drug trade. Throughout she is manipulated by the two men who use her to lure the men they want dead to them. She takes actions that they disagree with which angers them while she is resistant to condoning their actions while also aware that they are willing to have her tortured. Gillick's backstory is eventually revealed and he violently murders a drug lord who may have been responsible for the deaths of wife and child. Macer is eventually forced to submit to the will of the two men as they express a nihilist view on the war on drugs.

For all the praise of the performances I found them to be just alright. Blunt is a very capable leading lady as shown by My Summer of Love (2004) and Your Sister's Sister (2011) but here she displays none of the wonderful wit and warmth she brought to those roles and while she is perfectly fine as a relatively vacant young woman angry at how she has been used she can do so much more. Brolin is reliably sage and slightly smarmy as the aggressive Graver and del Toro brings the enigmatic presence that he used to such good use in Traffic (2000) but they had each given very similar performances to greater effect in other films and it was hard not be reminiscent for those films while watching this film. The supporting cast of Mexican actors are impressive as they bring a quiet sense of desperation to their roles as regular civilians but it would have been nice to see a lot more of them.

One element of the film that was superior to other crime thrillers was the cinematography as the legendary Roger Deakins worked on the film and he can make the reflection of light from streetlamps onto our main characters gorgeous. Most films of this sort look very generic but Deakins captures the Mexican landscape in all of it's ordinariness while still allowing us to understand that this is a dangerous environment to step into. Yes, the film definitely borrows some visuals from the films of Michael Mann but almost all modern crime films are inspired by Miami Vice and Heat (1995) and this film copies that style better than most. I can see why this film received a Best Picture nomination but it is hard to compete with the work of Emmanuel Lubezki on The Revenant (2015).

At the end of the day I didn't love the film but I can see why it was a financial success and I would prefer that a film like this succeeds over mindless dreck like Avengers: Endgame (2019). Villeneuve's Dune (2020) will be released next year and if he can bring the technical skills that he applies here to that film and extract decent performances out of Timothée Chalamet, Charlotte Rampling and Stellan Skarsgard I will be extremely excited to see his future work.

Denis Villeneuve (the director) has a tendency to just let his movies trail off, which I don't particularly appreciate but which works better in this film than in his others. The acting is precise, the cinematography as always is beautiful, and the tense traffic jam scene is fantastic. While the story is engaging I find myself wanting more of a take-away than this film provides, especially with the themes it deals with. Some of the characters' motifcations were more said than acted, which I would have liked to have seen done better. All in all, though, I understand why this was so well received initially, and I recommend it to people who like modern police thrillers (and can handle seeing some cut-up bodies).

Sicario chronicles morality in the war on drugs and attempts to restore order can turn corrupt. We see the moral spectrum through 3 main characters- Emily Blunt, the team player who plays strictly by the book, Josh Brolin, who lives in a grey area where he'll get the job done whatever means necessary, Benicio del Toro, a senseless killing machine morphed into the monster he's become by the deeds of the cartels he's combatting. Director Denis Villenueve bathes scenes in a murky yellow that creates a cloud of dread over a lot of the film and dials up intensity really well. He knows how to make you feel uneasy. Cinematographer gets some really cool overhead shots and helps ground you in the Mexico our characters are in conflict with. The heat vision and night vision is poorly executed and took me out of the movie. Benicio del Toro has a major, mysterious presence as an assassin who hides behind a pair of sunglasses. Josh Brolin and Emily Blunt are both fine, not their strongest performances, but they rise to the occasion and deliver decent performances. Sicario doesn't make you choose which side you're on in this elaborate web of federal agents, criminals and all around mayhem and I really like that about this movie. It's not black and white, it's grey. Sicario is really good and Taylor Sheridan has quickly become one of my favorite screenwriters working today.

Terrific thriller with heartpounding scenes and amazing performances. Blunt, Del Toro, and Brolin all shine in their roles and the ambiguity of what's right and wrong in the war against crime lingers after the film is over. The score is also great and the violence is memorable, due to the fact that it is grounded and not stylistic. It's raw and horrifying, demonstrating the grittiness the director was going for. The scene where the convoy is stuck in traffic is especially tense and well-shot.

Emily Blunt's Kate Macy, gets her hands really dirty, after an eye opening raid on U. S. soil that smells of death  and drug cartels, leading her to volunteer to join a task force with questionable goals, that crosses the legal line and the Mexican border into the murder capitol of the world, fondly referred to as the beast.

What this film sets apart from others is Denis Villeneuve. It would've been garbage if it was directed by Michael Bay. If action geeks are only seeking over-the-top action sequences will be disappointed given the premise. This is not your regular action flick, thank God for that.The acting is on point (Benecio Del Toro's Alejandro is unnervingly convincing), the camerawork is masterful, the cinematography is pitch perfect (it is Roger Deakins after all) and the late Jóhann Jóhannsson's score makes anxiety go off the roof. Without a doubt, Sicario is one of the best films ever produced.

I would credit Sicario as being one of the movies responsible for my deeply-rooted respect and admiration for the medium of film. Directed by Denis Villeneuve and acting as writer Taylor Sheridan's induction into the screenwriting business, Sicario is a tense, thought-provoking thriller that sets the audience on edge and keeps them there until the end credits begin to roll. With each re-watching of the film, one comes to appreciate Villeneuve's moviemaking on a deeper level and the faint subtleties he slips into every scene to enhance the film as a whole. The story follows FBI Agent Kate Macer (Emily Blunt) as she volunteers for a joint government task force to help bring down the leaders of the Sinaloa Cartel. Heading up the task force is DOD Adviser Matt Graves (Josh Brolin), a lifelong soldier hellbent on bringing down yet another threat to his country. Acting as Graves shadow is the mysterious Alejandro (Benicio Del Toro) a seemingly reserved man of few words. Agent Macer is thrown into the world of espionage and operations that don't technically exist with both feet, serving as a conduit for the audience who have also never been privy to such things. Villeneuve takes advantage of everything from lighting to wardrobe to help subconsciously tell Sheridan's story. From lighting certain characters so that they faces are in light while others are in darkness to the last scene of the film where Macer is wearing a pure white shirt in contrast to Alejandro's dark suit the director used every opportunity to compare and contrast the characters. Emily Blunt plays Kate perfectly, a by-the-book FBI Agent thrust into a world of wolves that has no ruling law. Macer is understandably upset and thrown off balance by the constantly shifting ground beneath her feet and the audience sees the toll it takes upon the character from the dark circles beneath her eyes and picking her smoking habit up again. Both Graves and Alejandro have lived in the world of shadows for so long that they too are shadows and we see two sides of the coin in their handling of the horrors they've seen and/or perpetrated. Although the movie follows the plot through Kate's perspective, it is Benicio Del Toro's performance as Alejandro that steals the show. Taking over every scene that he is in with his intense, silent demeanor, Alejandro carries himself like a predator, always ready to pounce should the situation call for him to. Graves on the other hand, deals with the dark madness around him through humor, smiling and laughing as though he doesn't have a care in the world when in reality, lying just beneath the surface, is a predator waiting to take down its prey. Throughout the film, the musical score by JÃ³hann JÃ³hannsson enhances every emotion felt in each scene. With a steady heartbeat of drums and deep thrums of string instruments, JÃ³hannsson raises the tension level and sets those watching on edge as they wait to see what happens next. Each character comes into the plot with their own objectives and motivations, Kate desires to strike a blow at the cartels killing innocent people, Graves perceives a threat to the United States of America and is willing to do anything and everything to protect his country, and Alejandro wishes to avenge the deaths of his wife and daughter who were brutally slaughtered by the leaders of the Sinaloa Cartel. Every step taken leading the climax of the film takes the audience down farther and farther down the very dark, malicious rabbit hole that is the drug trade. This film shows every aspect of how the destructive disease infects and destroys all those it touches and how the United States is searching the vaccine. Villeneuve and Sheridan craft a masterful tale of the chaos that reigns along America's southern border and all of those it affects, showing that in the face of lawless chaos and evil intentions, one must fight fire with fire or be turned to ash.

A tense and gripping movie about the horrors of the drug war that is unfortunately impacting the people of Mexico.

There's an effective, quiet pall that hangs over every scene of Sicario, an appropriately nervous sense that we have entered into an atmosphere of death. This is refreshingly new. Movies about federal agents at war with the Mexican drug cartels have a tendency to be very slick and unafraid to get into the messier bits of such an unsavory industry. Sicario doesn't do that. Here is a movie that isn't afraid to get its hands dirty. Pulled out of our comfortable American of commercialization, the film takes us into a world that might look right at home in a post-apocalyptic thriller. Yet, this is not about any grand catastrophe between nations; it's about the drug war that stretches from the southwestern United States all the way into the deepest heart of the Mexican desert.

The purpose of Sicario (which is the Spanish word for 'hitman') is to take us into this world and then ask us a question. Should our federal agents have free reign to move into Mexico and bend the rules in order to crack down on drug lords who are spilling poison into our country and theirs? The answer is not as simple as you might think. It is easy to think that procedures must be followed, that laws must be upheld. But what are our government agents to do when a community has become so overrun by drug cartels that naked, decapitated human bodies are displayed in public as a warning?

It is a moral dilemma that lies at the door of FBI agent Kate Macer (Emily Blunt), a relative greenhorn whose experiences are beginning to morph into PTSD. As the movie opens, we find Kate and her fellow agents busting into a house in Chandler, Arizona to find a kidnapping victim. They don't just kick down the door, they're tactics involve driving through the sidewall of the house. After a clumsy gun battle with armed criminals, something comes to light that is first spotted through a bullet hole in one of the walls - a gruesome tableau of death. Bodies wrapped in plastic turn up, rows and rows of them. Who are these men? Why are they here?  And how did they meet such a gruesome fate?

The search for those answers begins the next day when Kate is hired to join the intra-agency task force that will move into Mexico, and attempt to disrupt the drug business there. Her immediate superior is a smiling wise-guy black-ops cowboy named Matt (Josh Brolin) who isn't exactly loose with the details of their mission. She's none-too-trusting of Matt or his team, and is especially suspicious of a soft-spoken former prosecutor named Alejandro (Benecio Del Toro), a hulking specter whose positioning in this mission has a lot more to do with breaking down the cartels then meets the eye.

Traveling into Mexico with Matt's squad, Kate is appalled by the lack of procedure at hand.  What they do, and how they get information.  What is most galling to her is that Matt and his team are not interested in arrests but in getting to the kingpin at the center.  The method (as spelled out in the trailer) is to stir the pot, the create a war within the community that will smoke the head man out.  What seems reasonable to everyone else, is appalling to Kate, who still believes that policy and procedure must be observed.

That, really, is the movie's weak point.  Kate spends the entire movie in private protest over what is going on and how things are being handled.  We, in the audience, applaud the men who are willing to bend the rules.  We understand that they are operating in a den of vicious animals, and certain lines must be crossed, but Kate remains in protest long after it might have seemed that she would come around to their way of thinking.  One might think that she would either be on board for this, or be sent home.

I was also put off by the movie's third act, where it might have been interesting to see where the infiltration effected the cartels themselves.  Instead the movie turns inward and becomes a more personal drama leading to a showdown that has little if any real resolution.

Those objections aside, this still a very good movie.  It was directed by Canadian filmmaker Denis Villeneuve who made the excellent kidnapping drama Prisoners two years ago.  What he shows in both films is his ability to orchestrates scenes.  The scenes involving the feds infiltrating the inner sanctum of the cartel are handled very well because we understand it as part of the story, not as a series of confused editing as a Michael Bay film might.  Villeneuve has the patience to tell this story as it unfolds rather than make it all obvious in the first few minutes.  He gives us that sense that we are wandering through the valley of death where bloody violence springs up out of nowhere and human life is meaningless.  It's not a perfect movie, but it is a very well made movie, one that has you thinking about it afterwards.

"Your asking me how a watch works" is what Alejando (Benicio Del Toro) says to Kate (Emily Blunt) when she asks him about the cartels in Mexico. Clockwork is a perfect analogy for the events that take place in this film because nothing is simple or clear cut, yet everything is connected. Denis Villeneuve the director does a fantastic job of pulling the viewer in and painting a vivid picture of life on the U.S. Mexico border. 

Sicario is a gritty suspense filled action film that doesn't sugarcoat much. The film itself is shot almost like a documentary in a sense because there is nothing very dramatic or far fetched about the storyline itself. One might say it almost feels like an AE special about the cartels and law enforcement featuring A-list actors Benicio Del Toro, Emily Blunt, and Josh Brolin. Kate, played by Emily Blunt, is the main character of the film and Cinematographer Roger Deakins and Writer Taylor Sheridan do a brilliant job of putting us in her shoes. 

Kate is appropriately the main character because she is a textbook FBI agent who always seeks justice but never likes to stray from the rule of law. The film quickly takes us into a world that couldn't be further from the rule of law when Emily Blunt's character agrees to join a task force to dismantle a cartel. We follow Kate's character as they venture into Mexico, to the lion's den that is cartel territory.

Roger Deakins gives us plenty of aerial and panned out shots of the grim and unforgiving terrain of Mexico and the Southwestern United States. Overall the Cinemaphotography feels organic and authentic to the world the story takes place in. Character scenes are shot up close and personal so the viewer sees, hears, and feels every piece of dialogue and emotion. The emotional acting of our main character Kate can be felt at every twist and turn and reaches a pinnacle when she realizes some of Alejandro and Matt's ulterior motives. Kate then faces some hard moral dilemmas that might cost the agent her life.

Sicario is a must see, and begs to be viewed a second time to be properly understood. Gripping and suspenseful with no happy ending, this film is not for the faint of heart. Alejandro sums of the film perfectly in the end when he says, "This is the land of wolves now".
Great action and a great story. Well-cast.

Sicario is directed by Denis Villeneuve, written by Taylor Sheridan and starring Emily Blunt, Josh Brolin and Benicio Del Toro.

In the lawless border area stretching between the U.S. and Mexico, an idealistic FBI agent [Emily Blunt] is enlisted by an elite government task force official [Josh Brolin] to aid in the escalating war against drugs. Led by an enigmatic consultant with a questionable past [Benicio Del Toro], the team sets out on a clandestine journey forcing Kate to question everything that she believes in order to survive.

A great fast-paced, dark and powerful story, with an amazing direction adding some very talented cast, but with a couple of flaws, this is how Sicario was born.

Let's jump to the flaws.. Emily Blunt's character wasn't so necessary, she had no goal but just going with the waves of this movie, but with her amazing performance, she convinced me -or I pretended being convinced- that her goal is cleaning the world of it's dark crimes, but for me, it's uneven.

Some scenes were so confusing, and there was nothing to give any hope, it's just dark.. from the beginning to the very very end!

These are the flaws of this movie, everything else was well made.. the breathtaking scenes mixed with amazing performances with great story.

Sicario is a great movie, and I'm gonna give it an A-.

Sicario begins with an exciting, interesting, horrifying premise... and then it circles the drain for two hours.

From the very moment that she was invited to join the super-secret special operations team, I did not understand why Kate Macer (Emily Blunt) was invited. I understand that she was part of the team that discovered 42 bodies in a house, but why her?

And then I did not understand why Kate was dragged around the country and parts of Mexico by Matt (Josh Brolin) to witness random events in random places.

And then I did not understand why Alejandro (Benicio Del Toro) was such a badass, or who he was working for, or why he was part of this entire operation.

And then I did not understand why I was watching a random man in Mexico eat eggs and talk to his son about soccer.

And then I did not understand why Kate meets A Random Guy (Jon Bernthal) in a bar who then tries to kill her.

And then I did not understand why this super-secret special operations team is raiding a drug tunnel in the middle of the night, nor why Kate and Reggie (Daniel Kaluuya) followed the super-secret special operations team into the tunnel.

And then I did not understand why Kate tries to stop Alejandro from taking a police cruiser and why that was supposedly something that she wasn't supposed to see.

And then I did not understand why Kate cared so much about this super-secret special operations team following the letter of the law, or why she was almost ready to die for that ideal.

And then everything was explained and my response was, "Oh. Okay".

In all seriousness, everyone in the film gave excellent performances. The musical score was great. The cinematography was phenomenal.

The plot... not so much.

Strengths: Denis Villeneuve is quickly becoming one of my favorite directors in all of Hollywood. Movies like this are why. He does a fantastic job with tense scenes and this film is filled with those. From the scene in traffic to the invasion of the underground tunnel, this is one of the more intense action flicks in recent memory. The cinematography is fantastic. Benicio Del Toro (Alejandro Gillick) is outstanding. He doesn't have a ton of lines, but he commands the screen each time you see him. There's a chilling aspect to almost everything he does. Emily Blunt (Kate Mercer) is also great as the lead. She sells the combination of being terrified and still being tough, which is not easy to balance. Josh Brolin (Matt Garver) and Daniel Kaluuya (Reggie Wayne) were both also strong in their roles. There are some clever twists throughout that keep you on the edge of your seat. 

Weaknesses: The plot is a straightforward one that doesn't stand out as something special. It's simple and to the point. Some moments paint Blunt's character as being more incompetent than she should be considering her position within the FBI. As good as her performance was, it never felt like she had much of an arc. She doesn't grow throughout, even with everything that happens to her. The ending leaves a bit to be desired.

Overall: There's nothing special about the story or the plot, but Denis Villeneuve did his some of his best work to turn it into a tense action thriller. The performances are mostly great, adding to what makes this movie work.

The movie was excellent and reminded me, in tone, of Syriana. The movie doesn't have a crisp neat conclusion of the overdone good v. Evil genre. Nor is it a beat up on Mexican and brown people festival as one commentator elsewhere said. In a world where dictators and autocracies have been kicked over and chaos is following, it is a reflection of the desperate attempt to recapture order. The Mexicans could easily be replaced with Russian Mafia, the syndicate, or anything in between. Ethnicity is incidental and only relevant insofar as Mexico happens to be our neighbor and it's criminal cartels the ones involved.

In movies last lecture his that do echo the ugliness of big player's actions and everyday people caught in the middle, the idealists won't like it, let alone civil libertarian purists. I'm not a purist but I do understand the possible motives behind it as a means of controlling chaos and violence that can spread like a malignant ulcer from nation to nation.

An eye for an eye, especially when innocents are deliberately targeted makes the one seeking vengeance evil, no matter how justified it seems. The look at the horror of the cartels was the best thing about this film though. I personally wouldn't watch it a second time.

An immensely relevant, commendably intelligent military thriller about the cartels in Mexico and the evil necessary to fight evil. It's not some kick-ass summer action flick, no - it's a grim, respectful, realistic depiction of what's happening at our border and the innocent lives caught in the crossfire on both sides. Taylor Sheridan establishes himself here as an incredibly brilliant screenwriter, and his talent combined with Dennis Villeneuve's masterful filmmaking makes for one of the best, most mesmerizingly flawless films of the year.

Well, after nearly three years of avoiding it, and with needing the knowledge of the original before seeing "Day of the Soldado" tomorrow, I have finally watched Denis Villeneuve's "Sicario".
     Emily Blunt plays Kate Macer, a member of the FBI asked to join in with Matt Graver, played by Josh Brolin, and his shady assistant from Mexico, Alejandro Gillick, played by Oscar-winner Benicio del Toro. Their goal? Bring down Manuel Diaz, the lieutenant of the Sonora Cartel.
     Pretty simple story, huh? Yeah, I thought so too. It's the reason this film doesn't have a full five stars. Sure, the story is elevated by a few clever twists, but that's about it. Another thing is that keeps the score at four-and-a-half is the fact that, while the complexities and ideas that are mentioned throughout - that the world isn't black and white - are still relevant, I don't find them as having much of an impact as they should, because so many movies I've seen have already done that idea to death. "American Hustle" did it, the "X-Men" films do it, "I, Tonya" did it, and the list goes on. Nothing new here, but that doesn't mean it's still done great. I believed everything going on on the screen.
     Now, onto the positives. The cast, I mean, holy fucking shit! THEY'RE AMAZING! However, I must give applause to Benicio del Toro, who I am so glad has returned for the sequel. He is brilliant here. Surprisingly, he is a man of few words in this film, but despite this, he commands a serious presence whenever he's on screen. He ranks as one of my favorite actors now. Josh Brolin comes in a close second for me, as he has way more lines than del Toro. However, he conveys a passion and power on screen that perfectly balances out.

Overall, a solid film. I'm going to give it an A.

Beautifully directed, strikingly brutal, and showcasing the best performance of Benicio del Toro's career, Sicario is Denis Villeneuve at the top of his game. What could have been a generic action thriller about America's battle with the drug cartels is elevated to a reflection on morality and brutality. It's a well acted, well thought out, and ambitious piece of filmmaking. All that said, it is slow. Denis is a filmmaker's filmmaker, the kind of guy who is dedicated to the craft in a way that's been hampered by the studio system over the past thirty years. Sit back, and drink it in. This is about atmosphere, tension, and reflection.
