Sicario is one of those rare examples of a film that fires on every cylinder. If it had more pretentions one might call it a masterpiece. What it is is riveting on every level. From the script, to the direction, to the cinemotography, the performances, the editing, and the score. All of it’s elements blend into a searing mediatation on intensity. You have know idea what is going to happen in any given scene, and you have no idea where it is going until the very end. Your experience mirrors that of the protagonist, an FBI agent played by Emily Blunt. A raid on a drug house uncovers far more sinister activities, and Blunts character is thrown into league with CIA spook Josh Brolin, and his enigmatic henchman played by Benecio Del Toro, in order to push back on the drug cartels. We assume we are with the good guys, but everyones intentions and motivations are opaque. Something is happening, we kind of have an idea, but the what, the why, and even the how is just beyond our reach. Things are not hidden so much as out of focus, the suprise of the end is not a twist, but the sudden ability to see things that were there all along. The mystery plays out with steady intensity, across Roger Deacons lushly shot landscapes, and as Johan Johansonans eerie dissonant score drags you to the edge of your seat. On repeated viewing it loses little of it’s intensity. It is about these characters, and it is about what is happening to them in this moment. It feels captured rather than constructed, and it is solid entertainment throughout.

Also starring, Josh Brolin, Daniel Kaluuya, Benicio Del Toro, Victor Garber, Jon Bernthal.

Sicario" was the only movie in English directed by Denis Villeneuve that I hadn't seen yet. All five (including Prisoners", Enemy", Arrival", Blade Runner 2049") have been cult hits and among the most critically acclaimed screen works of given release year.

Villeneuve's movies are emotionally distant, slow-burning, and usually more dependent on mood than sharp storytelling. I am not the fan of his style - it's too slow, rather uneventful, lacks sharp dialogue and character building - but I gotta admit that it always pays off.

I could also say that Sicario" doesn't really offer any intriguing characters except Del Toro's (good that he's gonna be back for sequel Soldado") and the best drug war / trafficking stories are just more captivating (especially The Wire" and Breaking Bad")...

But it doesn't change the fact that it's a solid thriller, and a cool movie which makes you gradually more and more thankful that you endured the rather slow first half.

This never felt like it was dragging and every scene just fits perfectly into the picture.

Absolutely thrilling. This movie was kind of hard for me to watch, and not for a body count. At the beginning I was anticipating a lot more mangled corpses, but this movie's got some different skeletons you have to deal with. Who's doing the right thing in this movie? Obviously drug wars aren't good, but to what lengths do we go to stop them? What laws and ethics can be bent or broken? This movie has you sympathizing and disagreeing with just about everyone at one point or another; even from the crooked cop to our heroes. No one is a perfectly good or bad guy. This movie had me riveted from start to finish. My mind was absorbed thanks to terrific performances (this is a serious contender for my favorite del Toro), powerful direction (duh), and, to sound like a broken record, the great cinematography (Roger Deakins doing good work? Surprising, I know...). This movie was really gripping. I was into every moment. The ending was absolutely spot-on. The emotional core of this movie was so brilliantly summed up, and shown not told, in that last scene. A great movie.

Time and time again, a "strong man" had to rescue her out of a bad situation or "set her straight " on how the world really works. In the end because she had so much screen time the rest of the movie, while interesting, didn't matter.
Really unlike anything else I'm aware of. If you like grit. See it! Looking forward to Soldado.
Good movie but not great, kind of overhyped but definitely worth a watch and even a rewatch. The highlight was the cinematography. Movie also seemed kind of short.

This is an odd movie to me.  I think I liked it but I feel like I only liked it because the production value was high.

The cinematography, directing style, and acting is strong across the board.

However the story/ script itself is a little weak. You don't start getting a clear picture of what exactly is going on other than CIA black ops drug stuff unlike the last 20 minutes.
Emily Blunt's character is also ridiculously naive to the point where it undermines her character. I did not believe she was the hardened drug house raiding badass from the intro that was in the rest of the movie. Only her acting saves the character from being totally worthless. 

So overall I liked it but with a tighter edited script, it would have been better.

Although the theme and story are not that novel or complex, this film works surprisingly well with strong performances, dramatic tension, and excellent direction and cinematography.  Gritty realism and a grim mood prevail throughout, with brutality giving a rough edge to the action on the ugly, lawless border areas where drug cartels do battle with law enforcement willing to suspend all rules. Benicio del Toro is especially good in this, portraying an emotionally ravaged character trying to exact revenge for the murder of his wife and daughter by members of a drug cartel.  The theme is essentially good guys are no better than bad guys they are charged with bringing to justice when they must resort to the same violence and amoral behavior.  This is injected into the fight against drug cartels, and the personal struggle of a female agent who objects to the methods used by those around her who are convinced there's only one way to keep control of the drug world while never ridding society of the criminal element altogether.  I also appreciated the subtle, low-key and moody music that is used sparingly.  It's so refreshing to watch a film that depends on its acting performances, visuals and story line rather than resorting to artificial mood from overbearing soundtrack music.

Jeffrey Donovan's in it for a little while. And then suddenly, he's not in it anymore. And for the rest of the movie, you're like "What happened to Jeffrey Donovan? Who are these scrubs? Where's Jeffrey Donovan?"

Pretty great "war on drugs" CIA/FBI vs Mexican drug gangs action film, with plenty of gore and gritty reality. Blunt is good, as is Brolin & Del Toro, although they don't seem to be used that much. Some slow parts, but plenty of tension, action and amazing shots in the desert.

This is an intense, deep thriller.  Not sure I massively 'enjoyed' it on first viewing but it may require another look to fully appreciate.  There are some excellent performances by all involved and it feels like you're reading a novel in a similar way to Villeneuve's earlier film 'Prisoners'.  It feels like such a believable premise that it's soul-searchingly depressing at times.  Another strong film in the back catalogue.

'Sicario' is a stunningly directed drama flick, with a story that's highly intense - even without that much action. It's a very plot-driven and slowly paced story, and for some; kinda boring. It got its moments of symbolism and powerful imagery, but drags on without that much thrills or character moments. Its finale got some of this, but the overall film doesn't. Still; the director of both 'Arrival' and 'Prisoners' succeeds once again with a stunningly directed flick!

Personal rating: 68/100
Critical rating: 80/100

Young idealistic swat team door kicker gets more - and less - then she bargains for after she volunteers to join a DoD drug war task force led by a maverick smartass with a murky agenda.   Even more mysterious is the presence  of a steely-eyed South American who seems to wield almost as much authority over the team.   Sicario  delivers a potent sobering message about the modern war on drugs,  while also serving as they 'Don't Go To Mexico' PSA. Soundtrack contributes a palpable sense of foreboding with it's repetitive low tones more  The music score contributes a palpable sense of foreboding with its repetitive low tones more befitting to a science fiction horror movie.  Richard Deakins' camerawork captures the deep southwestern landscape in eye-widening fashion. Many tension laden sequences, the best of which may be a prisoner transport from Nogal u many tension laden sequences, the best of which may be a prisoner transport from Nogales  back to the USA which has the audience scanning every pedestrian and car seat for trouble through each city block.  The cast is solid led by Benicio del Toro who looms largest with danger reflectted in his cagey demeanor.  My lone gripe is with Emily Blunt's naïveté, and especially how dumb her reactions are to learning some unsavory truths.  What did she possibly think would happen following her  threats of exposure?  Clearly the smart move  would be to play along with your mouth shut, then srab your superiors in the back in your report later, just as they had done to her in the field.

House full of dead bodies and nobody notices until someone actually sees one, she says "where?" He says "around El Paso" then she gets mad because it's not exactly El Paso. It felt like they didn't even try hard when making this movie. But hey, that's just one man's opinion
Weak story and hardly any character development, so it was hard to get attached to anyone. Slow

Though the beginning was agonizingly slow and unpromising, Sicario proved to be much more than a basic "guns and explosions" action movie. Not much is there in the way of Blunt's character's background, but the transformation from the beginning of the story to the end is dramatic and psychologically toll-talking. What at first seems like a random string of fabricated scenes of intensity unravels into a story with a much deeper idea that will take some contemplation to grasp. The cinematography was beautifully done in certain moments, and though the vibe was firm and familiar there was an edge that proved vulnerable, which for action movies in this category is crucial and almost poetic. Despite strong moments, however, there were also negatives. The lack of a resolution to multiple parts of the plot left the movie in a weird haze, and some of the dialogue was just so damn boring. At times Sheridan attempts too much at once, while not focusing on making a single aspect as well as he can. As a piece, Sicario is within a stone's throw of greatness, but comes up short in delivering a story with a hard hitting message.
Incredible pacing, cinematography, and acting.  Very good all around!
Real and eye opening!
Brilliantly acted, beautifully shot, and absolutely flooring, this film is a masterclass of suspense that deals with unsavory moral choices and never lets go of the viewer.

Sicario is a masterclass in suspense and tension.  The whole film is really roughly about 4-5 extended, tense scenes joined by some exposition.  And those set pieces are all absolutely masterful.  The acting from the three main leads is fantastic, and the score is heart-pounding.

Its one issue for me, though, was it felt like it was trying to reach for a larger idea that it never quite captures in a satisfying way.  But still a mesmerizing bit of filmmaking.

Unlike other films, Sicario, in addition to its thrilling set-pieces, begins to stretch your ideas on right and wrong.

WHAT I LIKED: On the one hand, 'Sicario' is one of the most tightly directed thrillers I've ever seen, as Denis Villenuive steers each set piece and scene with such a tight grip and strong punch that it grabs hold of your stomach and twists it into knots. That in-the-moment tension is brought by the fact it takes its time, but is also helped hugely by great performances from Del Toro and Emily Blunt, as well as an incredible score from Jóhann Jóhannsson and unsurprisingly stunning cinematography from Roger Deakins.
WHAT I DIDN'T LIKE: On the other hand, rather like with 'Prisoners,' you can't help feeling all of that is a very gripping and beautiful mask for something that actually holds a fairly weak base indeed. Yes sadly the characters are vastly under-written, and only fill equally evil sides of a fairly simple thematic message. From there, the plot is fairly basic, and all-in-all it consequently lacks ability to engage beyond the nail-biting grit and visual splendor.
VERDICT: 'Sicario' may have you in some moments, but the overall piece is sadly a very mind-numbing, if mostly admirable film.

I was glad to see than one well known critic made a point of describing Emily Blunt's character as "implausible" even though her acting was excellent. With so many great storylines in the world, I have a hard time watching any movie that has characters behaving in absurd or ignorant of incredulous in order to make a storyline work. It makes the whole action too concocted for my tastes.

Even though all the praise for the directing and acting is well-deserved, I found more of my time procured with how dense a person would need to be in order to behave as Blunt's character did. Regardless of one's moral fiber or stubbornness could account for such unbelievable behavior.

As such, the movie was  a 75 for me. As an example, a story can have over-the-top characters and still have them credible. A great example is the character portrayed by Javier Bardem in "No Country for Old Men". Now that was an extreme portrayal but very believable!

Starring Emily Blunt as Kate, the FBI agent who is committed to her convictions, and Benicio Del Toro as Alejandro, a consultant with a shady background. Agent Kate has been enlisted by a task force, led by Alejandro, to help them in their war on drugs in the border between the U.S. and Mexico.

Standout performances from Emily Blunt and Benicio Del Toro complement the film's theme, showing that there is nothing glamorous about the implications of the ongoing war against drugs. You see the distinction between Kate and Alejandro, Kate's committed yet confused and troubled by how they conduct their investigation. While Alejandro is intense yet calm and collected throughout.

I admit, there are times when the film begins to be draggy and how certain scenes, even certain dialogue, tend to be facile. Overall, Sicario is a worthy watch that's anchored on a serious motif that makes its case.

The "War on Drugs," or even illegal drugs themselves, is a tricky cinematic subject; the material is rife with potential for action-based set pieces, but filmmakers need to be careful with their overall "message."  All it takes is a few wrong notes in either one direction or another and the movie could end up being either too preachy or too bleak.  Steven Soderbergh's masterful ensemble 2000 film "Traffic" is a brilliant example of how to do it properly, and now you can add Denis Villeneuve's "Sicario," one of the best films of 2015, to the short list as well.  The two would actually make for a great double-feature, as they both take the drug trade seriously while simultaneously recognizing that this whole effort may be a futile endeavor on the part of our country.
 
Emily Blunt stars as a hardened FBI agent firmly entrenched in the War on Drugs.  As the film begins, she and her partner (Daniel Kaluuya) lead a raid on a drug den later revealed to be operated by a dangerous cartel based out of Mexico.  Although the bust is made, it comes at a cost, and ultimately the agents know this won't have any lasting effects on the ongoing War.  A minor drug bust matters very little to a cartel that has millions of dollars at its disposal.  To that end, Blunt is recruited into a specialized government anti-drug special task force, led by Josh Brolin, where she is told that maybe now she'll be able to make a difference.  Aiding this team is a mysterious consultant (Benicio Del Toro) who possesses both deadly skills and an intimate knowledge of the cartel they're targeting.
 
It doesn't sound like anything special, but Villeneuve and screenwriter Taylor Sheridan have crafted a film that moves with razor-like precision; nothing feels glamorous or "Hollywood-ized," and it works brilliantly as an exercise in prolonged tension.  This is not strictly limited to set pieces (although the film does have its share of those, like a suspenseful motorcade drive across the U.S.-Mexican border and a daring, nightvision-utilizing trek through an underground tunnel).  Much of the time the tension stems from characters-and the audience-not being sure of the motivations of other characters.  Brolin and Del Toro are so secretive that we begin to wonder just what their end-game is, and, perhaps more importantly, why they've brought on Blunt in the first place.
 
I also liked that the film seems to be aware that, just like real life (and, as mentioned above, just like "Traffic"), there is no easy--or, more disturbingly, permanent--solution to the whole thing.  We can tell that Blunt is good at what she does, and she's not a naïve greenhorn to the drug-tackling business.  Yet the film implies that, despite that, she may be a bit too idealistic, something that Brolin and particularly Del Toro recognize almost immediately.  "Sicario" is full of painful lessons, but one of the hardest is that, in order to make any kind of progress in this dirty business, one may have to be willing to compromise, particularly when it comes to one's values.
 
This aspect of the film is likely to anger some viewers, but I sense a hard-edged truth there that I found both interesting and unsettling.  This actually makes the film a bit different than "Traffic," as although that movie also dealt with difficult truths, it also provided a larger degree of hope, and the compromises the characters had to make didn't feel as drastic.  "Sicario" takes a worldview that is considerably more despondent.  That doesn't make it better or worse; it's just another side of the same coin.
 
Anchoring the film are the fine performances by the three leads.  Emily Blunt has become one of my favorite actresses.  She's shown before that she can handle steely, action-oriented roles (see also the superb "Edge of Tomorrow"), but her part here goes deeper than that.  She's clearly capable in the action scenes, but she projects a sort of melancholy world-weariness in the quieter ones, and this where her work stands out the most.  Her banter with Daniel Kaluuya, who's also quite good in a smaller role, feels warm and genuine.
 
This is one of Josh Brolin's finest performances, infusing his character with a sort of flippant casualness that flies in the face of all the mayhem he's embroiled in.  As for Benicio Del Toro, the common link between "Sicario" and "Traffic," his work is likely to go more unnoticed since his role isn't as "showy" as some of the others, but his stoic presence wonderfully conveys a sense of authority and experience as well as a dash of menace, which is crucial to both the character and the proceedings.
 
This is a great film, the kind you immediately want to watch again after it's over.  If you haven't already seen it, check it out.
A good 'slow burn' sort of movie. An examination of fighting the drug trade.

Denis Villeneuve is a director who creates visually stunning scenes and tense emotion, whether it is in Prisoners, Enemy, or Arrival. Sicario is no different, and I really hope I see his take on other genre films. This one - an action thriller set in the legally ambiguous world of the US/Mexican border. Emily Blunt is great as an idealistic FBI agent who stumbles into this world with Josh Brolin. But Benicio Del Toro steals the show with a vengeance, and it is no wonder that a sequel based on his character is in the works. I really would love to see more of him. I recommend it and I think that even his weakest work will be better than most directors' strongest.

A friend clued me into this movie.  Fantastic.  It's a bit of a Western shoot em up but with the claustrophobic sense that the problem cannot be solved by more violence from the gun-slinging cowboy (cowgirl).  Instead the movie offers real people involved in complex situations of violence and desperation.  Some great analysis has been done on the various scenes, especially the gun fight in the toll booth; but what I was moved by was the humanity of the thugs who get creamed by the CIA agents.  Yes they were gangsters and bent on horrible violence, but the way Villeneuve treats them they have moments that reveal their fear, their indecision, their attempt to muster the grit to perform the violence... in short, their humanity.  They are no more cardboard characters than anyone else in this fine movie.  Great story, camera work by Deakins, music by Johannsson, directing and pacing are great - moments of extreme tension throughout the movie.  The violence, language, are not gratuitous but work to further the vision of the movie.  Really fine piece of cinema.

An exhilaratingly powerful film from director Denis Villeneuve, who directed Prisoners and Enemy, which I thoroughly recommend. What I like about these two films and Sicario is that they're not afraid to shock the audience with spontaneous violence, twists, turns and intense drama.

Sicario is beautiful to look at with eye-catching locations and cinematography that adds to the action scenes, making them appear more realistic than the average action film. It's beautiful to listen to as well with a powerfully intense score that draws you into the characters emotions. Johan Johansson who also worked with Denis Villeneuve on Prisoners, is quickly becoming one of my favourite musical composers for film.

A strong cast with an amazing performance from a favourite of mine, Benicio Del Toro. Benicio portrayed a character that was intriguing and unpredictable, adding to the intense feel of the film. I was also pleased to see Daniel Kaluuya, Posh Kenneth from Skins, performing in this film. A nice surprise and a good performance from him and the rest of the cast. 

The only thing that lets Sicario down? The story. I feel it had a good base narrative, but I expected it to go into more detail and become a more immersive experience as a viewer. This is a small negative for what is a superbly well-produced film, made with a cast and crew on fine form.

Denis Villeneuve has a real hard on for moral turpitude. Sicario, like Prisoners before it, is tightly controlled, hard to watch whilst hard to take your eyes off. Working again with the cutting edge digital work of veteran DP Roger Deakins, it's unflinching gaze fixates on the terrible things men justify in fighting evil, and the film dives headlong into that murky moral quagmire with no comfortable resolution, and all of that ambiguity and uncertainty and darkness contained in another hypnotic collection of performances. The film has two or three masterfully handled extended suspense sequences, alternately almost bleached out and cloaked in night, the interplay of light and dark and the queasy, interminable shadows the film forces us to peer into.

FBI field agent Kate Macer is approached to join a special anti-drugs task force that also involves the Department of Defense and the Department of Justice.  She is given very little information about the methods or aims of the task force, except that it is going after senior members of a Mexican drug cartel.  She soon realises that their methods are quite unorthodox, even potentially illegal, and the aim may be even more unconventional.

Great action-thriller, directed by Denis Villeneuve (Prisoners, Incendies).  Slow-burning intensity with a great deal of intrigue.  Not your average cops-and-drug-dealers story in that, like the lead character, the viewer is kept in the dark about much of the objectives of the mission.  This keeps you guessing and makes the reveal even more profound in its impact.

Great, realistic action scenes and good special effects.

After showing herself to be a very good action performer in Edge of Tomorrow, Emily Blunt gets another opportunity to further those credentials.  Less action for her in this, but enough, and she does well.  I can see her being the go-to female action star for a few years to come.

Good support from Josh Brolin, Benicio Del Toro and Daniel Kaluuya.

The end message is a bit unsatisfactory and the target for derision too easy, and those would be the main negatives.  Otherwise, a very good movie.

They could have upped the plot twists or the violence I think, and perhaps made the ending more harrowing. BUT if you're looking for a suspenseful procedural thriller, look no further. Side note- Emily Blunt's performance in this reminded me strongly of Cillian Murphy.

Grim-as-all-hell look at the drug wars, as FBI agent Emily Blunt gets co-opted into Josh Brolin's operation in Mexico.  It's not quite clear who Brolin works for but he's accompanied by brooding Benicio del Toro who we come to understand represents the title character, a veteran of the brutal and sickening war between the cartels.  Canadian director Denis Villaneuve handles action well and the bloody violence here feels less gratuitous than just a matter-of-course for this plot and probably the real thing.  But there is a lot of violence and the dusty desert locations and forboding soundtrack don't brighten things up at all.  The intrigue lies in trying to understand what is going on but there is little cheerful pay-off in finding out.  Blunt is solid in her role but mostly left clueless and frustrated.  Viewers may feel similarly but the film does move quickly and hits that sad cynical spot.

Sicario is a movie that explores dark, real life themes, backed by amazing cinematography and character performances. It's thrilling from start to finish, wrapping itself in a perfect bow to be enjoyed by nearly all.

An FBI agent joins a task force in a border-crossing battle in the war on drugs.
This would be a great movie if the protagonist wasn't basically useless. Doe-eyed in parts, foolish in others, and mostly stripped of any real chutzpah, Macy, played by the usually awesome Emily Blunt, is the opposite of a compelling character; most of the plot happens to her, and the few occasions when she has the opportunity to shape the story, gutless screenwriting thwarts any chance that Macy has to be compelling. The supporting characters are far more interesting, especially personal-vendetta-driven Alejandro. Their amoral commitment is far more interesting than Macy's moral tergiversation. 
The film's brutal depiction of the borderland's social and political battles is actually as intelligent as the great classic Traffic as the film seems to have a nuanced understanding of how even everyday people's lives are thrown into disarray.
Overall, if only the protagonist wasn't such a boring character, this would've been an incredibly compelling film.

***** Excellent
Director Denis Villenueve has imported in a tour-de-force picture in "Sicario". The movie stars Emily Blunt as FBI Agent Kate Mercer. She is recruited by the mercy (sort of, kind of) of a U.S. government task force to aid in the escalating war against drugs at the border area between the U.S. and Mexico. Half mercy on Mercer because even though she volunteered for the journey, this is not what she envisioned it to be. Josh Brolin co-stars as the Government Agent Matt Graver who does not want to dig his own grave in this dangerous mission, so he manipulates Mercer in ways I will not reveal. At the center of this mission, is the mysterious Alejandro played by Benicio Del Toro. Villenueve marveled in his orchestration of "Sicario" by keeping it tense and unpredictable. Taylor Sheridan's screenplay was a little bit of a bust, but not so much to lessen the movie's strength. Blunt delivers the best performance of her career as Mercer; and Mercy, Mercy, Me why in the world was she not nominated for a Best Actress Oscar! Brolin was his usual steady self in his work as Graver. Del Toro was the scene stealer of the movie though, and there were plenty of hits to that statement; I will just leave it at that. "Sicario" is sic!! And A must see, so open your borders for it.

One of the best mystery/thrillers made in 21st century. The cast is awesome, even though Benicio Del Toro steals the show, the story wrapped so tight that you are constantly confused until the end (this marked the first time in a long time where I couldn't guess what was gonna happen next) and with the worlds greatest cinematographer Roger Deakins shooting the film, the end result looks simply amazing.
Director Denis Villeneuve is seriously a one to watch, I think it's safe to say he is the next David Fincher.

I enjoyed Sicario in spite of the Emily Blunt character. I'm sure the writer tried to do a cross between No Country for Old Men and Point Break where the newbie Blunt is challenged by the realities of the Mexican drug war but that part just didn't jell for me. IMHO, I found her Kate character annoying, confused and petulant at times.
 With that being said, Benicio Del Toro gives an engrossing performance as a "DOD adviser" with a secret and parallel agenda involving some very bad drug lords. He's somehow part of the Medellin cartel but is recruited (?) to take on one of the Mexican drug lords.
 The action scenes are generally put together pretty well though there was a bit of fantasy since the characters are not concerned about the press as they shoot up several car-fuls of bad guys in the middle of a busy traffic . I mean this is the age of instant streaming using cell phones etc.! 
Still, a pretty amusing movie if you can ignore Blunt as Kate and just enjoy Toro being moody. Three stars.

The war on drugs is an on going battle, and this film focuses on the drug cartel and border between Mexico and the U. S. Team of elite forces Brolin and Del Toro enlist a new rookie in Emily Blunt to take on the hard hitting brutality of the enforcement. Blunt's character confronts a complex and lurking issue today, admitting the audience to the realization of the scope and obscurity of the drug market.

We slowly come to understand that these issues have become obscure to the point that their cannot be any understanding, ultimately.

Garcia's?(I forgot his name, will be back to edit).  Blunt expresses a confliction about the particularly vile nature of these operations she has taken part in, and as well tragically accepts the realistic necessity of them.

Sicario was a movie that sucked me in right from the start. With taut directing, tense action set pieces, and powerful, understated performances, it's a technical wonder. The story unfolds slowly and methodically, and we see everything through the protagonists eyes as they're widened by a world she was aware of but could not fully contemplate. Many of the action scenes, which in a typical modern movie would be set to a heavy, pounding score, are done with almost no music at all. It might come across as boring and uninvolving to some, but to me it felt like the movie was truly mimicking real life, where these moments have no soundtrack, and all you can hear is what is happening all around you. At times the film does feel like it's spinning its wheels, and many of the acting turns seem dialled down so low they might as well be sleepwalking, but it makes their lash out moment feel more genuine and deserved. If you like a tense movie that takes its time, builds atmosphere and character and doesn't simply rush between action scenes, Sicario is well worth your time.

"Sicario" is an amazing drama/action movie of 2015. The plot to "Sicario" is an F.B.I. agent named "Kate" portrayed by "Emily Blunt" is working in "Mexico" with a team to bring down a large drug dealer. The first scene of the movie is exciting and thrilling; the scene shows the F.B.I. searching through a house where it's believed a drug dealer is hiding. Most of the movie shows "Kate" going through a struggle of weather she is doing the right thing or making a mistake. These scenes are great, they show the type of person "Kate" is. The film's climax is very unexpected and is a perfect finish to a superb film. There are some scenes of the movie that show the drug dealer and how he lives his life. Those scenes at times can be boring and dull. The movie's plot is great it contains a dark tone; which fits in perfectly. "Emilia Blunt" does a stunning performance as the protagonist "Kate".  "Benicoio Del Toro" also did a splendid job as the character "Alejandro". "Jóhann Jóhannsson" did an okay job at composing sad and dramatic music, but some scenes the dramatic music is lacking and brings down the movie's quality. "Sicario" is filmed well throughout the first part of the film but after the camera quality is not as well filmed. The action sequences in this film are very intense and unexpected which make them even better. As stated before some sequences don't work due lack of good camera work. If you are a person who enjoys dark action films then I highly recommend you watch "Sicario" as it has stunning action, good action sequences and a terrific climax. Although the movie has some issues these being a uninteresting side plot, more dramatic music for certain scenes and better camera work. I give 2015's "Sicario" a 9/10.

I've been waiting with anticipation for this film for about a year, and let me be honest, it did not disappoint! Sicario, is Canadian director Denis Villneuve's return to storytelling at his absolute best.

The film takes place in the south of the United States, and Mexico, as FBI agent Kate Macer (Emily Blunt) joins a team of military personnel to cross into the Mexican border town of Juarez, in order to bring down some of the biggest criminals in the Cartels. Benicio Del Toro plays a former Colombian lawyer Alejandro and Josh Brolin joins as CIA spook Matt Graver. I enjoyed watching their characters interact with each-other and particularly found Emily Blunt a sensitive yet determined agent, despite her lack of physical prowess. Well acted all the way through.

What really makes the film a pleasure to watch is how well the story it told through the cinematography and direction of some of the best in Hollywood. In my opinion, Villneuve's Best; 'Prisoners' (2013) was a much more personal story. He takes on a much larger and hugely difficult topic on how the U.S approaches, and deals with the violent drug cartels pushing mostly cocaine and heroin across the U.S/Mexico border. He manages to approach the subject objectively, even though we may not understand the depth of such a difficult problem. I thought the director's style wasn't his usual approach to film making, yet it still has just enough grit and depth of story to make it interesting.

Well acted, and very well told. In my opinion this puts Villneuve in the top echelon of cinema direction.

I sat down with a bowl of popcorn, well a pop-up bowl of popcorn, saving myself the arduous task of cleaning a bowl after I finished.  Next, I turned on the movie Sicario.  My last experience with Emily Blunt was an excellent one in Edge of Tomorrow, so I figured I'd give her a second opportunity to impress me.

The opening scene is enthralling.  From the get go you are fed tension as the FBI raid happens.  The action is smooth and realistic mixed with just the right amount of fear.  By this time, barely two minutes into the movie I had already stopped eating my popcorn due to the interest I had in the action.

What follows is an amazing job at isolating Emily Blunt's character, Kate.  Every shot has her being the odd man out.  Isolating her and making her feel alone in club where she does not belong.  It creates a feeling of unease when the interactions between Kate and Alejandro (Del Toro's character) begin.  Not to mention the tension Josh Brolin brings.

There are small details in the cinematography that make you appreciate the effort that went into making the movie.  The sweeping shots of the US military bases with the rows and rows of helicopters, jeeps, and tanks only help reinforce the seriousness of the situation.  The first of the details that I noticed was when the convoy moved into Mexico and stopped briefly on the street.  There is this small rack focus to the wall where there are posters of young women, presumably missing.  It may be a small detail but it helps paint that bigger picture of a place without order.

Looking back at Roger Deakins' credits, it is no wonder I am in love with the visuals.  Skyfall was gorgeous.  Not to mention True Grit and No Country For Old Men.  Out of his previous works I would have to point to Jarhead, and Sicario having a reminiscent feeling of it, which is a good thing.

One thing I now regret is not seeing this movie in theaters.  The sound system I have is lacking, but even then I enjoyed what was presented to me.  The low beats, repeating over and over, building that tension and making you clench in anticipation.  The last movie I felt this way about was Rush, and there are few others I feel this way about.

Overall, Sicario is engaging.  It combines the right amount of action with everything else so as not to bore the viewer.  Great visuals, score, acting, and character development.  Everything you could want in a viewing experience.

Incredible, powerful film. Dennis Villeneuve is well and truly one of my favourite directors now, and after being blown away by the cinematography here I wasn't remotely surprised to see the legendary Roger Deakins was behind it.

Relentlessly tense, bleak, and brutal, with an ominous and unsettling soundtrack by Jóhann Jóhannsson, this is a chilling film impeccably acted by its 3 leads, especially Del Toro. 

I've seen some criticisms of Blunt's character, but I think allegations of anti-feminism and weakness of character totally miss the fact that she's VERY strong, but in the situation she's in, it doesn't matter, it doesn't help. The reality of the situation robs her of any power, a fact she slowly comes to realise. 

Like all of Villeneuve's films, I could go on about this for a long time (not quite so much as 'Enemy', which was such a mind**** as to lend itself to so many interpretations that discussion and contemplation are almost a necessary consequence of having seen it), and look forward to seeing again as soon as possible.

Also proves that men are total dicks. Guess they figured that it’s easier to manipulate a female than a male.
Outstanding. Did expect that ending, but I'm glad it went that way.
Very suspenseful. A must see.

Denis Villeneuve continues his hot-streak with the grisly thriller Sicario. The whole commits whole-heartedly to the dark, twisted world of Sicario, resulting in a film that can't help but immerse viewers in a thick, discomforting, and wholly uncompromising atmosphere.

Fantastic mystery/thriller. The pacing is excellent and the plot is interesting and complex enough while remaining simple enough to grasp. I especially enjoyed Villaneuve's masterful cinematography. Every shot is wonderfully composed, with symmetry and vibrant colors. He does well to set the stage with wonderful shots of the Mexican and Arizonan landscapes, congested city of Juarez, and the homes of the drug lords - contrasting the inequality of the drug cartels. Especially penetrating was the illustration of the collateral damage -- the officer Silvio narrative arc was the most poignant expression of this theme. All around fantastic.
Excellent, with acting as its core and a story line and set pieces that scream Oscar nod. It's up for cinematography; however, it's 3rd in my mind, behind Mad Max: Fury Road and The Revenant.
total sleeper hit. watch it

Huh, oh sorry I didn't realize I had fallen asleep, again, trying to get through this snooze fest. Someone attached to this film must be holding something very big over Rotten Tomatoes to get such an undeserved high rating. 
Director Denis Villeneuve successfully pulls you into what seems like a taut thriller in the first 15 minutes and then very successfully puts you to sleep for the next 1 hour and 45 minutes of excruciating boredom. Villeneuve has no idea what the word "pacing" means to a film. 
Director Denis Villeneuve is rumored to be attached to the next Blade Runner movie, I hope that is not true.

Sicario is a very well directed and beautifully shot movie that follows an FBI agent who is enlisted by a governmental task force to aid in the escalating war against drugs.The film is directed by Denis Villeneuve and the lead stars are Emily Blunt, Benicio del Toro and Josh Brolin.
The main things that stand out from this movie are the acting, directing and the brilliant cinematography from the amazing Roger Deakins who can do no wrong.Everybody in the movie is amazing, especially Emily Blunt, who is traumatized most of the time and this is certainly one of the best roles I have ever seen her play. Benicio del Toro also really surprised me and his character is really mysterious.
The action in this movie, while there's not much of it, it was still great and very intense. Also, the score is amazing by Jóhann Jóhannsson and it totally deserved the Oscar nomination.
However this movie is very slow in some parts and it feels like it's dragging on for quite a while. There are some good intense sequences but at the same time some slow parts that go on forever. The ending is also weird with a surprise twist. 
Nonetheless I enjoyed this movie but I wouldn't say it's one of the 2015's best.
BENICIO IS VERY INTERESTING NOT ONLY IN MOVIES BUT INTERVIEWS

A great movie about what is going on along the border in these times...how in the heck is this outstanding movie not up for a ton of Oscars including "Best Picture/Best Actress"!!! A big time FBI/CIA/Drug Cartel life along the USA/Mexico border crime-suspense-thriller!!!

This is a film that should have been nominated for best picture. It is tense, harrowing, action packed, and will leave you feeling winded and disturbed. The cast is fantastic, the cinematography (which did get nominated) is jaw-dropping, and the direction is flawless. This is one of the best films of 2015.

The annual gray fight-against-terrorism movie.  So this is about an FBI agent (Emily Blunt) who gets recruited to be on a special task force.  They have been assembled to combat the transportation of narcotics across the U.S./Mexican border, and they have a high priority target in their sights.  This is very similar to number of movies we have seen in recent years, and they are usually made my Kathryn Bigelow.  This is very much in the same vein as Zero Dark Thirty and The Hurt Locker, and these are all movies that I do like and feel that they are all high in quality, but, at the same time, I can't go without saying that they're all strikingly impersonal, and I never cross that line from liking it to loving it.  Now this came about early enough in the year where it could potentially get lost in the Oscar season shuffle, and for the most part, I would say that it did, only getting a handful of nominations for technical awards.  Nevertheless, this has still been getting very good word of mouth.  It's easy to get into, as it puts you in this Training Day situation of this newbie getting thrown right into the fire, as she is an idealistic girl in this boy's club.  It is so quick that she is thrown into this kill or be killed environment, and you never forget that she is surrounded by a bunch of jackals who determine what's right and what's wrong on a level that's above the law.  It's gritty and it puts you right in the moment, and one of the strongest aspects to Sicario is that you never feel safe.  The best part of Sicario is when they get to Juarez.  Through the entire scene, you are nervous and stressed out as can be.  It climaxes with this traffic sequence that I can guarantee will put you at the edge of your seat.  That said, there's about another hour left in the movie, and the rest of the movie is never as satisfying as that one sequence.  The cinematography is great (Roger Deakins always turns in amazing work), and I really enjoyed the surreal score that added an unexpected element to it.  Sicario is a really good movie, but for me, it falls just shy of being one of the best of the year, and I couldn't find a spot for it on my best of list accordingly.
The cast is great, especially Benicio Del Toro. Also, the story is compelling. It is definitely worth checking out if you have not seen it yet.
I liked it. Realistic, brutal.  Somewhat similar to 71'

Again a movie that had the earmarks of a contender that went sideways a bit.  It has it's moments but overall it lets you down as it drags a bit.  Good acting as usual from the usual suspects but somewhere the director lost this one a bit I believe.
Amazing drama & intense action!

The first one-third is incredibly exhilarating with well-paced action sequences and adequate tension build-up thanks to mysterious (and thus interesting) characters, authentic-looked setting, and stylish minimalism in editing. But the rest is simply dwindling in comparison, with a seriously under-used Emily Blunt, an under-developed storyline, and an dissatisfying closure (it seems that such ending serves as "opener" for a sequence, but this film's premise is good enough for an excellent standalone, why did they have to try to grab money from such good film?). Del Toro is still reliable as ever, but both Josh Brolin and especially Emily Blunt do not have any moment to shine with their one-sided characters. As any other film by Denis Villeneuve, the film's technicality is impeccable, but the lacklustre second half really hurts its chance to win major awards. An entertaining film by any mean, but Mexicans' suffering due to the drug war deserves a better cinematic depiction than this.
I liked the movie, didnt love it!! I guess I wanted more than I received. A cool flick, though nothing special.

I wish the film continued with the high stakes that appeared in the first few minutes of the film because it was all downhill from there and really boring. some parts were good, but overall, i didn't care for it.
Awesome movie, one of my favorites. It had a great ending. Great actor choices and really good directing!

Moody, dark, yet emotionally distant, this war on drugs on the front lines certainly feels authentic and some of the cinematography brilliantly and creatively takes the viewer into places we'd rather not go. Despite the grit and virtuoso filmmaking, something still feels off, from the less than believable characters to the motivations to some contrived moments.
Hard hitting and realistic. Great action and story from the start. Good photography which gave a documentary style which put you into the action.

Given the amount of critical praise this movie has gotten, I was a little disappointed in the final product.  I suppose I was expecting a more straight forward film.  I was immediately hooked into the violent opening sequence, but the plot that developed about the Mexican drug trade was more frustrating than satisfying due to the fact that it's more about accepting a bad situation rather than changing it.  I was hoping Emily Blunt's character wouldn't be so impotent, but I guess she represents an ideal that isn't possible.  Nonetheless, while it's not the kind of film I'd watch again, I suppose my sense of unease with it shows the impact a more realistic kind of story like this can have.
Slow moving, but extremely intense... and awesome. And music. Yes.

With flavours of The Kingdom and Traffic, Sicario starts with such a powerful momentum that it digresses in its course and falls short of expectations leaving more loose ends than a suspense thriller should.

All said, Sicario still achieves commanding performances from a renowned leading trio, and indeed the cinematography is something to behold. So far as script and soundtrack are concerned; the context became distracted and blurred by the overbearing augmentation of irrelevant ambient noises. 

To conclude, this is a film that maintains a fiery suspense for 75% of its two hour duration, but simply looses traction and ends in an unsatisfying sequence of scenes.

While it doesn't necessarily offer a showcase of stellar acting, it does deliver an audiovisual feast of stunning landscapes, creative camera work, and a dark, somber score that hums like reliable engine.
Emily Blunt is fantastic. I just wish the film had a little more resolution. A very on edge film.

cinegeek.de Sicario eröffnet mit zwei Indikatoren einer brutalen Welt: Der erste, eine furchtbare Entdeckung, der zweite eine Explosion. Beide begründen den folgenden für uns befriedigenden Thriller (und genaus diese Tatsache bereitet mir Magenschmerzen). Wir befinden uns in einem Universum, in dem das Böse schlicht exisitiert. In dieser Welt kann Gewalt einfach so ausbrechen, Leben nehmen oder niederschmettern. Sicario schafft leider tiefe Befriedigung. Der Film untersucht den Krieg ohne Regeln oder Verpflichtungen mit einem spektakulären Auftritt von Benicio Del Toro und der faszinierenden Cinematographie von Roger Deakins. Böse Zungen behaupteten, Sicario sei zu ausschweifend und prätentiös. Sicario fehle deshalb die Dringlichkeit eines wahrhaft grossartigen Thrillers. Ich muss zugeben, dass mich diese Ansicht wütend macht, so ergriffen war ich von Villenueves Film. Sicario funktioniert, weil er sich die Zeit nimmt, den Schauplatz der Grenze Arizonas zu Mexikos zu beleuchten. Wie könnten wir uns sonst in dieser unvorstellbar grausamen Welt zurecht finden? In der ersten Szene versucht die FBI Agentin Kate Macy (Emily Blunt) das Opfer einer Entführung in Arizona aufzuspüren. Kurz blicken wir in ihr Gesicht: Furcht und Entschlossenheit vor dem Zugriff. Sie bricht mit einem Truck durch die Wand eines Hauses, erschiesst einen Täter, der seine Waffe gegen sie richtet. In ihren Augen blitzt Verzweiflung auf. Macy ist ausgesprochen menschlich und noch nicht abgestumpft. Ein Schuss reisst ein Loch in die Wand des Gebäudes und es kommen Leichen zum Vorschein. Mehr als 20, mehr als 30 tote Körper. Das gesamte Gebäude ist gefüllt mit Leichen - während des schockierenden Anblicks reisst eine Explosion draussen im Schuppen zwei Beamte in den Tod. Macy handelt ohne zu zögern und streng nach Vorschrift, was ihre Vorgesetzten beeindruckt. Sie wird vorgeladen zu einem Treffen einer Task Force, geleitet vom mysteriösen Matt (Josh Brolin). Seine Identität bleibt wie die gesamte Operation verborgen. Man arbeitet zusammen mit dem düster wirkenden Alejandro (Benicio Del Toro) - von dem nicht einmal sicher fest gestellt werden kann, ob er nicht einfach nur als Söldner dient. ihr Einsatz findet in Mexiko statt und endet blutig. Wo ist der Zusammenhang zwischen dem Leichenhaus in Arizona und der rechtslosen Stadt Juarez in Mexiko? Die Drogen Barone sind dort so prominent, dass sie Leichen verkehrt herum an der Hochstrasse aufhängen können. Der Befehl lautet, einen Drogen Schieber zu stellen und in die USA zu überführen. Auf dem Rückweg gerät der Convoy in einen Stau (man hatte sie vorgewarnt, dass explizit der Rückweg gefährlich sei). Während das Unternehmen im Stau feststeckt, blicken wir in verschiedene Autos: Wir erblicken tätowierte Gestalten, bewaffnet. Die Szene gehört zu den besten in der Disziplin des Aufbaus von Spannung überhaupt: Gewalt liegt in der Luft und wird ausbrechen... Das Drehbuch von Sicario entwickelt nicht nur einen Hauptcharakter. Macy nimmt oft nur die Position einer Beobachterin ein, während Matt und Alejandro agieren. Sollte es möglich sein, dass Macy eben nur zu diesem Zweck angeheuert wurde? Im Kern kreiert Sicario eine Welt ohne Anführer, die im Chaos versinkt. Dementsprechend kann sich Macy während des gesamten Films nicht zurecht finden, da keine Grundregeln existieren. Denis Villeneuve kann sich auf die Anziehung Del Toros verlassen, die fast magnetisch wirkt. Ihm gebürt der Showdown, der gnadenlos und radikal abläuft. Wir merken, dass der Kanadier Villeneuve auch in seinem dritten US amerikanischen Film nicht von Hollywood korrumpiert wurde: Emily Blunt als Heroine? Mir scheint sie in gefangen in einer unerhört altmodischen Frauenrolle, die Hollywood so gar nicht mehr vergibt. Sollte sie jemals aktiv an diesem Einsatz mitwirken oder bloss Bericht erstatten? Rechtfertigt sie einfach nur die Unrechtmässigkeit der Operation? Benicio Del Toro dagegen als dunkler Held? Provoziert der Film, dass wir uns mit seinem Feldzug gemein machen? Bestaunen wir einen Mann, der innerlich längst abgestorben ist? Ist ausser mir noch jemandem aufgefallen, dass wir Zeuge einer angedeuteten Zuneigung zwischen Macy und Alejandro werden? Ich muss mir Sicario noch einmal ansehen. In diesem Moment fühle ich mich nur elend und schockiert.
Okay movie. Not feeling the storyline or ending. Expected so much more.

Daring and provocative, Sicario is a gritty political thriller about drug trafficking.  The story follows an FBI agent who joins a joint task force to go after a Mexican drug cartel, but their unconventional methods and tactics soon leads the agent to doubt the mission and shakes her believe in the system.  Starring Emily Blunt, Benicio Del Toro, and Josh Brolin, the film has an impressive cast that delivers some excellent performances.  And the director brings a lot of intensity and suspense to the scenes.  The film also does a good job at exploring the moral ambiguities and complexities of the war on drugs; however there is a bit of a political agenda at play.  Additionally, there are some weaknesses in the plot and some underdeveloped characters.  Yet while it has a few problems, Sicario, is a dark and edgy film that's quite challenging.
Really good, fast-moving, gripping... Grabs your attention from the very start - to finish. Emily Blunt and Benicio Del Toro are both great in this movie.

Usually I'm bothered by present-day films in which the heroine can do no wrong. This movie however is a throwback to the misogynistic films of old, the backlash to which created the ridiculous politically correct superwomen of newer popular movies. Featuring nothing less than a slut-shaming scene in which the heroine needs to be saved by the hot macho heroes from being killed by her one-night-stand gone bad. And boy does she feel guilty after. But this scene is merely the lowest point of a film in which the female lead does virtually nothing but look confused while the men around her boss her around, keep secrets, run the show entirely. We are told at one point she is only around because she is the sole member of the secretive group who is actually a cop. What an honour. 
 Besides that, this is really nothing more than another cynical action movie whose entire premise seems to be that the war on drug cartels is a farce (duh), with a lot of shootin' and stuff blowin' up. It's riveting, and makes for a fun evening but, like our slut-shamed heroine, you'll regret it later.

"Sicario" es una excelente película de un excelente director.  Denis Vileneuve ("Incendies", "Prisoners") que nos introduce en un mundo de pesadilla llamado el Cartel de México, a través de los ojos de una agente del FBI llamada Kate Mercer (una estupenda Emily Blunt).  Mercer es reclutada por el jefe de operaciones Matt Graver (un sólido Josh Brolin) para tratar de combatir a esa enorme y violenta bestia.  Y junto a Graver, aparece un enigmático asociado llamado Alejandro (un minimalista Benicio Del Toro) quien busca algo más de la asociación.  La fotografía de Roger Deakins, la música de Jóhann Jóhannsson, la dirección de Villeneuve y  las actuaciones de su elenco hacen de "Sicario" una de las mejores películas sobre la guerra contra el narcotráfico, junto a las obras maestras "Traffic" de Steven Soderbergh y "Miami Vice" de Michael Mann.  No se la pierda.

I'm in a period in which I am not very inspired in expressing my opinions, and so I just can say that I didn't find it extremely interesting. The topic surely is interesting, but maybe could have been showed better.

Sicario is more than just an action-thriller about the brutal, pointless drug war in North America. Its graphic depictions and nihilistic tone flip a sizzling pan of heroin into your face over and over again, forcing you to confront the grim realities of wealth, power and addiction.

The cinematography is a treat and the bleak landscapes of the American desert and the gang riddled ghettos of Mexico are themselves a metaphor for the emptiness of the struggle our characters endure. Benicio Del Toro, Josh Brolin and Emily Blunt all put in excellent performances and the script is clean and efficient, eschewing needless exposition in favor of short, smart dialogue that focuses on pushing the plot forward and not wasting time or insulting the intelligence of its audience. The ominous soundtrack and excellent pacing keep you on the edge of your seat as you move from one barbaric encounter to the next.

If you see only two films released in 2015, they should be Mad Max - Fury Road and Sicario.
Intenso, inteligente, impactante, magníficas actuaciones. Sicario encontró la formula exacta para mantenerte atrapado a la pantalla; ésta es sin duda una de las mejores películas del género policial.

Sicario is one of those films, that comes along every once in a while; and you love it, but you really can't quite work out why. Is it the haunting music? Or the chilling and emotional acting? Is it the characters? Or the scenery? It's really a combination. That's how good films work.

Excellent directing and cinematography, and a thoughtful script, make "Sicario" an impressive film, albeit slowly paced.  The acting is superb from all, except possibly Blunt, whose occasional, affected naivety and weakness blended implausibly with the self-assured, tough and jaded agent who volunteers for an obviously dangerous assignment.  On the one hand, she's tough as nails, is perfectly willing to consider shooting another agent in the back, and agrees to be on a team she is explicitly told is operating outside of the law.  Yet on the other hand, she breaks down at times and is freaked out when she sees someone of the team acting outside of the law.  Well, which one is it, Emily?!  Are you a gritty cop or an idealist?  It was like seeing two different characters on the screen, depending on what suited to moment most impact-fully.  If one just approaches the film accepting that Blunt's character is just a bit unstable, then the film is excellent and entertaining.  Otherwise, it's confusing and manipulative.

Overall Sicario is not a film I would recommend for people to see. The whole film lacks emotions and strength making it a pretty weak overall film.

Once again a film comes along that blurs the line between just what constitutes good and bad, and just what some people are willing to do to get the job done. Don't go into Sicario if you are expecting a film full of sunshine and roses, though it is exquisitely shot and very well thought out. Blunt, Brolin and Del Toro are all on a superbly level playing field here, neither seemingly willing to let the other out act them. Perhaps even Blunt's naive and almost goody two shoes character is merely a vehicle for us as the audience to peer through a window into a world that like her young FBI agent we don't really want to see.

Impossible to review this without mentioning Michael Mann and Zero Dark Thirty, and this holds its own to those comparisons. This is a breathtaking film at times. Brutal and suspenseful in its depiction of betrayal, street justice, and corruption, from the dirty underpasses of Ciudad Juarez to the lavish mansions of drug cartel kingpins. The whole, nausea-inducing sequence (in terms of both cinematography and graphic content) of the black SUV motorcade entering Mexico with Policia Jeep escorts, getting their man, then instigating a violent bloodbath right in the immigration lanes into the US, was the second-most anxious I felt at the movies this year (second to "Room"). Johann Johannsson's ominous, gut-sinking score - with its blend of classic strings and modern synths - is nominated for an Oscar, and rightfully so. 

What nearly ruined the movie for me, though, is that while this is a story that needed to be told, the creators invented a paper-thin "tough woman" character to be the lens through which the story is told. Cold yet vulnerable Emily Blunt plays Kate Macer, a tough woman FBI agent chosen for special ops (why are tough ladycops always named Kate?), but despite her physical toughness, she acts as nothing more than a bland moral compass. Her idealism is hardly motivated at all. Is she haunted by a past case gone wrong? Does she have a backstory for joining the FBI? How did she get so respected in her field of kidnap response? The character is basically there as the audience proxy to question the shady dealings of Benecio Del Toro's Alejandro, who helps the team but for his own reasons. 

Kate doesn't seem to have agency of her own. Her junior partner is the one to finally get the straight dope from her special ops handlers (and to make some derisive comments about her nonexistent hygiene and beauty routine, ostensibly to make her seem like "one of the guys," but just comes off as unnecessary patriarchal banter), and *SPOILERS* when she does get the gumption to pull a gun on Alejandro and deck Matt, it's like, "Why would she do that? What makes her so righteous yet foolhardy?" She fights back, but blindly. Although both Blunt and Del Toro are good in the scene in which Alejandro tenderly threatens her life unless she sanctions their sins in the name of the lesser evil and she pulls her gun on him AGAIN (really?!), Kate's brave resistance is really only written in for show.
Beautifully filmed, superbly acted by the three leads, and reminiscent of Apocalypse Now to describe the endless battle of the war on Drugs. The climax will leave you floored.

Excellent movie. High energy. A must see!!

I normally avoid crime dramas. This one was not bad, kept me engaged and interested the whole time, and I felt like it taught me a little bit about the topic. The conspiracy theory about the us government controlling the drug trade and being in league with columbian drug cartel is an interesting one with perhaps a grain of truth. The message of the sisyphean nature of the war on drugs is a true one that I appreciate, plus the reflection of both the ground cop naievete and the deep agent cynicism is a true one and well-acted. Overall, believable story and not bad for being a genre film I don't normally like.
A gritty, realistic 'shades of grey' flick about the drug war... with no real heroes to be found.  Tense and gripping for sure... but so possibly realistic I might not want to watch it again.

Review:
I must admit, I did think that this movie was going to be much better than it was. I loved the scenes at the end, when Del Toro became a one man army on a mission but the rest of the movie was slightly boring. Emily Blunt plays an FBI Agent, Kate Macer, who finds dozens of bodies hidden in the walls of a house in Arizona, along with her partner Reggie Wayne (Daniel Kaluuya). The crime investigating team come across a shed in the backyard, which turns out to be a bomb and detonates, killing 2 officers. Her boss, Dave Jennings (Victor Barber) recommends her to a CIA undercover officer, Matt Graver (Josh Brolin), who guarantees that she can get revenge the death of the 2 officers, so she volunteers to join there elite team. They then leave for El Paso in there private jet, we're Kate meets Alejandro Gillick (Benicio Del Toro) for the first time. When they get to Juarez, they extradite one of Diaz's top men, his brother Guillermo but when they try and cross the border, they sight a group of hitmen in a traffic jam, so the elite force kill them on the spot. When they get Guillermo back to base, they torture and interrogate him and he eventually tells them about a tunnel that Diaz uses to ferry drugs into the US. They then return to Arizona and question a group of Mexican migrants who give them some more information about the tunnel. Meanwhile, Reggie and Kate are fed up with being kept in the dark about everything, so Matt tells them that their goal is to cause a disruption in Diaz's drug operations so he will be called back to Mexico to meet his boss, drug lord Fausto Alarcon (Julio Cedillo). After freezing Diaz's account, Kate tries to build a case against Diaz involving his money transactions but Matt isn't interested in using that route to catch Diaz. She then tries to go to her boss with the evidence but Jennings tells her that they outrank him and if she goes against them, there could be legal repercussions. After a night drinking in a bar, Kate goes home with Reggies friend, Ted (Jon Bertha) and she realises that he has a wristband which is used to bundle Diaz's laundered money. When Ted realises that she knows who he is, she puts up a struggle and tries to shoot him but he knocks the gun away and starts to strangle her. She is then saved by Alejandro, whose was close by, watching her because she exposed herself at the bank. Matt and Alejandro then torture Ted and threaten his friends and family which leads to them getting the names of corrupt cops who are working for Diaz. The next morning, Kate and Reggie realise that they are being used by the elite force, purely to give the CIA the legal ability to operate within US borders. Reggie doesn't want to go any further with the investigation but Kate wants to see the whole thing to the end. After finally getting through the tunnel, Alejandro sneaks through the Mexican side and he kidnaps one of Diaz's mules, whose a corrupt Mexican police officer. Kate follows Alejandro and attempts to arrest him but he shoots her in her bulletproof vest and tells her to return to the US. Matt then tells Kate that Alejandro is only working with them to avenge his murdered wife and daughter. Alejandro then uses the corrupt police officer to catch Diaz and then he kills him and wounds Diaz. Diaz then drives Alejandro to his bosses estate and then he kills Diaz and fights off Alarcon's henchmen. Alarcon is calmly eating dinner with his wife and children and he tells Alejandro that what happened to his family wasn't personal. After killing his family in front of him, he looks Alarcon in the eyes and he shoots him with no remorse. The following day, Alejandro goes to Kate's house and makes her to sign a waiver, by gunpoint, stating that everything that they done was by the book. Kate then attempts to shoot him from her balcony but she ends up letting him walk away. Del Toro is definitely the best character in this movie and his calm demeanour, even though his family was brutally murdered, was great. The only problem that I found with the film is that it takes some time to get going and you don't know what really is going on until the end, so you are kept in suspense through most of the film. Emily Blunt just wants to expose everything before she actually knows what's going on but I did like Josh Brolins character, who used brutal tactics to get the job done. Anyway, I personally enjoyed the movie, mainly because of the ending and I can't wait to see how Del Toro's character will progress in the sequel. Enjoyable!Â 

Round-Up:
This movie was directed by Denis Villeneuve, 48, who brought you Prisoners in 2013, with Hugh Jackman and Jake Gyllenhaal and Enemy which also starred Jake Gyllenhaal. He's rumoured to be directing the next Blade Runner, along with Story of Your Life starring Amy Adams, Jeremy Renner and Forest Whitaker so he's obviously gained some respect, due to the success of this movie. I liked the way that he showed the different points of view in this movie, like the corrupt cop with his family and there is a sense of authenticity which made it feel real. I just hope they don't mess up the sequel, if they ever do release one!Â

Directed by Denis Villeneuve (Prisoners), Sicario is a film that once you see it, I'm not sure if you need to or want to see it again. I'm glad I saw it because the acting was superb, but I couldn't get with the plot and found myself confused and not 100% captivated by the film. Great acting is always a staple of a good film, and the 3 technical Oscar nominations are well deserved. If the plot had been a little better paced and had it pulled me into the film more, Sicario could have been a top choice for 2015. It's better than Hitman, but I'd rather run into Timothy Olyphant's character and not deal with the pure fright I'd endure meeting del Toro's Alejandro.

It's shot really well, and the characters are all really good, as well as the moral dilemmas and criticisms of our politics and law enforcement come in full gear. I wanted to like it more. Towards the end the narrative seems to move out of focus for lack of finding a more interesting way to tell the story. Still, stoked this director will take on Blade Runner 2

I like that we begin "Sicario" thinking it's going to be a gritty battle of good vs. evil, only to realize sometime during its middle half that that's, unfortunately, wishful thinking.  It is a merciless depiction of the war on drugs, so authentically dogged that we, sooner or later, come to the conclusion that we're witnessing a war that perhaps can never be won, and this cynicism is as frightening as it is brutally watchable - it is a tremendously effective film.
	"Sicario" is French director Denis Villeneuve's third American feature, following in the footsteps of critically acclaimed kidnapping drama "Prisoners" (2013) and indie horror fantasy "Enemy" (2014).  We can establish that Villeneuve is not a filmmaker comfortable with being confined to one specific genre, but clear is that he is a stunningly confident master of his craft, able to give a project of any means artistic strength that has helped in his quick rise to the top of the most remarkable modern cinematic talents.  Having only seen "Enemy," which mostly, despite having interesting moments, turned me off with its existentially based quasi-terror, "Sicario" is a head-turner and certainly one of the best directed films of 2015.
	I'm not so sure it's a masterpiece, as its focus isn't as tightly wound as we might expect and because having a firm grip on the pitfalls that could occur during its scenes of suspense aren't always crystalline.  But, nevertheless, the film is galvanizing, thought-provoking, and convincingly bleak - I especially like the way its moral ambiguities slowly reveal themselves to be unsteady after we've long decided that "Zero Dark Thirty"-esque good is where everything is headed.  Its final act is a terrifyingly visceral knockout.
	It also features career high performances from its refined cast: here, Emily Blunt redefines herself in her most challenging role to date, quixotical FBI agent Kate Macy, a specialist in kidnapping cases.  The film, harrowingly, opens with a bulleted raid of a suburban home (headed by her) that leads to the discovery of scores of corpses, all presumed to be hostages victimized by the drug trade.  The scene quickly goes awry (a bomb is accidentally denoted and kills two officers), but her expertise does not go unnoticed.  Recruitment for aid in the war on drugs soon reaches her, despite no prior experience in the category.
	With superiors (Josh Brolin, Benicio Del Toro) whose questionable ethics lead her to ponder just how far she's willing to go to ensure justice, Kate is brought into a dangerous world where surviving lets itself be known as something perhaps more vital than being spotlessly moral.  By "Sicario's" end, we aren't surprised to find her shattered, unsure of where to go next in her career.
	I suppose I could go further in depth regarding "Sicario's" plot, but as we mostly live vicariously through Kate, who spends much of the duration unsure of what's going on herself, an appreciation of the chaotic, oppressively violent interior of the film is necessary to decipher an ultimate emotional reaction.  Perhaps "Sicario" isn't so refined narratively, never really deciding if Blunt's Kate or Del Toro's mysterious Alejandro is the real main character, but what it lacks in plot central cohesion is made up for in arrant ardency, found in its direction and its acting.
	Blunt and Del Toro are particularly marvelous.  Blunt, more or less the moral center of the film, vivifies her characterization through persuasive fearfulness that sometimes causes us to forget just how courageous of an individual Kate actually is.  When "Sicario" finishes and she's no longer the person who believes that being essentially "good" is enough to make it in this world, we're left genuinely devastated.  Del Toro, as Blunt's superior whose affiliation to the law is never clearly stated, gives one of the best performances of 2015, his kept-secret personal vendetta against the drug force moving enough to cause us to question how far our sympathies can go.
	"Sicario" is never simple, and the more we let it sink under our skin, the more we become inclined to analyze the complexities of virtuosity itself.  Villeneuve is a director destined to become increasingly notable in the film industry; Blunt and Del Toro strengthen the awe that has become them.

Their's aim is to tackle the main source, instead to deal with its lower order. Something that impossible to do without international cooperation. Every raid is done in secretively, sometime if required at any cost in whatever effort to stop it. Like I said, this was an awesome movie, and good to see it after the documentary like 'Cartel Land'.

The story is kind of hard to detail it out, because it was more an action movie than the talking. How a special force unit goes after the bad guys and stops them is the main plot. But the characters were so distinctive, every main roles had their own agenda for what they are doing and that's how the narration dominated with the high standards.

The cast who played them were simply outstanding, including that starts with Emily Blunt, who is someone looks changed the attitude to play physically challenging roles after 'Edge of Tomorrow'. And then Josh Brolin and another one, an upcoming young British actor who I really don't know, but Benicio Del Toro was actually the show stealer.

His part was unexpectedly great, totally raw and aggressive. Especially the his end scene, no one could have guessed it, but that's how the way it is. No doubt any top actors would have denied to perform that, anyway well shot with minimum violence, but the intention was very clear as fighting against the dark forces to cut off the head first. One of the best movie of the year, so definitely recommended if you're interested.

There's a lot that doesn't make sense when it's presented.  You have to keep watching closely to get the fill in the pieces.  For instance (spoiler) she's attached to the FBI (or CIA) unit because they need a non-federal cop attached.  
1) That makes no sense legally that I know of.  2) Why is this some secret from her and therefore the audience?  They wouldn't put someone in danger without disclosure to them.  There are a variety of other confusing or inconsistent pieces like this.

The "got revenge" ending, isn't enough to carry a movie for me.  I live for more than revenge as the whole purpose of a movie.  I need some depth somewhere -- either characterization, or historic info, or thoughtful concepts on life and solving things, or humor, or fun.

Top notch, gripping and relentless intensity.

If you've got nails before watching Sicario you certainly won't have
after it, for this beautifully lensed and tension riddled Mexican
cartel themed thriller is a nail-biting experience of a high order that
from its explosive opening through to breathtaking night time finale
will have you very much on the edge of your seat even if you don't know
exactly what's happening or even care much for our main protagonists.

The 4th film on the trot that has quickly established French/Canadian
director Denis Villeneuve as one of the inform directors of Hollywood -
his previous films where the incredible Incendies (please anyone that
has yet to see this film do so now), Enemy and Prisoners - Sicario once
more showcases the directors visual sensibilities and skill with
creating an intensely crafted narrative and while Sicario may fall
short on emotional sensibilities it's very likely it was another part
of the reason why Villeneuve has been chosen to helm the soon to be
shot Blade Runner sequel.

The lack of emotion that runs through Sicario, from its characters
through to its cold as ice handling of life and death, is likely a long
thought about process that falls hand in hand into the way in which
even our central character of Emily Blunt's dedicated and by the book
FBI Agent Kate Macer is thrown into a world she knows far less about
than she'd ever have thought and how the essence of her mission
directives remain clouded by a murky world of politics and dastardly
deeds.

Viewers feel a sense of being overwhelmed much like Macer herself feels
but through this quick-fire and often frenetic journey we get treated
to a haunting Johann Johannsson score, some amazing scenery and
sequences shot by legendary D.O.P Roger Deakin's (who in any other year
not against The Revenant would've finally had his long overdue Oscar)
and a Benicio Del Toro performance that can count itself very unlucky
to have missed out on some more awards attention. It's a great reminder
of Del Toro's talents and the arc of his mysterious character Alejandro
is one that elevates the film whenever his on screen.

Sicario is easily one of 2015's most accomplished thrillers and an
uncompromising look at how the drama playing out daily in Mexico
through its illegal activities is steadily finding its way into the
land of America whether the nation acknowledges it or not. Cold as ice
but on fire in many departments, Sicario is sleek Hollywood movie
making and another win for director Denis Villeneuve in what's quickly
and assuredly becoming quite the career behind camera.
