Especially Benicio Del Toro, he made a comeback from playing some high-dude collector in Guardians of The Galaxy (2014). His mysterious character made the film looked more than a simple thriller. My dad, usually predicts what a character might do, but he couldn't predict him. Watch the climax of the film, you'll know what I'm talking about.

Also the cinematography was great. The technical side of the film was very complex, but yet looked realistic. The old man really knew what he was doing since the 1980's.

Besides that, I really like to hear the film's sound design and foely, it sounded so realistic. It build more of the suspense.

As for the writings, there were plot twists all over the place, but the most surprising one was on the climax. We really don't know what Benicio Del Toro's and Josh Brolin's character motivation for  3/4 of the movie. Once we knew it, OH SHIT, this is fucked up.

I bet this film would be in one of Oscar's nomination.

The Verdict:
Sicario is one of the most suspenseful film of the year, with strong cast, plot twists, and technical (cinematography and sound).
Absolutely superb. Looks incredible, feels incredible. It's a powerful and uncomfortable watch, but worth it - so worth it. Can't believe how overlooked this has been on the awards front.

Loved this. Terrific confusion displayed by Emily Blunt trying to work out what the whole agenda is, with Josh Brolin and Benecio Del Toro very good at underlining the mystery, the traffic jam scene is great and reminiscent of the central bank robbery in Heat, but the final scene is shocking indeed. Brilliant stuff and the extraordinary score has rightly been nominated.
Bleak as hell, but very thought-provoking.
Best movie of the year, amazing sound and shot selections.

I really don't like high action movies with guns and crap but... I LOVED the way they did this, it was different, engaging, not too emotional. They shot this movie in the most... incredible way. Really loved it. Applause to the director.
This movie was awesome. Brutal & vicious... but awesome.
The very violent film "Sicario" offers virtually no depth and is plainly outdone by the classic "Traffic" (also starring Del Toro) as well as the 2014 film Sabotage.
Intense and graphic story of corruption and violence in both sides of the Mexico-USA border with excellent cinematography.
Really good movie with fantastic performances

The second film in which Mexican drug cartels are represented at the forth-coming academy awards. This is a pretty good film, shot very well, hence the cinematography nom. I'm surprised Benicio Del Toro didn't get a nom because he was pretty awesome in this.
Amazingly intense, with a fantastic story.  I loved the characters that Del Toro and Brolin played.

Some nice, novel shots using camera drones.  the pace is kept alive without slowing down.  Emily Blunt seemed out of place and weak in certain scenese that it was not credible to watch her as a trained law enforcement agent.
Really entertaining movie but I thought the female lead character was a bit weak.

Taught from beginning to end.  Blunt and del Toro are tremendous.  Fascinating story in that this is what it takes to fight the drug cartel.  Who gets to decide when the rules don't count?  When are these rules only applied to this situation.

Sicario is a dark look into the US government trying to keep order in the dark drug underworld. Emily Blunt, Josh Brolin, and Benicio Del Toro give great performances in this thriller. I'll never forget the opening scene with the bodies in the wall.
and the Oscar for best cinematography goes to...

Intense the whole way through without any of the cheesy subplots or forced character developments you suffer through with other big name actors.  Just a damn good movie.  If you liked No Country For Old Men, this is a must see movie for you.

I hated the ending. But great acting..would have liked to see Emily Blunts character be a little more aggressive in her quest to do the right thing.

Sicario is stressful - very, very stressful. And the scariest thing is that this film doesn't seem too far detached from reality. Emily Blunt gives a powerful and emotional performance, and Benicio Del Toro is mesmerizing as the mysterious Alejandro. This is not a movie that I can pop in anytime and enjoy, but it is a well-crafted piece of cinema.
Horrible movie...Emily Blunt is one of the worst actresses ever....Wasted $6

The movie is slighly better than the standard Lionsgate mediocrity. However, Sicario still suffer from their usual system that builds a lot of anticipation, but short-shrifts with the payoff.  It also is plagued by an ending that invalidates the initial setup, as do most LG films.  Continuity is alien to them, unless a major studio is involved and driving the bus.  Then LG films tend to be quite well done.

Emily Blunt's character was an absolute puss in this whole story. She was the only thing slowing it down. She basically cringes in every scene she's in and fails to do anything really meaningful except in her first scene with the group making a key kill. 

But she's relegated to the sidelines for almost the entire 3rd act. It became Benecio Del Toro's rendition of Taken for about half an hour, and then BAM here come's Emily again to whine about a guy killing someone's family when she's witnessed endless amounts of horrifying bloodshed for an hour and twenty minutes. She somehow went unhardened in that entire process. She never accepted reality and its horrors, and instead of joining in the fight she just got in its way.

It's still a good film. It just could have been so much more. I don't blame Blunt by the way, she was a fine actress in the film. The writing is to be questioned when you put such heavy emphasis on a character without explaining her properly. From the get-go they obscure the reasons behind her hire, making her more of a plot device than an actual character I should care about. But still they push her forward and I DO care about her because Blunt did a great job of interpreting her internal struggle between ethics and reality. 

Yet they never cashed it in. She ends up being a character who constantly seems in too deep and incapable of handling things. It makes her appear weak and the ultimate message becomes unclear. Is the War on Drugs good? Bad? Are our politics with Mexico sound? Is this good for people or not?

Those are profound questions this film had the potential to answer, and it simply passed on them all. With regards to cinematics, it's a beautiful movie that reminded me of Full Metal Jacket and Apocalypse Now, as well as flashbacks from The Hurt Locker. It's gorgeous. But unlike those movies, it doesn't take a definitive stance on what the story really means. I walked away more confused than enlightened and I believe where this could have been art it became shallow and obtuse past the mid-way point. While there are some highlights, the plot just leaves glaring holes filled at awkward times.

Check it out, but don't wet the bed in excitement.
scary and good. Benicio del Toro is always so riveting

I want to divide this review into 5 parts: Directing, Cinematography,Writing,Score and finally Acting.
Let's star with Directing - I thought that directing was phenomenal. It seemed that all of the main actors were on the same page as far as the movie should go. And portrayed their roles perfectly. All of the actors worked together like a well made Swiss watch. Denis Villenueve masterfully managed to capture the intensity and suspense of this mesmerizing thriller. The director cemented his name as one of the best if not the best thriller masters in Hollywood today.  I would rate it 18/20
Cinematography - Was really impressive, and manages to capture the audience from the first shot of the movie and never let go of the viewer. The lightning seems bleak, but that just adds to suspense of the movie. There were a lot of impressive shots, including the very well made aerial shots of the USA - Mexican border.  I would rate it 17/20
Writing - A movie is as good as it's script. Well in this case it's marvelous. The movie delivers everything it promises and more. It manages to deliver the thrills and sense of intensity from the start. All through out the movie, viewers are encouraged to question every single character, because the line of good and bad in this movie is very thin.  20/20
Score - The composer Johann Johannson manages to do a very good job. Score is done to perfection. Every bit of sound seems to fit the frames perfectly and just helps to add the thrills.    I would rate it 18/20
Acting - A give a very big A plus for all the actors in this movie. Like i mentioned before, everyone fitter the role pretty much perfectly with good casting. All of the actors performed very well, so it is very difficult to mention some in particular. It seemed like every actor added something personal to the role, that made them very memorable. The chemistry between actors was something special, every relationship between characters was really intensifying, and mesmerizing.      I would rate it 20/20
Now for the MVP of the movie is: Jon Bernthal, who truly might have slipped under the radar. But his performance was both memorable and amazing. Even though he didn't have very much of a screen time, what he did with what he got, was really masterful. He deliver a bad cop, who does not give a bad impression and hides under a mask. His character is like a wolf, disguised himself as a sheep.
In Total i would rate this movie - 95/100. One of the best thrillers ever made, and one of the best last years movies.
Does a good job of showing some of the Govt's corruption, although I think it's much worse than what the movie showed.
I love this genre and its one of the best cinematography I have seen in a film. All the top names are fantastic however Blunts character felt a bit lost at times.

Very surprised this is getting such high reviews, I found this movie to be a real letdown despite the talented cast. Comes across as propaganda that the United States should increase resources and get tougher on the war on drugs, despite the evidence that the policy is misguided and the war unwinnable. Some of the plot elements are so outrageous and unbelievable, even in the fantasy land of a Hollywood script. Terrible film, nothing interesting or redeeming. I found it almost unwatchable, impossible to take seriously, and difficult to finish.

Something about this one bugged me enough to write a review. Maybe because it is overrated on this site and a couple others. It is not a masterpiece, it is a 3.5 star at best. It had a solid premise, twist, intense scenes, score, and decent into darkness. It also has a powerful message to send about escalation and drug enforcement policy. What went wrong? I think the film relied too heavily on shock and drama to obscure from its shortcomings. The plot moved at a snail's pace for  3/4 of the film where little was explained or happened. Besides that it has one major problem. The lead character was insufferable. She was annoying, clueless, afraid, and amateur, despite this being her profession. Her treatment was also abysmal. She was used, mislead, and bullied by her teammates; threatened into submission. There are deliberate undertones of misogyny, and promotion of violence. Expected considering the subject matter and audience, though are no less disturbing to experience. As for it's realism. Something funny to know is that the CIA, Mexican Government, and town of Juárez all called bullshit and denounced the film, even getting it ban in several places, since violent and cartel related crime statistics have been steadily dropping for years thanks to successful DEA, FBI, CIA, Mexican Army and police efforts to quell the cartels. In many respects what is portrayed in the film is still very "Hollywood".

Sicario is a violent, dark, gritty masterpiece that tells a tale of revenge and explores a common motif that sometimes, you are forced to do what's necessary to survive in a world where rules don't exist. Sicario is another dark, gritty film from director Denis Villeneuve. It takes a look at the war that US law enforcement is waging against the Mexican drug cartels, and tries to make you question if the ends justify the means. The first thing that needs to be said is that this movie deserves every Oscar nomination it received. Between the spectacular look of the movie and the sound/score, they set a tone that played brilliantly into the story. As for the story itself, I had some issues with that. In the opening scene I was totally hooked. There were surprises, great acting, and spectacular effects. However when the plot started to get rolling and suddenly we find ourselves left in the dark (along with Emily Blunt) I was only slightly intrigued but largely frustrated. I had hopes that there was some huge underlying secret that might really make the movie great with a stunning twist in the end. But when everything is revealed I wasn't satisfied because none of it was all that shocking, in fact it was kind of along the lines of what I thought was going on from the very beginning. Perhaps the issue is that they spend so much time selling you on the mystique of Benicio del Toro's character that he would almost have to be an alien from Mars in order to live up to the intrigue they created. I think the acting was good, the action was good, and (as I said) the look and sound were amazing. I just wish Sicario had a more impressive or satisfying conclusion. In the end I was still identifying with Emily Blunt, and like her I could not find satisfaction in how things were handled. To be fair, though, it's a very affecting movie that I think might work better for others, it just fell short of greatness for me.

Convoluted, confusing, and ultimately pointless. We never find out who Benicio's character is, or what motivates him to kill a (mostly) innocent cop. Basically the moral of the story is: you can't do anything about the status quo so you might as well perpetuate it. While that may be the current state of affairs in the 'war on drugs' today, it's hardly inspiring to make an entire film based on that premise. Really it all feels like a long slow build-up to nothing at all. It's ultimately anti-climactic and disappointing, and as the credits roll, one is left feeling distinctly underwhelmed. I understand how critics would enjoy such a gritty and depressing movie, but I do not understand the high audience rating. And to call it as a "thriller" is a stretch to say the least. Less than one eighth of the film could be characterized as "thrilling". That's tantamount to describing the latest "Die Hard" as a foreign film because it features 15 minutes of Russian dialogue. Highly not recommended.
Well paced, acted and executed. One of the best of 2015.

Exceedingly bleak, brooding, violent and yet unapologetic, Sicario is a mature film conceived and executed by mature filmmakers. When tensions rise on the US-Mexico border, a task force is assembled, enlisting a passionate yet naïve FBI agent (Emily Blunt) to aid in its efforts. The goals and actions of the task force represent a departure the young agent is not yet willing to make, yet feels inexplicably logical in an illogical world.

With Sicario, talented director Denis Villeneuve takes on the drug war in really an unprecedented way. Its' political overtones, realism, and cynicism is reminiscent of the great Traffic, yet without the overwrought indignation. It's a slow burn, with a methodical build up and a matter-a-fact way of examining the brutality and carnage that cartels engage in, without glossing over government complicity. Vilenueve pulls no punches, and succeeds in making a film that is both enthralling and cerebral. It has a point of view, yet the viewer has to make their own interpretations. Shades of gray abound, a laudable departure from a genre that otherwise can succumb to less nuanced stories.

The film's ensemble cast is second to none, featuring marvelous performances from all involved, including Emily Blunt, Josh Brolin, and Benicio Del Toro. Toro, for his part, showed a depth I haven't before seen from him. The chemistry between the cast is palpable and the direction brings the best out of the actors, whose complex characterizations all bring a much needed wrinkle to a the story.

Toward the end, one would wish for more exploration of the film's major revelation, feeling a bit unsatisfying in the last act. Yet it still manages to bring something to the table that past genre pieces have not, a very real sense of hopelessness that, if never confronted, will never be defeated.

Sicario (2015) is a brutal, intense film with an incredible score, cinematography, directing, and cast. I can't believe this film is not nominated for an Oscar for Best Picture this year. I can't believe Emily Blunt is not nominated for an Oscar for Best Actress this year. I can't believe Benicio Del Toro is not nominated for an Oscar for Best Supporting Actor this year. I can't believe Denis Villeneuve is not nominated for an Oscar for Best Director this year. The Academy has really missed the boat by giving this film only three nominations (sound editing, score, cinematography). The tension builds and builds from the very start, Sicario is the most intense film since Zero Dark Thirty. Mark's Grade: A

I don't understand why this film didn't receive more Oscar attention, because this thriller showcasing some of the best filmmaking, storytelling and acting in a long time shows how to tell a story very, very well. Sicario is an intense, thrilling watch, the story slowly builds up the whole time until its final mind blowing release and you never know what to expect next. It's shocking, it doesn't have many plot twists but there are a few moments after which i stared at the screen with my mouth open totally not expecting what has happened. 

The directing and the cinematography are huge contributors to the movie's atmosphere, the cinematography is probably my favorite part about it. The colors, wide shots, i can't describe how pleasing was it to watch it. 

My main complaint about the movie is Blunt's character. It was a constant moral battle for me to watch her. Sometimes i loved her, sometimes her strong moral compass pissed me off and i wished she understood what's happening, and then i loved her again for being so opinionated. That's the beauty of it, seeing such complex characters on screen, never knowing whether to love them or be annoyed. The acting both on Blunt's and of course on del Toro's parts is amazing.

The most important part though: this movie is scary. Seeing how much innocent people are affected by drug cartels running their towns and at the same time how used they are to it. Gun shots, missing people, dead family members are not treated as a tragedy anymore, it's a part of their daily life. And to think people still live like this in the world. It's terrifying.

Review: Sicario
Well, it's here. Sicario was one of my most anticipated movies of the year, right up there with Spectre and Star Wars: The Force Awakens. Now that I've seen it, I wouldn't dare call Sicario a disappointment, but I wouldn't label it as my favorite of the year. After Denis Villeneuve's underseen gem Prisoners back in 2013, I eagerly awaited his next major film (he made the limited-release film, Enemy, between then and now-I've yet to see it). The two films share the similarities of being intense, suspenseful and bleak, but where Prisoners featured limited venues and focused more on characters' emotions, Sicario is a globe-trotting film (between the US and Canada anyway) that focuses on characters' actions.
Emily Blunt stars as Kate Macer, a young cop who's work in leading teams that hunt down kidnappers and victims hasn't gone unnoticed by the higher-ups. She has a loyal partner in Reggie (Daniel Kaluuya who gets the task of playing possibly the only likeable male character in the movie, and he does a great job). After an investigation goes wrong and two cops from her team end up killed, Kate is eager to find the men responsible. She is afforded this opportunity when a mysterious task force of mixed agencies asks her to join them in taking on a Mexican drug cartel they tell her is linked to the kidnappings she is investigating. She doesn't hesitate to volunteer, leaving Reggie behind at first, but when she realizes she can't trust the strange new men she is working with, she insists on her partner's presence. She has every reason not to trust them. Matt Graver (Josh Brolin) won't reveal what agency he works for. And he's a bit on the quirky side-he wears flip-flops. And his partner Alejandro (Benicio Del Toro) is even more mysterious-he doesn't talk much and it feels unlikely to both Kate and the audience that he works for any reputable agency. It doesn't take long observing their unusual and violent tactics for the normally by-the-book Kate to wonder what she's gotten herself into. The team conjures up a dangerous plan to follow a Cartel higher-up to the leader of the whole thing so they can both be taken down, hopefully putting a big dent in the criminal activities. There is also a side story involving a crooked cop with a heart played by Maximiliano Hernandez. This story feels very tacked-on throughout the movie and it isn't until the very last scene that you finally realize the point to it-but it still feels somewhat unnecessary.
Every actor in Sicario brings their A-game and does the best they can with what they've been given to work with. That's not to be overly mean to the script as it is an interesting story, but at times the dialogue seems very generic and some very important characters are often left with little to do. Blunt plays Kate much more feminine than her much tougher roles in Looper and Edge of Tomorrow would have you predicting, but she makes the character feel authentic and she carries the film well-that is until the filmmakers decide to lose her for some time to focus on Alejandro's agendas. This isn't easy on the audience because we're asked to accept him as a protagonist even though he is very violent and unlikeable. Del Toro plays the part well and practically owns the final act of the movie. It is clear Alejandro suffered some horrible tragedy in life-and I wish they would've included a flashback or two to some happier times for him so that we might find it easier to sympathise with him and understand his actions. Other good actors show up for small parts including Victor Garber as Kate's boss, Jon Bernthal as a character I won't reveal, and Jeffrey Donovan as a member of Matt's special task force.
Behind the camera, master-cinematographer Roger Deakins works hard to make Sicario a unique visual experience. He's one of the best in the business (12 Academy Award nominations and still no win-Come on Oscar!) and proves himself once again here. Some of the natural skylines he captures are gorgeous and there is an amazing sequence where everything is seen through infrared and night-vision goggles-fans of the compound raid scene in Zero Dark Thirty will love this sequence. Editor Joe Walker makes sure the film doesn't drag too much. When things start to feel a bit slow, watch out-because something intense is about to happen. The score by Johann Johannsson is one of my favorites this year. Director Denis Villeneuve and writer Taylor Sheridan have made a film smart enough to please critics but mainstream enough to entertain audiences.
Sicario is a film about moral flexibility. We, the audience, are forced to recognize that sometimes good people do evil things because they they believe it is for the greater good and sometime bad people do bad things to protect those closest to them. Other than some lazy dialogue here or there, Sicario's weakest attribute may be what feels like a lack of purpose. While it does open audiences' eyes to the war zone certain parts of Mexico have become do to these cartels, I couldn't help but feel like "That was good, but what was the point?" when the credits rolled. Still Sicario Is an intense thriller that deserves to be seen. 8/10?

During an FBI SWAT raid of suspected kidnappers in Chandler, Arizona, idealistic agent Kate Macer (Emily Blunt), her partner Reggie Wayne (Daniel Kaluuya), and their team discover dozens of corpses hidden within the walls of the house. While the team investigates the crime scene, an improvised explosive device in the backyard shed explodes, killing two officers. Afterwards, Kate's boss, Dave Jennings (Victor Garber), recommends her to Matt Graver (Josh Brolin), a CIA Special Activities Division undercover officer and Department of Defense adviser leading a team of Delta Force operators searching for the men responsible, including cartel hitman Manuel Díaz. Kate volunteers to join the team. On the plane to El Paso, Texas, Kate meets Matt's partner, Alejandro Gillick (Benicio del Toro), and learns that they are going to Juárez, Mexico, where they will extradite one of Diaz's top men, his brother Guillermo...

Denis Villeneuve is back with yet another fantastic film after "Prisoners" and "Enemy" and his "Sicario" is a tour-de-force thriller that pushes the boundary of where justice and morality are no longer valid. We are driven straight into the depths of criminality and it´s not always clear who is the good guys and who is the bad guys. It all comes down to reaching results and not how you reach them. Blunt, Brolin and del Toro are simply magnificent and in the hands of Villeneuve and cinematographer Roger Deakins we are served an amazing dynamic piece of film that keeps your blood rushing for 121 minutes. The tension is high throughout the film even in more slowpaced scenes and as in "Enemy" Villeneuve works with industrial muffled weird sounds in the background that creates a dark and disturbing vibe that fits the film. Villeneuve shows a situation that is beyond salvation, while showing at the same time that life nevertheless continues no matter what happens in the shady parts of the world. The action is truly believable and you end up together with Blunt and Co while they are trying to understand the events that occur. The role of the observing Macer is by far one of Emily Blunt´s best performances to date. I love as well that Villeneuve isn´t afraid of keeping a distance to his actors and the dialogue like in one scene between Macer and Graver where the camera is several feet away. Great scene. Dan Jolin from Empire gave the film 5 stars, calling it "a beautifully murky, hard-edged thriller. Quite simply, one of the best films of the year." And I can´t agree more. Trivia: While Benicio Del Toro's character is frequently silent in the movie, he initially had more lines. "In the original script, the character explained his background several times to Kate," Del Toro says. "And that gave me information about who this guy was, but it felt a little stiff to have someone you just met 15 minutes ago suddenly telling you what happened to him and who he is." Working with director Denis Villeneuve, Del Toro began cutting some of his dialogue to preserve the mystery of who his character is; Villeneuve estimates they cut 90 percent of what Del Toro was originally intended to say by screenwriter Taylor Sheridan. Like Del Toro, Villeneuve saw power in stripping the character down to a brooding silence, stating that dialogue belongs to plays and "movies are about movement, character, and presence, and Benicio had all that."

I don't usually leave RT reviews, but I feel I need to with this one. I feel really disappointed with it, and that it's completely overrated. 

It opens really exciting, and looks like it's going to be a brilliant movie. I LOOKS great, it FEELS great, but the story really is very poor... if you've not seen it, stop reading now.

Spoilers ahead: You meet Emily blunt's character, then you're left hanging for around 40 minutes to know why she is even in the movie, and once you do find out, she has little to nothing to do with the plot. The plot is so simple, yet they stretch it out, and then the movie ends, with one final look at her, and she does nothing. Oh well...

Simply put this film is a case of actions speak louder than words. Everyone here is excellent and in top form, from the actors, who do so much with the little dialog available (Benicio del Toro uses facial expressions like a master painter wields a paint brush, Emily Blunt is haunting and powerful), the directing, the score, the cinematography, everything comes together here to give a gritty reality to a dangerous part of our world. The action is exciting, but reserved, and absolutely thrilling. I understand why it's been placed on so many top 10 lists. I think it's biggest flaw is pacing. There were enough lulls in the narrative that I found myself getting distracted. That's probably more of a critique on myself than anything, but since I'm reviewing what I thought, I think 4 stars out of 5 is about right.

Sicario is a thought-provoking film which examines the dark realities of the US-Mexico border and the on going drug wars in Juarez Mexico. Juarez which was once known as the murder capital of the world makes for a grim setting where US CIA operatives launch a secret dirty war against a Mexican drug lord and his cartel. The film is well crafted and at times, feels so real that it creates a certain sense of paranoia. It's without a doubt an important contribution to cinema but it's harsh realities may leave one feeling depressed long after the movie is over.

An excellent movie that obviously benefits from some fantastic performances from Benicio Del Toro, realistically, this might be one of his best and Emily Blunt.  Though, honestly, I will say that this is the type of movie that doesn't really reveal all its cards until the last act.  That makes watching the film, not necessarily difficult, require a little more patience from some of those in the audience.  This approach, however, I think really adds to the movie, because you're just as much in the dark Emily Blunt's character is.  You learn things as she learns them and not a moment before.  The character work in the film is top-notch as Kate, Blunt's character, is doing her damnedest to try to do things by the book as everyone around her goes about doing things the way they want to and the way that would get the desired result, which is to bring Alarcon down.  Kate, and Alejandro points this out in the ending of the film, is trying to traverse a world of wolves without the necessary skill set to do so.  Not to say that she is a sheep among the wolves, but she is far too idealistic for the type of tasks that the people she's working with are doing.  In fact, realistically speaking, Kate is essentially useless to the task these agents are trying to accomplish.  I don't mean ineffectual, like Kurt Russell's character in Big Trouble in Little China, I just mean that her contributions, as sound and as smart as they may be, will never be considered by the team, because she is there simply so they can carry out their operation, nothing more.  And I think that's one of the things this film does so well.  It gives you this character, that's supposed to be the moral compass of the film, the only person who, seemingly, wants to do things the way they should be done and she, even with all her efforts, is unable to change the way things were done.  It wasn't a lack of trying, it was willful ignorance from those who are higher up above her.  She, to them, is just a small pawn in a clearly larger game.  So I thought that was a a really interesting choice to take the character and one that, again, adds to the movie tremendously.  As mentioned, the acting is pretty fantastic.  Benicio Del Toro is quietly menacing in this film.  He doesn't have to show a lot of emotion or communicate a lot, but you know that this man has seem some shit and would probably kill his own mother if he felt that she was getting in the way of his progress.  It's also interesting seeing his character arc and witnessing how he ends up in the movie and what really was haunting this man for all this time.  As mentioned, Emily Blunt is also excellent as well, and her character, from a narrative standpoint, is probably the most interesting in the film as she slowly realizes what she actually adds to this mission.  So, yes, this is an excellent film, but one that's just not gonna show all its cards right off the bat.  That makes it more rewarding to watch as a viewer.  I'd highly recommend this, might be one of my favorites of last year.
I expected more action from this movie

Seeping with existential dread, you cannot help but grip the sides of your seat as the story unfolds. I feel like there are times where first time screenwriter Taylor Sheridan falters, such as the scene about an hour in where we first get to engage with the character of Kate Macy as she walks into a bar. After watching the film for an hour and having it make no attempts to get me to connect to this character, rather simply using her as a vessel for the audience (which I'm fine with) when she finally does walk into a bar and show her human side it completely jarred with what I was expecting to happen. Nevertheless, this sequence is used to propel the plot forwards at the same time and so this complaint quickly disappeared as I was watching. What the film gives us is a timely message about large, faceless branches of government doing what they want and answering to nobody, told through the eyes of a few key characters that it switches between at certain points. Typically beautiful visuals from Deakins, characters are created through the performances (del Toro being very good at this) rather than expository dialogue, haunting score, and a screenplay that accomplishes what it wants with very little dead weight.

Sicario is a bit two-dimensional in its effort to pull this "We're just as bad as the bad guys" motif out of its hat. The two-dimensionality trickles down to the characters who mostly just feel like cliches, which is a shame, and the remarkable cast does the best they can which, coupled with the outstanding cinematography and Denis Villeneuve's deft hand make it a compelling film. It mostly plays like a lesser Hurt Locker/Zero Dark Thirty and a less shaky Paul Greengrass film, and Villeneuve knows when and how to perfectly ratchet up the suspense on the film's explosions of violence. Benecio Del Toro has shades of Javier Bardem's character in No Country for Old Men but is somehow more terrifying, even given his hokey, flimsy backstory that feels like it never evolved after the script's first draft. The script is the main issue here. The subject matter is fascinating, and I just can't help feeling that this could have been an outstanding film were the characters given the requisite amount of depth to make you care what happens to them and the script stripped of the action/revenge/vigilante tropes that cheapens the film.
When will I learn to trust my gut and not the hype?

I had high hopes for this film which is winning awards and getting some
Oscar buzz. The cast is amazing and the storyline is very interesting.
However, there are some very gross flaws in the direction and
characters in the film that caused me to give it a 7 (maybe even a 6)
out of 10. The handful of great moments of intensity make it worth a 7,
but this is not a best picture nominee. Without giving away any
spoilers, I can say the following:
THE BAD:
 * Emily Blunt character does (or fails to do) what you expect she would. She fails to ask questions or show some basic skills you would expect for someone in her position.
* She is not believable in her professional or personal behavior. We
don't really get her. Yes, she's conflicted, but there are 4-5 times
where it makes no sense. 
* The story gets confusing and convoluted. Who are they going after and how and why and how does it all work out.
Beyond implausible, it's like they edited 50% of the film away and left
us with some gaping holes. 
* Governmental agencies are jumbled and confusing to an absurd level. 
* A few action scenes are absurd. 
* Random locations with random people where you do not know who they are nor why they are there.

What I love about feature films in theaters is the level of realism,
acting and storytelling is generally FAR superior to any TV show or
movie. In this case, the director handles the character development and
action scenes more like a TV movie. The cave scene being the most
absurd and the main character (Emily Blunt) feeling like a poorly
written TV character. 

Benicio and Josh Brolin have their moments of greatness, but their
characters are too gruff to care much about them. There is
another storyline about a Mexican police officer that is also poorly
developed. 

THE GOOD: You will feel like you understand the complexity of the
Mexico-US drug crisis. For those who feel doing illegal drugs does not
harm anyone, this movie will give you a clear picture of the dangers to
society and the corruption that exists along the border. Clearly, we
have major issues that must be addressed.

Great action thriller. Surprisingly nuanced with different strong willed characters at odds, but no one side presented as definitively correct. Emily Blunt's character could have been unlikable, or worse someone the audience is required to side with, instead she ends up as something like the Starks in Game of Thrones. Someone who's too forthright and honest to fully comprehend a world without rules. I love how even some of the smaller bad guys are not even shown as conflicted and human instead of monstrous. But what I like best of all is the presentation of a wider conflict as many of the characters and groups peripheral to the main characters have lives and wits of their own and do not exist solely for the main characters to show up. It reminds me of Heat in a great many ways, and is one of the only movies I could call a worthy successor to that (which is my favorite crime film).

I am honestly struggling to see why this film is quite so critically acclaimed? It is painfully predictable at the best of times, seriously, the underlying 'twist' was about as transparent as transparent can be. Emily Blunt also appears to be in my opinion a completely superfluous character. Considering she is supposedly the lead role in the film. It is really quite difficult to see the point in her actually being present most of the time as all she seems to do is cry, a lot. From what i can work out she is only there to constantly remind us that what is going on is most defiantly bad. Seriously. And as for thrilling, it's a joke. I can honestly say there wasn't a single moment I was even close to the edge of my seat, quite the opposite in fact, at one point struggled to actually stay conscious. This may be due to the poor character development throughout the entire film all of whom have the most minimal backstories I have come across in recent memory. Meaning I felt literally nothing for them throughout and frankly could not give a toss what happened to them or not. The only character I felt any sort of connection with was the father, who, of course, predictably died.  I would say this is a spoiler but the entire movie is so transparent I don't feel this would be justified.

The only saving grace is the excellent work done from the films camera crew which helps, as at least it gives stunning scenery shots to distract from the rest of the content.

I'd say this movie is more style over substance, but damn if that style isn't amazing. Denis Villeneuve and Roger Deakins killed the look of this movie. I was a huge fan of Prisoners and looked forward to another great slow burn from this duo. It did not disappoint with its grittiness and realistic take on the War on Drugs. The shots of Juarez, the open skies and other scenery were breathtaking.  The tension was built up excellently and there were many suspenseful moments, particularly that traffic scene. The action was handled really well in between the slower parts of the movie. The acting was all around great, but the character development was lacking. Benicio Del Toro easily stole this movie and was the most interesting character by far. Emily Blunt did a good job but I wasn't a fan of her character. She didn't really develop much and was kind of bland. Josh Brolin did a great job of playing a confident, gum-chewing asshole. This is where this movie fell pretty short of Prisoners for me. I was so invested in multiple characters in that movie and in its story. The story in this film is rather passable. Not bad, but nothing special or that memorable. It was a good look at the debatably immoral, but necessary means needed to fight the War on Drugs and the impact it has on the inhabitants in Mexico. The last scene of the movie really stood out to me and made me feel such sadness for the Mexicans living among such violence. This movie has its powerful moments here and there, but the story and characters could have been a lot stronger. Still worth a watch though, because it looks absolutely incredible.

In the lawless border area stretching between the U.S. and Mexico, an idealistic FBI agent [Emily Blunt] is enlisted by an elite government task force official [Josh Brolin] to aid in the escalating war against drugs. It is not very often you get a false film about soldiers that feels so real. "Sicario" is one of those films. The base story is a team of soldiers hunting down the drug cartel. There are more complexities that come from the lawyers and head hunters, but that is the least interesting portion of the story in my opinion. We follow Emily Blunt's character who is not used to this kind of field work, but the team she works for interested me much more. "Sicario" benefits from a very solid script, a tension-filled story, and terrific performances. I do think this film is slightly overrated, but it's concept is worth the price of admission alone. In the end, I really enjoyed watching this film. I did not buy into everything that happened, but in the end, it became one of the more interesting films of 2015.

For the last few months I have seen and heard a lot of hype surrounding this movie so when I saw this movie I was very excited to see it. After seeing the film it didn't disappoint. The film was gritty, it was dirty and it was tense.
Firstly the movie is visually stunning, the cinematography is exceptional and Denis Villeneuve showcases his directorial talents  once again after Prisoners and Enemy is showing he can consistently created well directed and captivating movies.
The performances in the movie are also magnificent Emily Blunt delivers another terrific performance and is fast becoming the best actress within the action genre after her tremendous performance in Edge of Tomorrow. Her character is the person that we see the movie trough and is probably the only morally stable person in the whole film, and this gives her a feeling of vulnerability because although she can physically handle her self, unlike the other law enforcement officers she is too idealistic and doesn't always have what it takes to get the job done. But definitely the best performance and most intriguing character in the movie was Benicio Del Toro who gives a fabulous performance as Alejandro, he is a mysterious character who's motives are unclear until the end and you never really know who's side he is on. 
The only minor fault with this movie is that its story and at times very little interesting is happening. Without the tremendous performances and direction the film could have fallen flat on its face but they elevate it from just being another standard drug bust movie to one of the best films of 2015.

Pretty decent thriller.

Seeping with existential dread, you cannot help but grip the sides of your seat as the story unfolds. I feel like there are times where first time screenwriter Taylor Sheridan falters, such as the scene about an hour in where we first get to engage with the character of Kate Macy as she walks into a bar. After watching the film for an hour and having it make no attempts to get me to connect to this character, rather simply using her as a vessel for the audience (which I'm fine with) when she finally does walk into a bar and show her human side it completely jarred with what I was expecting to happen. Nevertheless, this sequence is used to propel the plot forwards at the same time and so this complaint quickly disappeared as I was watching. What the film gives us is a timely message about large, faceless branches of government doing what they want and answering to nobody, told through the eyes of a few key characters that it switches between at certain points. Typically beautiful visuals from Deakins, characters are created through the performances (del Toro being very good at this) rather than expository dialogue, haunting score, and a screenplay that accomplishes what it wants with very little dead weight.

Some clear plot holes:
1) What would Alejandro have done had the cop car not been there?
2) Why did they need to care about the tunnel at all? They already had a drone on the Mercedes, so why not follow it all the way to the drug lords home?
3) The drug lord wasn't hiding. He was out in the open, in a huge mansion. This would make him pretty easy to find in the real world!
4) Why did they have to go in and out via Chevys? Why not fly in and out of Juarez with Guillermo?

"Sicario" only proves that Denis Villeneuve is one of the greatest upcoming directors! "Sicario" tells a generic story about an FBI investigation on a drug cartel, that is elevated through Villeneuve's fantastic direction and Roger Deakins' gorgeous cinematography, both Oscar-worthy in this film. The entire cast gives great performances, Benicio Del Toro gives his best performance in years and Emily Blunt gives what is possibly her best performance. Josh Brolin is also very good as this charismatic police agent. This film shows its story in a very realistic and gritty way, making for some very strong scenes. "Sicario" is one of the most powerful and one of the best-looking films of 2015!

The best thing Sicario sadly, is also the worst thing about Sicario. All the potential exists for a film that could easily be Zero Dark Thirty's south of the border twin. With the comparison to Zero Dark Thirty also comes the disappointment. Jessica Chastain's character was tough, resilient and killer at heart. Emily Blunt's character is described perfectly and entirely ironically by Benecio Del Toro when he tells her that she will not survive because she is not a wolf in a land of wolves. Ironically again, her acting only shines when she is called upon to play scared little girl, her terror matched only by the petulance of her character. Not only does her fragility underscore the strength of female characters but some of the scenes like in the tunnel, where a supposedly hardened FBI door kicker flinches at gunfire, are absolutely ridiculous. This film was so close to being great it's painful.

'Sicario' is an Action Thriller / Crime Drama that follows an FBI agent who gets thrown into a war against the drug cartels operating along the border of the US and Mexico. Apart from the stellar cast leading the film, i was most excited to see this film because of it being directed by Denis Villenueve. For those of you who don't know, he directed 2013's 'Prisoners' and 2014's 'Enemy', both are incredibly fantastic films that were directed to near perfection and you should definitely check out. This was still a fantastically directed film by Villenueve, but compared to those films i just mentioned, this one has many other flaws that didn't make it quite as intense as i hoped it would be from seeing the trailers. If you are looking for a fast paced, high octane action thriller, this is not it. Much like his previous films, this is a very character driven story where the film at times is carried on the backs of the amazing performances by Emily Blunt and Benicio Del Toro. Despite these praises, there are elements of the film that i didn't enjoy and harmed my overall experience with the film. 

The film started off very promising, it showed off some some of the thriller elements whilst also introducing our characters and the main overall plot of the film which was pretty meh up until the last third of the film. I was initially intrigued by what was going on and wanted to find out more about what is really going on behind the scenes, especially with Del Toro's character. But for almost the entire second act of the film, i found myself checking my phone a few times because it dragged on and on and didn't look to be ending any time soon. It had some short moments that were quite interesting in terms of character development and getting me a little more interested in the plot. But overall, the second act wasn't all that compelling to watch like the rest of the film was. I feel like they tried to do a lot to set up the finale, and just the way it was structured became an issue for me. A lot of scenes didn't quite make sense and took me out of it a bit. It all ran at a fairly slow pace which i was expecting but there were no dramatic or intense tones to get me engaged with what was going on, apart from one or two moments. A lot of this middle section relied purely on the performances of Blunt, Brolin, and Del Toro, and even though they were fantastic it wasn't enough to make me enjoy this section. It's hard to explain, but just a lot of the writing in this section looks and sounds good on paper, but the execution wasn't great. 

That being said, the last 30 minutes of this movie....... SPECTACULAR. Not going to give anything away but shit hits the fan from a storytelling standpoint, a character standpoint and an action thriller standpoint and this really saved the film for me. All of the little bits and pieces that were set up throughout the film come full circle and you realise a lot of things that maybe didn't make sense earlier make total sense now, such as 'why is the film even called Sicario?....... **You know what, stuff this, i'm gonna revoke some of the things i have mentioned so far MID REVIEW but not edit it out, because thinking about the end, and then thinking about what happened earlier is making me realise that this film was a lot smarter and well crafted than i thought it was 5 minutes ago. I obviously can't talk about any of the things i am thinking about, but this is probably going to make me watch it again like i did with 'Prisoners' and 'Enemy', and i reckon i might enjoy it more the second time, only time will tell. 

But as i mentioned before, the performances of Emily Blunt, Josh Brolin and Benicio Del Toro were all absolutely fantastic. I am not necessarily surprised because they are all incredible actors but in this film when they came together no-one took anything away from the others' performances. One did stand out well above the others but it didn't make me love the other performances less, if anything each performance added to the others. There is also quite a bit of talent in the supporting roles but due to the scope of these three large actors always commanding the screen they will most likely go largely unnoticed. 

In the end, Sicario is a film that definitely not everyone will appreciate. It is more than an action thriller and incorporates great amounts of drama, and plenty of intense moments. The second act of the film whilst watching it did really hurt my enjoyment of the film in the moment, but as i mentioned, it didn't bother me nearly as much and i actually now praise some of the decisions they made. If you like Villenueve's previous films this one is not quite up to par but you can still see a lot of his signature all over this film and that is what i enjoyed about it. - 7.2

Scario was a film I had high expectations for and did it meet them? Sadly not completely. Starring Emily Blunt, Bencicio Del Toro, and Josh Brolin, the movie sends off Kate, an FBI agent, to solve who's behind this bombing attack revolving around drug cartels that occurred in Pheonix. They travel to Juarez, Mexico to try to figure out who's behind these drug cartels. I liked a lot of things about Sicario, but I also have many issues. The action scenes are great. So smooth and efficient. Every scene was tense and suspenseful and made the movie better to watch. But there weren't many of them. When the action was going on, the movie was more intense and exciting. But when the not so interesting dialogue was on screen, I wanted more action and tense scenes. It just takes you away from the film. On a performance standpoint, I felt Blunt was decent but it was overshadowed by Del Toro. He really is Oscar deserving in this film. He made his character more dirty, cruel, and electrified the movie. One of the highlights in Sicario was how beautifully shot it was. The cinematography in the film is magnificent with stellar camera work that is eye candy. Definitely an Oscar contender. My biggest flaw in Sicario is the way the story was told. There were many scenes in which characters on screen were explaining the next plot point but it just wasn't clear enough. It just  took awhile for certain points to come across and become understood. The pace was just too uneven. But overall Sicario is a decent film. I think if the story wasn't so tangled and things were better explained with more it could've made the movie a lot better. Nonetheless Sicario still gives entertaining enough action scenes along side excellent cinematography and Del Toros performance to enjoy.

"Sicario" is a realistic interpretation of the drug trade in Mexico as seen through the eyes of a slightly ignorant FBI operative.  The film did not arrive with the same pomp as "The Martian" (which opened the same weekend), but it left an equally large impression on the critics.  It is dark, gritty, and the only thing more disturbing than the imagery of cadavers hanging in the streets is the idea that the residents of Juarez have accepted this atmosphere as a part of daily life.  The story seems a bit overdramatic but a little research shows this portrayal to be chillingly accurate.  Moreover, the main reason that Juarez has descended from its rank as the most violent city in the world is because one drug cartel has defeated its rivals.  One would hope that the police and military had brought order to the area, but that is simply not the case.  Director Denis Villeneuve has made a bold statement about the government corruption and drug violence that rule this area.  Most of the critical praise surrounding "Sicario" has involved the acting.  Emily Blunt and Benicio del Toro turn in impressive performances through subtle but powerful moments.  I could see either of them receiving an Oscar nomination but neither performance is good enough to win.  Josh Brolin also gives the high-caliber performance that we expect from him.  I do feel that the film moves a bit too slow, especially after a riveting opening sequence, but the pace gives you a chance to reflect on the unfortunate circumstance of the area.  The film focuses on situational development more than character development so that, in the end, you feel a greater attachment to the story than the characters within.  "Sicario" accomplishes its goal of bringing awareness to the drug violence in Mexico through strong acting performances and a story that is so unbelievable that you have to believe it.

It's taken a few films, but Denis Villeneuve has finally made the film we knew was in him. This slow-burn thriller recalls all the very best hallmarks of Steven Soderbergh classic Traffic, but intensifies and contemporizes this unstoppable war with frightening reality.
You'll see it in the fluidic cinematography; the insane prisoner transfer through the streets of Tijuana is one of the year's finest scenes. Johan Johannson's ominous score adds to the continual overhanging sense of pointlessness of this war. 
But it's the trio of performances that really give Sicario its integrity. Brolin and Del Toro are both excellent, displaying the varying elusive and ambiguous qualities of their respective characters with great depth. But its Blunt's in-over-her-head FBI recruit who is the heart and soul of this film; its the two qualities completely redundant and wasted in the cyclical, cynical hopelessness this war weighs down on those with any humanity.
So, not an uplifting film by any stretch, but a tensely accurate thriller that reminds us all that some wars are unwinnable.

A powerful piece of work from director Denis Villeneuve.  More than that, it's nearly a masterpiece of sustained and unbearable tension, the sort of movie that gets the audience to feel that something truly awful could erupt at any moment.  It's a grim and unflinching film, one that is unafraid to make the audience witness some very intense and unpleasant realities about confronting the drug cartels along the border.  As the lead, Emily Blunt is incredible, delivering a performance full of depth that completely sells this by-the-book character's realization of the gravity of the situation she finds herself in; this is Blunt's finest hour, and it is one of the standout performances of the year.  She's equally matched by Benicio Del Toro's subtle and enigmatic turn; it's not a showy role, in the traditional sense, because Del Toro plays everything incredibly close to the vest, and he makes what could have been a one-note character into the page into a dynamic and magnetic presence.  Roger Deakins' cinematography is fairly stripped down, in contrast to his usually painterly style, but his photography here matches the harshness of the subject matter perfectly (and still finds a way to include some legitimately beautiful compositions, to be sure).  If one wanted to nitpick, the plot specifics are - at times - a bit murky, but this appears to be by design.  With this, PRISONERS, and ENEMY, Villeneuve has firmly established himself as one of the best thriller directors working today, and while it might be too downbeat for some to stomach, SICARIO is an engrossing and frightening movie, and an experience that won't be easy to shake.

Denis Villeneuve may just be the most exciting and original film maker working in Hollywood currently, he recent psyche crushing thrillers have been a marvel to behold, if not ever so slightly flawed in the smallest of places. Sicario is his latest release before bringing the Blade Runner sequel to the big screen, and although many hardcore fans wait with bated breath, Sicario can act as a solid piece of entertainment to give them some confidence. Going bolder than ever before, Sicario follows the growing turmoil between the border of USA and Mexico, with cartel's massacring all walks of life for money, boredom or drugs. Presented with an opening to find the man in charge of such travesty, a covert government task force enlist the help of a by the books FBI agent, which she is all too happy to comply with, until she uncovers the corrupt and game changing mentality such a force need in order to succeed. From the moment Roger Deakins glorious cinematography lights up the screen and the pounding score breaks in, you instantly know your in for something thrilling and disgusting and Sicario doesnt let you down. The film continually throws you off guard by playing up a typical genre movie, only to snatch your expectations from underneath you and force you to endure a different breed of film. The performances in this film are stunning, Emily Blunt is beyond wonderful as Kate, our protagonist, Josh Brolin does what he does and to great effect, Benecio Del Toro almost steals the show and Jon Berenthal shows up to be an asshole for a brief amount of time. Sicario deals with some horrendous themes and subject matter, so having the cast downplay their performances really allows the grit of the piece to come through, especially when we question the force's tactics only to have them explain what needs to be done to win this war. It's harrowing and it manages to cause a range of emotions from disgust to anger, paranoia to fear and this is what sets Sicario apart from its competition, the film will have you on a razor blade throughout its 2 hour run time, managing to craft some of the most intense sequences you can imagine from the most unlikely of places, without spoiling anything, a traffic jam at the Mexican border will have you reaching for the valium. Its a wonderfully shot and excellently conceptualized thriller which plays the long game, rather than place all its eggs in one basket. Sicario's weakness is sadly its rock solid body armour, the film is so bleak and dank, so full of double crossing and back stabbing, its pretty hard to fully connect with. There are points during Sicario you will either feel lost or have an odd sense of deflation, quite possibly from being on edge constantly, and although if it were intentional this feeling would be acceptable, it happens all too often and for no good reason. Luckily Villeneauve bookends these moments with moments so shocking and pungent it almost makes up for it, almost. Sicario isnt perfect, but its stunning, gripping and darker than oil, an intense ride that will alienate some but further cements a director who may just be about to move up to another level entirely.

I can confidently say that 'Sicario' is one of the best movies of 2015. This movie exposes the bitter reality we desperately tried to hide, and by doing so, it makes us question about the fundamental values we have taken granted, so far.

  The most remarkable and charming point of 'Sicario' is it's complicated characters. There are neither perfect heroes nor utter villains in the movie. Each character has their own strengths and weaknesses, and we, the audiences have much trouble in separating the sheep from the goats. 

 There are several critical issues that the movie requires the audiences to think about. The first one is about the law and the justice. Matt is very competent CIA agent, at least in the war against the drug. He frequently breaks the law, and sometimes, even makes us to question whether his acts are justifiable, but ironically these are the main constituents of his ability. In some sense, he is the most dangerous character in this movie. As the movie progresses, we are somewhat persuaded by him, and begin to think that maybe sometimes, to root out the great evil like the drug, it is allowable to cross a line. Like 'for the greater good' thing. However, is it? Who is entitled to allow such violence of law and injustice? 
 Kate is the complete opposite of Matt. She is faithful, righteous, and principled FBI agent. She is qualified for the typical protagonist, and we can say she was a good police officer in Phoenix where the rule of law still existed. However, ironically, in this fierce war against the drug, she is helpless and even incompetent because of her faith and morality. I wonder whether she is a 'good' police to deal with the drug problem, because she could not solve anything. This irony itself is what the movie requires us to think about the law. Law is the basic rule which we, by ourselves, made to live on the straight. However, if the law is helpless and incompetent to eradicate the evil and corruption of people, then, where is the place for the law? What is the meaning of the law? 
 Alejandro is the most complicated character who hides so many secrets. He helps Kate in critical moments. On the other hand, he ruthlessly killed the innocent woman and children for his personal revenge. He was originally a prosecutor, which means that he knows the law, and understands the very meaning of justice and morality. However, the extreme experience made him to do such cold-blooded thing. Can we judge him, and criticize him whose wife's head was cut off, and whose daughters were thrown in hydrochloric acid? To make our society healthy, we must think that even so, this behavior is unjustifiable. However, in the bottom of my heart, I am not sure. Then, what is justice?

 Second one is about the evil. To be precise, the banality of evil. From the beginning of the movie, it intermittently shows Silvio's everyday life with his son, right after Kate's life in work or home. At first, I thought these scenes are meaningless, but now I understand the meaning of them. In my opinion, this character, Silvio represents the banality of evil. Silvio is an ordinary man, diligent police officer, and good father who cares about his son very much. On the other hand, he works for the cartel, and delivers drugs which destroys millions of families. That is, he is also the part of the evil that should be eradicated. This is the essence of evil. Not every bad guy looks like a monster. He or she is usually among our neighborhood, and can be good mother or father for their children, and outside home, destroys millions of families. No one is born evil, and looks like devil. No one is designated to be evil.

 'Sicario' is the movie that sets an extreme condition and require the audience to continuously question about the most basic rule and faith of our society. It does not give answers to these questions. Perhaps, no one can. I believe finding an answer is an obligation of all of us 'who lives in the lands of the wolves'

 I'd like to finish this plain review with the quote from 'Mad Max : Fury road', another fabulous movie of 2015 :

The sum of the movies parts don't equal something that memorable or even creative. It feels like the story builds all this anticipation and by the time it's over you feel like nothing happened. Take the Cohen Brothers classic "No Country For Old Men" (also starring Josh Brolin) the film is based on similar subject matter, it moves at a slow pace at times but by the end of the film you are left with so many deep and memorable scenes to draw from. I would be let down by every movie I see if I held it to the standard of "NCFOM", but I do expect the film to at least give me a little to work with. Unfortunately that is not the case with Sicario, it's worth one viewing but I would not add it to my collection.

Sicario is a bit of a tough movie to watch because it seems like the producer wants to desensitize the audience when it comes to murder and humanity. The fact that there are bodies hidden in the walls and hung across the tunnels in Mexico and Kate's lacking facial expression when she sees these atrocities shows that mutilated dead bodies are somewhat normal. This movie relates to the movie, Border Town, because of the misrepresentation of Mexico. Even though drug cartels exist, it seems like producers make these type of films to highlight the negative aspects of the country. City officials of Juarez even stated that this movie was depicting the city in a bad light. They also stated that criminal activities have declined since the movie has been made, so it appears that the producer wants to milk the criminal activity in Mexico as much as he can in order to make a masterpiece of a movie. 
Although one of the themes in the movie tries to portray the glorified murders in Mexico, an interesting theme in the movie is how they assigned a female to play the part of an FBI agent. Just like in the movie, Border Town¸ when Jennifer Lopez's character was assigned to play the lead role in solving or documenting a murder case, Kate, the FBI agent, is seen taking a stand and trying to figure out how to solve the case even after she was told that she wasn't needed anymore. Kate relates to Jennifer Lopez's character in Border Town after her boss decides not to use her information because he wants to sell out. These female characters are often assigned important roles in order to be demoted into the character that is no longer needed. This is borderline sexist because movies like this seem to be allowing the female characters to get a taste of being superior and to be considered as one of the guys when in reality they are just being used by the white men to gain access to the valuables. 
This movie proves itself to be sexist as well as devaluation of humanity because of the displays of dead bodies everywhere and that one female character who is considered to be of no use after the white men obtain what was needed. This movie appears to be insensitive to the people living in Juarez because they are communicating to the audience that this is not a safe place to visit or be. Sicario can influence a viewer to believe that the city of Juarez is dangerous and should be avoided at all costs.

Director Denis Villeneuve (Prisoners, Enemy) has proven to be a dominating force in cinema. Sicario is an another outstanding achievement in his career. This time, Villeneuve takes on America's war on drugs. From start to finish, Sicario is a tension filled spectacle. If ever think the film will ever ease up, don't hold your breath. 
Sicario follows a FBI Special Weapons and Tactics Teams agent Kate Macer, played by Emily Blunt. During a drug raid, a bomb goes off killing two fellow officers. She meets Matt Graver (Josh Brolin), a Department of Defense adviser who is setting up a team to capture those responsible. Kate is offered a spot, which she accepts. She soon meets Matt's mysterious partner, Alejandro (Benicio Del Toro). Kate begins to discover Matt's and Alejandro's unorthodox and illegal procedures. 
Sicario is dark and gripping tale held together by a strong direction, screenplay, and acting. Emily Blunt gives an outstanding performance that should earn her an Oscar nomination. Much like the audience, Kate is in the dark about Matt's and Alejandro's agenda. As the film progresses, she is given more light on their agenda, but is morally conflicted of how they are going about it. She wants to capture this drug lord, but at what cost? One of Blunt's strongest aspects of her performance is her facial expressions. It highlights her confusion and frustration with the situation. 
Brolin is stellar as the cocky team leader. Matt's one and only goal is to take down this drug lord in any way he can. He doesn't lose sleep about the way he goes about it, it's just business. The most mysterious character is Alejandro. Del Toro gives bone chilling performance. It is also his most captivating performance since Traffic. Maybe films about illegal drug trade is his calling. 
The unsettling direction by Villeneuve is brilliantly captured by cinematographer Roger Deakins. Deakins uses actual darkness to capitalize on the film's gritty nature. If I had to give one warning about Sicario is that there is no shining light at the end of the tunnel. The film does not give the viewer anything or anyone to hold on to. Sicario commits in being dark. You feel like you have to cleanse yourself afterwards. But while you are watching the film, you will be glued. Sicario is one of the most captivating films of the year.

An average film. Nothing particularly gripping, just very violent. It seems as though some of the violence depicted is based on the real life events/violence going on in Mexico. However, a lot of the plot seems rather unrealistic. For example, I thought Emily Blunt's character's relationship with the Swat team should have panned out differently because of both her attitude, voiced opposition to the unruly behaviour/operations of the Swat team and also when she goes off on her own during a live operation. You would have expected some harm to come to her. The other thing I did not get was how Emily's character and that of her partner who seem to be both in position through political correctness rather than ability, no matter how much the film tries to say otherwise, are able to just slot into the Swat team's operations. Just not realistic at all, almost stupid. A bit like joining the Navy Seals for an operation with no training at all. Then Del Torro fails to deal with Emily Blunt's character in the manner consistent with his character. Similarly, the last scene involving Del Torro and the Drug Lord is rather silly to say the least. Hasn't the director seen Scarface. In short, there are some good parts to the film and some ridiculous, almost lazy parts that the director could have sorted out if he had a bit more balls. Scorcessee would have made a classic out of this. It was begging for it.

The following review was created using notes I took after watching the film several months back. 

A bleak, pitch dark, hopeless, disturbing, and violent movie. Filled with an unrelenting tension and suspense (It's a film that turns rolling down your car window into a tension filled event). It's almost a dark horror film. 

It exists in a grey area. Nobody is good (Except for Emily Blunt and Daniel Kaluuya, who plays her buddy), but nobody is really bad either. Most are just grey, or bordering on bad. 

It's expertly shot, with cinematography by Roger Deacons. It deserves an Oscar nod/win for that alone. 

Emily Blunt has a flawless American accent and is beautiful in a normal, everyday way. She is our eyes into the film and she acts as our moral compass. 

Benicio Del Toro is what I like to call The Dark Angel of the film. Both he and Blunt deserve Oscar nods, him especially. He's a mysterious but very likable character and it is Blunt and him that are our main characters. 

Daniel Kaluuya is also fantastic. 

The opening scene is one of the best scenes in film this year. It's fantastic and gripping. 

Sicario is certainly a tough watch, and it's almost a downer of a film (Really, not a happy film....but what were you expecting?) but I applaud it for handling it's subject matter in an adult, mature way.

Sicario is a film that packs a punch and doesn't mind fighting without gloves on. Meaning hitman in Mexico, Sicario tells the story of three lawmen, hit-men, soldiers and consciences working their way through the streets of morality and legality in an effort to put a stop to the war on drugs. Emily Blunt plays the lawmen and conscience of the film, with Josh Brolin and Benecio Del Toro playing smoke and mirrors on the streets of Juarez wearing masks of lawmen and soldiers in order to regain control over the underground drug trafficking that has filtered over the border.

From the first scene Sicario comes out of the gate swinging, jostling your senses with a gorgeously timed house raid that plays out some thematic elements of action and horror that quickly let you know you aren't in for a singular note in this crescendo of movie making magic. After witnessing a few dozen bodies piled in between the walls of a suburban home in Arizona, we're quickly taken over the border, accompanied by Johann Johannsson's thumping drone and neo-classical score that gets your heart rate beating and demonstrates an amazing control over suspense. Not a stranger to crafting a story out of a simple notion, with Prisoners telling the tale of a family dealing with the kidnapping of their daughter, Denis Villeneuve manages to layer his film with enough tension, gritty action and dimly lit atmosphere that he makes setting a masterwork seem obvious.

Fade from black the film start with a legend, the true definition of Sicario.
latin term is a hitman, a person responsible killing by contract. But in Hebrew, Roman kill Zealots. 

With this title we been presented a blue print of what about too see. FBI agents Kate Macer (Emily Blunt) and Reggie Wayne (Daniel Kaluuya) raid the house of a suspected kidnappers. The team finds more than dozen of bodies hidden on the walls of the house.

After this operation Kate's boos recommend her to Matt Graver (Josh Brolin) a CIA Special Activities Division to join the team. Matt is searching for a cartel boss who presumably was one of the responsible of the murders found by Kate and Reggie.

Kate character is a green agent who still learning the vicious cycle inside FBI and CIA. Throughout the film she start discovering the corruption, manipulation, abuse of power of this federals agencies, but she is unaware of who is the real enemy.  Kate is a strong woman on the outside, vulnerable for been alone and also divorced, it's also supporter of ethics and respect in the force, one of her biggest enemies in this war against corruption. 

Arriving to el Paso, Texas in a orchestrated operation lead by Matt Graver, Kate meet with Alejandro Gallic (Benicio del Toro) an advisor who seems to have ties with enemy. Alejandro is very sketchy person, and Kate figure out the first time she see him.

Besides all this red flags Matt use it as his primary connection to get the cartel people capture.

Sicario is a thriller but also a great film about the hard reality of drug traffic in US borders. Masterfully directed by Denis Villeneuve (Enemy, Prisoners) the movie immerse you in a harsh terrain where only the strongest succeed. Villeneuve engage with the audience with a rollercoaster of emotions by manipulating the senses. Sicario have constant moments of silence, also supported by the impactful original score by Jóhann Jóhannsson and the intense sound crafted for this film. The visual style is borrowed from films by Steven Sodergber in Traffic, also Jonathan Demme in Silence of The Lambs. The intense and long aerial shots are powerful and serve as another character for the movie

After carefully you finish the film you came to the conclusion who is the enemy and who are the zealots. You care for Kate's character but not so much for Matt and Alejandro. The true meaning of sicario is the search for fanatical and uncompromising pursuit of ideas, that could be religious or political, you just need to pick one.
