This film makes you think, reflect, and quiver at the fact that this film is all based on what actually happens in the real world.

One has to love brilliant acting from Emily Blunt and Benicio del Toro, the most brilliant soundtrack which creates pounding tension and proper suspense, cinematography to create proper tension among sequences, etc. The story about drug trade is not new at all. After all these years' war on drugs, we are still fighting drug cartels, or drug cartels fighting one another, and so on. There is no black and white anymore as we might get the hint from Benicio del Toro' s character. And you know what? It is true. And who are we to judge what is right and what could possibly be definitely wrong?

One of my top three movies in 2015.

Sicario achieves the reality of drug wars that is often traded for the Hollywood effect; a reality where there are no losses or winnings, only trade-offs, and no heroes or villains, only victims. Intensely action packed from beginning to end, Sicario will have you at the edge of your seat while showing the astounding and brutal reality of drug wars and how powerful drug cartels really are.

Directed by Denis Villeneuve, Sicario is a film about an FBI agent who is enlisted by the government on a mission to bring down the leader of a powerful Mexican cartel. The flawless performance of Emily Blunt and Benicio del Toro, along with stunning cinematography, create a heavy and suspenseful atmosphere throughout the movie.

Most importantly however, is the story and its relevance to the real situation. As someone who lived in Juarez / El Paso while the worst of the drug wars was taking place, who watched news stories after news stories of brutal assassinations, shootings and kidnappings, and who saw how the city became deserted as people moved out and businesses closed due to fear, I got chills while watching this movie. One just had to innocently be at the wrong place at the wrong time to have an unlucky fate.

Sicario portrays the reality of a very cruel but important issue. While this film will not leave you with a warm feeling or a happy ending, you will be immersed into a very dark place and be surprised by how deep you will go.

Well directed. Decent cinematography. Very intense moments that didn't require high-octane action or even much dialogue. It's dark in tone and sometimes just in the screen, as well as gritty and even a tad gruesome in the first act. Emily Blunt does well even though I didn't care for her character in the film. Benecio Del Toro steals the movie in my opinion. Brolin is good in the film too as he adds some humor. Have to mention Victor Garber because I think he gets overlooked and for his short appearances it lends to the movie.

This movie is actually pretty damn good and close to great. It has some intense scenes and lots of subtleties. Del Toro is like the subtlety God in this film and pulls it off nicely. I honestly believe that if Del Toro is not in this movie then it would suffer severely. Sicario starts out following our lead (Blunt) and somewhere in the second act it starts following (Del Toro) all the way to the end and circles back to (Blunt) with a nice finish - albeit probably not the finish you're looking for either.

I have favorite scenes for each act in the film and would assume that you will as well. Is you're thinking that this movie is all about drugs and drug cartels, then you're wrong as it is about much more than that. If fact, there are little situations about drugs and you might see them a couple times at most. This film is actually about much more larger aspects than just simple drug running. Emily Blunt's character is an emotional wreck of some sorts and brings the movie down a bit for me, which is why I rated "Sicario" at a 3.5/5. If here character was different or not so much of a drag - then I rate it 4/5.

I highly recommend this movie and it is definitely re-watchable. I've seen it twice so far.

Let me know what you think after you watch it. As always, I would never to NOT or DON'T watch a movie as I want you to watch every movie as I do. Enjoy!

It's been over a month now since I've seen this film and it has stuck with me in a way few films have this year. Denis Villeneuve is a talented director who knows how to build the right atmosphere for his movies. Sicario is all about tone and atmosphere. We've seen the premise of this film done to death, but somehow Villeneuve and screenwriter Taylor Sheridan manage to tell a familiar story in a very unique way. The success of Sicario isn't that it has a unique premise or a fantastic twist, but that it manages to tell a familiar story in such a captivating way with some of the best performances of the year. Sicario will be included in my list of the best films of 2015 without a doubt, and it is a must see for movie fans around the globe. Emily Blunt continues to expand her acting career with another brilliant performance although its Benicio de Toro who will get all the accolades for getting the stronger dramatic material to work with.

The film has the best opening sequence by far in a movie released this year as we are introduced to Emily Blunt's character, Kate Macer, who is leading a SWAT team across an Arizona desert and into a house where they suspect to find one of the Mexican cartel leaders, but end up finding much more than what they bargained for. Kate is a tough DEA agent who is determined to bring down the Mexican cartel. Once they arrive back at the station she is introduced to Josh Brolin's Matt Graver, a superior who wants her assistance in catching the cartel leader who was responsible for the events that unfolded at the house. Graver has a suave persona, he may be in charge of the operation but he seems laid back with his flip flops and cargo pants. His right hand man is much more silent and mysterious. It's Benicio del Toro's Alejandro, who certainly seems menacing and is hiding something underneath his calmed demeanor. He is evidently a man who has seen and experienced a lot of things in life. Kate accepts the mission despite not being fully informed of what she must do and she becomes a surrogate for the audience as she tries to understand what these men are up to just as we do. Villeneuve keeps the audience hooked and engaged while taking us through the Mexican border an back again with some magnificent cinematography from Roger Deakins. Sicario is a brilliant film that maintains the tension throughout its entire runtime. My only complaint is that the second half isn't as strong as the first.

Sicario is a film that should receive several nominations come Award time and I can't see how Del Toro won't be nominated for his superb supporting performance here. Although I must say that Brolin and Blunt are equally deserving for their work. Blunt is much more subtle in her approach as she has to adapt to this masculine dominated world and is constantly left in the loop of things. Brolin plays a character that he could play in his sleep with his suave and cool exterior, but he does it so well that it's hard not to sympathize with him. Del Toro is menacing and his turn as Alejandro will be one of the most memorable characters of the year. He has some great scenes. It's hard to avoid some comparisons with Zero Dark Thirty, especially the way some of the scenes were shot and how it focuses (although in a very different way) on two strong motivated female characters who are determined to accomplish their goal in a masculine run world. It also happens to be a very intelligent thriller that manages to tell a familiar story in a fresh way. Sometimes it's not what you say, but how you say it that makes the difference and in Sicario Villeneuve manages to craft an engaging work of art. This is the Zero Dark Thirty of war on drug films.

Daniel Villeneuve's "Sicario" is a brilliant film that features beautiful direction, some great performances, and stunning cinematography from Roger Deakins. But however perfect I want it to be, this movie still has flaws. The characters aren't too unique or interesting  in their own right, they're all just tropes, and the scenes near the end that focus on Benicio del Toro's character, while great, feel out of place with the rest of the movie. Despite the faults that it has, all its accomplishments are enough to outweigh them and to make this the best major motion picture of 2015 so far. -Sicario is een 2015 Amerikaanse crime thriller film geregisseerd door Denis Villeneuve en geschreven door Taylor Sheridan. De film sterren Emily Blunt, Benicio Del Toro, en Josh Brolin. Deze film  werd gekozen om te strijden voor de Palme d'Or op het 2015 Cannes Film Festival.
-In december 2013 werd aangekondigd dat Denis Villeneuve  een Mexicaanse grens drama zou dirigeren, Sicario (het Spaanse woord voor Hitman).

--Kritische reactie:

-Sicario wordt alom geprezen door critici. Recensie aggregator website RottenTomatoes, de film heeft een goedkeuringsscore van 93%, gebaseerd op 184 reviews, met een gemiddelde waardering van 8.1/10.. De site's kritische consensus leest. "Geleid door uitstekende werk van Emily Blunt en Benicio Del Toro, Sicario is een strak, stevig gespannen thriller met veel meer bezig dan aandacht trekkende decorstukken." Op Metacritic, de film heeft een gewogen gemiddelde score van 81 uit 100, gebaseerd op 41 critici, met vermelding "success". Op CinemaScore, publiek heeft de film een gemiddelde cijfer van "A-" op een A TOT F-schaal.

-Richard Roeper heeft de film een tien, noemt het een van de beste van dit jaar, en bejubeld del Toro's performance, zeggende: "...er is del Toro, die loert over de marge van de actie voor het merendeel van het verhaal, en dan in actie springt in een handvol scènes in een verscheidenheid van manieren die laat  geschud laten - en dankbaar om een zo  mooi donker werk gezien te hebben'.
-Dan Jolin van Empire heeft de film 5 sterren en noemt het "een prachtig duistere, keiharde thriller. Gewoon één van de beste films van het jaar."

-hoewel haar personage Kate Mercer niet plausibel is, Emily Blunt "brazens uit eventuele onrechtmatigheden met grote actering focus en front".

- "kunstig en spraakmakend" en "onberispelijk realistische momenten", heeft een aantal tekortkomingen. Ten eerste, de federale agenten".agressieve tactieken en overtredingen in regels in Sicario zijn veel meer nodeloos dan eender wat hij getuigde in zijn verslag. Ten tweede is er een gebrek aan invallende Spaanse rechtshandhaving agenten, zoals personages, in de film in verhouding tot die momenteel in het echte leven werkend. Tenslotte de film richt zich overwegend op het Amerikaanse oogpunt in de war on drugs.

-heeft de film een B-, waaruit blijkt dat het gebrek aan karakter ontwikkeling was een afknapper ondanks extreem sterke cinematografische en stijlvol regisseren. Hij voegde er nog aan toe dat "Sicario wellicht één van de meest melancholische, moreel failliet, en ethisch inhoudsloze mainstream films die dit jaar is uitgebracht; toch, zulke zwaarmoedigheid komt met het grondgebied van het huidige, politicus-gebrandmerkte 'war on drugs'.

-Chris Ryan van Grantland vergelijkt Sicario met de film Apocalypse Now geregisseerd door Francis Ford Coppola. Hij stelt de gelijkenis van de visuals met betrekking tot de respectieve narratieven van de twee films. Hij schrijft ook dat de karakters  Alejandro Gillick, en Matt graven in Sicario zijn vergelijkbaar met die van kolonel Kurtz en William Kilgore, respectievelijk in Apocalypse Now.

--Reactie van ambtenaren in Ciudad Juárez (Mexico):

-Sicario's portrettering van Ciudad Juárez werd bekritiseerd door functionarissen van die stad, die dachten dat de film  hun stad in een kwaad daglicht stelde. In de film opgenomen sequenties die kadavers opknoping aan downtown viaducten en nachtelijke vuurgevechten in de stad vertoont. Deze ambtenaren zijn van mening dat op het moment van de release van de film, de intensiteit van criminele activiteit in de stad aanzienlijk waren gedaald ten opzichte van voorgaande perioden.


- Bestudering van de Amerikaanse War on Drugs:

-Volgens Sebastian Rotella, Sicario onderzocht vele aspecten van de oorlog tegen drugs door de Verenigde Staten tegen, meestal, drugskartels in Mexico, Zuid-Amerika en Midden-Amerika. Een perspectief nemend als een Amerikaanse, zo merkte hij op dat de film illustreert hoe de Amerikaanse war on drugs is "wat ons in het bijzonder tot monsters maakt die wij proberen te verslaan." Bovendien is de situatie in Mexico, met betrekking tot de illegale drugshandel, gestagneert voor twee decennia, zoals van de film's release. Dit punt is herhaaldelijk door het personage Matt Graves gemaakt in de film.

Sicario es una de las mejores películas que han visto la luz a lo largo de este 2015. Un crudo retrato del conflicto social que vive México respecto al crimen organizado y narcotráfico,  tensa y emocionante, desde su inicio la película no se guarda nada y muestra de manera muy bien estructurada todo el proceso  que se lleva en la lucha día a día contra estos criminales. 
Las actuaciones de Emily Blunt y sobre todo de Benicio del Toro son fenomenales, la dirección de Denis Villeneuve es impecable, el desarrollo de la psicología de los personajes es muy impresionante. Lo más impactante de todo es ver como la policia federal de México trabaja a la par con el FBI y fuerzas especiales, ciudad juarez al desnudo envuelta en violencia y traiciones de ambos lados tanto de los buenos como de los malos.
Al final de cuentas todos estos elementos hacen de Sicario una experiencia reflexiva sobre una situación que se presenta tal y como es, sin las incoherencias y grandilocuencias de series de univisión como "El señor de los cielos" o "la reina del sur", Sicario va mucho más allá y no sólo enaltece este genero sino que lo realizado en esta película se siente a veces como un documental por la dosis de realismo implementada en ella.

Expert camera work and cinematography help give the movie a real world feel to it with a soundtrack and score worthy of at least an Oscar for its job in bringing the movie to life and keeping the audience on the she of its seat as they wait to see what the sicario does next.

Sicario can be summed up in one word: intense. From the explosive first scene to the pulse pounding conclusion, the film is unrelenting in both its imagery and pace. This does not, however, hide the fact that the lead character, played by Emily Blunt, is a weak willed female being dominated by her male counterparts. This is a shame, as in the past, Emily Blunt has portrayed very strong female leads, such as in Looper or Edge of Tomorrow. I was looking forward to her dominating the screen, but instead found her crying more than she was helping her mission. The story is interesting, but once everything is set in motion, it is hard not to predict just what is really going on behind the curtain. It would be a mistake not to commend Roger Deakins on his brilliant cinematography, as there are some brilliant shots of Mexico that are haunting in their beauty. The soundtrack also helps to lend a sense of weight to the proceedings. I'm alway impressed with Denis Villeneuve's direction, and this is no exception. If it weren't for the disappointing lead character, and the predictable plot points, this may have been up there for my favourite film of the year. If you enjoy dark thrillers, action films or dramas, this should definitely be on your short list for movies to watch this year. 4 out of 5 stars.

La historia de Sicario no va a más allá de donde muchos otros thrillers antes que ella han ido. No es nada nueva. Por dios, esa escena en la aduana es oro puro.

Su buen hacer se nota también en el gran trabajo que ha realizado con sus actores, destacando a Del Toro, Blunt y  Brolin, un trio que me dejó asombrado con sus actuaciones en la película. Blunt tine un personaje femenino complejo y bien construido y que es una extrapolación del propio público; mientras que Del Toro tiene un personaje que está diseñado para "caer bien", pero que en el fondo sabes que tiene algo oscuro y perturbador.

La fotografía de Deakins es brillante, destacando su trabajo en la escena del túnel.

For me Sicario was the most unsettling film of the year. I found this much more disturbing and difficult than The Revenant, or even the documentary The Look of Silence.
Although technically a fictional story, the film is laced with a gritty, docudrama aesthetic, albeit a beautifully photographed one, and is anchored in real world concerns that plague the various citizens and law enforcement agencies represented. 
I greatly admire this film. It's a work of art by a very talented group of artisans, it is well told and very intense. That being said, it's not a film I'll return to very often precisely because of how well it does its job. But I can certainly see why it has cracked so many critics year end top ten lists. 
Don't get me wrong, this is a great movie about a pressing topic that should be seen if you have any interest in films about the cartel, about the drug trade or about Americas various arms of law. All I'm saying is it's unpleasant to watch and to think about. It's very dark and ends quite cynically and as such I doubt I'll return to it often.

I'm kind of torn on this one. The tension was great throughout, but it felt really empty. What did the protagonist learn?  Did she grow as a result of her journey? You can try to argue, these aren't always necessary,  and that's cool,  but hell, she wasn't even in the climax of the movie. You might be able to say the last scene between Blunt and Del Toro is the climax, but it's weak by comparison.  It's probably because she isn't the main character. 

If you want to have a female protagonist, great. We need more movies like that. But don't pretend she's the main character if she's not. The movie's called Sicario, and Del Toro's in all the important scenes of the movie, including the climax. You want to tell the story through her perspective,  right on. Have her be there when Del Toro kills the head of the cartel. I can see that being pretty intense,  but no. We get this muddled story without a resolution for the lead. 

On a positive note, it was exciting throughout. It's the kind of movie you don't make time to see again but definitely worth a watch.

"Sicario" has a toughness to it that is appreciated, plus a great deal of suspense and terrific work from the leads, particularly Benecio Del Toro. The ending is undeniably grim, though, and makes the movie a bit harder to recommend. Not saying I wouldn't tell people it's worth seeing, but I'd advise them to be prepared for the last few minutes.

Featuring stunning cinematography from the Roger Deakins, strong performances from Blunt and Del Toro, and a heart-pounding score from Johann Johannsson, Sicario has all the makings of a great film. As with Prisoners (2013) and Enemy (2014), Villeneuve uses Sicario both to challenge viewers and to drag them into a haunting and morally ambiguous world that they won't soon forget. Though Taylor Sheridan's script is not always as clear, as focused, or as committed as it could be, Sicario remains gripping and entertaining throughout. But it's still a shame that it doesn't quite live up to its potential.

Villenueve gives us the notion that the "bad guys" are simply good people who've been corrupted by the world -- and, all they're doing is fulfilling their definition of what justice is, it's all very morbid, and it's all too real

Sicario does not hold the audience's hand. In fact, even Emily Blunt's character is mostly left out of the loop as Denis Villeneuve dives into the unknown of crime and corruption. The build-up of tension is thus more impactful, with excellent cinematography that captures the sprawling environments which would be explored. The intertwining subplot is only occasionally seen, but it is there to further the ripple effect that the main plot causes.

While Blunt and Josh Brolin are solid, Benicio Del Toro is one to look out for, as his character has a lot on his mind. The actors in general do display bits of comic relief to ease the film's stressful nature. Nevertheless, Blunt's character is purposely treated in a sexist manner, only so that she can properly manifest her opposition to the unethical procedures being ran by the team with whom she otherwise thought her methods would be useful.

The lack of soundtrack of course adds more tension to demanding scenes, while the music that does play is visceral. And off-screen sound plays a key role in the alienation of the plot towards us and Blunt's character.

Denis Villeneuve is however no stranger to tackling unconventional methods of storytelling, and thanks to his and his crew's fine work, Sicario proves to be a mysterious, daring, competent crime thriller.

I was not a fan of director Denis Villeneuve's first two efforts ("Prisoners" and "Enemy"), both of which I felt suffered from weak writing.  Luckily, with this film, Villeneuve finally found the right material to suit his style.  Everything hits right in this movie, it's the perfect storm of an excellent script, sharp directing, and a stellar cast.  The actors are all at the top of their games, particularly Benicio Del Toro, who is in peak badass form.  The film has the same stylized look and ominous tone as Villeneuve's first two features, but as a composition, this one is far superior.  The film starts with a bang (there aren't even any opening credits) and grabs your attention right out of the gate, I was hooked within the first 5 minutes.  The story skims along nicely and maintains high-tension throughout, and makes excellent use of music to help pile on the tension.  It's not easy to watch, but it's to be commended that the film does not pull its punches, and it's all the more affecting for it.   There are some pretty disturbing images and concepts here, but that's really the point.  This movie does not give you the typical "good guy/bad guy" scenario that we can all sit back and be comfortable with.  Instead, it's a full-tilt exploration of moral ambiguity and challenges your ideas of what being a "good" or "bad" guy even means.  But more than anything, it's a depressing confirmation that the 'War on Drugs' is hopelessly unwinnable. It does lose some points for a having a female lead who, in typical Hollywood fashion, ultimately has to be saved by a man.  So that was disappointing, I would have liked to see the so-called "strong female lead" save herself for a change.  But that's really all I can say against it.  This is an intelligent, atmospheric, gripping, and thought-provoking psychological thriller, that's also incredibly well made.  It doesn't give you the warm fuzzies, nor should it, but it should be seen.

One of the best movies of 2015. At the border of the United States and Mexico lies a lawless land where justice is not always black and white. A young FBI agent Kate Macer (Emily Blunt) is working with the FBI to catch drug trafficker with a violent record. Sadly, she finds that the scope of the corruption is beyond her understanding. She is recruited by Matt Graver (Josh Brolin) to be part of an Undercover Team to pick up a witness across the Mexican Border, and bring him back to the United States. Kate meets Alejandro (Benicio Del Toro) who is a Consultant that she doesn't understand his job. As they cross the border, everything she believes is tested and her loyalties come in question. Their mission to find a notorious Drug King Pin turns into a bloody path with no real distinction between wrong and right. This movie is such a brilliantly directed movie with a perfect cast. Emily Blunt is so convincing as the naive FBI agent & Del Toro steals the screen with just one look. I expect this to be one of the contenders for awards season.

SICARIO-2015(R)-Oct. 24.
By:The Movie Guy.

In Sicario, Emily Blunt plays Kate Macer, a DEA agent recruited to join a team led by DOD adviser Matt Graver (Josh Brolin) to capture Mexican cartel leader Manuel Diaz (Bernardo P. Sacarino) who Kate holds responsible for blowing up several of her fellow officers in a previous attempt. Believing that the team which now includes a shady agent named Alejandro (Benicio Del Toro) are going to El Paso, Kate soon realizes that they are instead crossing the broader into Mexico. Once in Mexico, Kate begins questioning why she was chosen for the team after seeing some of the shocking methods being employed by the team in order to catch Diaz. Kate discovers that law & justice will be violated in order to stop the drugs from entering the Untied States. Directed by Denis Villeneuve from a screenplay written by Taylor Sheridan, Sicario is an intense, heart-pounding thriller with some stunning twists that you don't see coming. The performances from Emily Blunt & Benicio Del Toro were terrific & captivating. I would not be surprised to see this film getting some award consideration. MUST-SEE FILM.

SICARIO - an emotionally driven thriller where actions speak louder than words. I saw this in a packed theatre on Sunday night after the Walking Dead... just when I thought I was desensitized to violence, I was rudely awakened and nearly walked out on the movie when my date complained that we were sitting too close and the violent imagery was too intense, but the artistic filmmaking was captivating and we stuck through it. There's not much to say about the plot, since it's more about emotionally exploring the world of drug cartels on the other side of the American border. Through terrible events that occur around and directly to the main character, an idealistic white woman (an important storytelling decision), our sense of American law, order, and justice is crushed. This movie is not for kids and its full impact is best experienced in a dark movie theatre...

The biggest war that America needs to win isn't in the middle east or South Asia. It is deep within its heartland where the drug lords of the Mexican cartels have spread the highly influential poison and there is no sign of it ceasing. Tons of illicit drugs pass through secretive tunnels beneath the borders of USA and Mexico, accounting to some very wealthy and powerful cartels while scores of Americans perish under their harmful effects. Parts of Mexico are literally the most violent places on Earth and while Denis Villeneuve's 'Sicario' showcases all these realities between the borders, it serves merely as a backdrop to the true motive hidden beneath the story's surface. This covert war on drugs by America is completely in the gray area of morality and justice of which, Kate (Emily Blunt) is an exponent. She is, however, only learning to cope with the reality around her which alters itself brutally and that, makes her the perfect proxy for the audience.

	The cartel has pushed deeper into American soil with Manuel Diaz controlling much of their trade through his legit businesses. While raiding one of his properties for a kidnapping investigation, FBI agent Kate discovers several decaying bodies hidden behind the walls of a house in Chandler, AZ and a subsequent explosion in the backyard shed leaves two of her agents dead. Determined to bring Manuel to justice, she agrees to volunteer in a covert CIA mission led by Matt Graver (Josh Brolin). On their way to El Paso, she is introduced to the mysterious Alejandro (Benicio Del Toro), whose shady background keeps Kate on guard but whose sharpness on field soon gains her respect. 
What follows is perhaps the most tense, suspenseful sequence where the agents extradite Guillermo (Manuel's brother) in and out of a prison in Juarez. Brilliantly executed with escalating build-up, aerial cinematography of chaos and a thumping background score, this has to be among the finest moments in recent cinema. Emily Blunt's performance thereafter, portraying Kate's disbelief in the irresponsible engagement with the cartel members at the border in the midst of civilians, is outstanding. Throughout the film, she shows her righteous side that upholds justice, procedure and law. She is vocal about the ambiguity of the mission but as the events unfold, she is left with no choice but to become part of Matt's anarchic team. They soon track down Manuel and initiate a plan that would require him to meet the Cartel's head in Mexico to answer some questions. 
Against the backdrop of an incredible sunset, the team discovers the tunnel that would lead them to the cartel but Kate sees things she wasn't supposed to. Josh Brolin really gets into his character as he enlightens her about the reality that will be too much for her to handle. He is a bad-ass agent who isn't shaken by the guns firing around him as he chews his gum. Brolin depicts Matt's coldness but with purpose as he sets himself to pursue the bigger objective of the mission. Between Kate's idealism and Alejandro's darkness, Matt is simply a reality check for the situation and Josh Brolin delivers that superbly. Mayhem on a personal level ensues after the tunnel episode and without revealing much of the story's twist, it should suffice to say that it all makes sense in the end. Benicio Del Toro revisits the cartel world after 'Traffic', 'Che' and 'Escobar'. His insight into Alejandro's character seems naturally easy with a rock solid composure under any circumstance that is a result of his dark past. We will never know what he precisely did with the 10 gallon water container that he took into the interrogation room where Guillermo was held and that, is the level of intrigue held by Del Toro's performance. 

Screenwriter Taylor Sheridan doesn't just focus on the menace of cartel activity on the streets. The film also goes into its effect on a completely normal family of Silvio, a police officer in Mexico who gets his hands dirty for that extra income. Kate's evolution as a special agent in the war on drugs is in sharp contrast to Silvio's journey. The cinematography by Roger Deakins truly brings out the thrill of imminent danger with vast aerial shots, wide sunset shots and close, dark encounters in the tunnel sequence and the minimalist background score by Johan Johannsson's simply augments the effect.  
Villeneuve delineates this covert war on drugs without the typical mainstream approach. He shows monstrosity taking over both sides, resulting in total neglect of judicial process, law and morals. Benicio Del Toro is the manifestation of this monstrosity in a laudable performance that should win him a nomination for the Oscars. 'Sicario' isn't triumphant for society but it truly is one of the best thrillers that shows the merciless environment created by the cartels on both sides of the border.

Mexico's gruesome cartel wars makes for a bleak and deeply unsettling subject, but in recent years it's been mined by a number of directors and yielded a slew of terrific films.  Sin Nombre, Cartel Land, Narco Cultura and a few others come to mind.  Sicario has now firmly planted itself in that group.  Probably best described as a cross between Zero Dark Thirty and No Country for Old Men, this movie borrows some of the best elements of both films to paint a brutal, deeply cynical portrait of "The War on Drugs" and its gruesome human costs.  

Without delving too deep into the story since you should see it - tonight if you could - but Emily Blunt gives a terrific turn as strong-headed, by-the-book FBI agent overwhelmed by an amorphous moral morass she finds herself in.  Benicio Del Toro has always been a versatile actor - and he's been one of my favorite character actors since The Usual Suspects.  He's been in enough cartel movies to be dangerously-close to being typecast.  That said, he always brings something extra to these movies and he does amazing work here as a world-weary, mysterious enforcer.  

The past few weeks have been great for devastatingly-bleak films about real-world issues anchored by phenomenal performances (I saw this shortly after watching Beasts of No Nation which saw Idris Elba and newcomer Abraham Attah deliver awards-worthy work).  Like that film, much of Sicario's haunting power comes from its rootedness in the ugliness of the world we live in but often choose to acknowledge.
A masterful combination of tension and action culminates in this beautiful display of a film. a must-see for 2015!

(On a side note, MAN has this month been good to us for movies this year. When you have not one or two but SIX high-grade films released within the span of a month, it's like an elusively rare slice of moviegoing heaven)

A pure mood piece. Stellar acting, a nervy score and assured pacing make Sicario the best thriller of the year. Without hyperbolising, this is an utterly visceral experience, with Villevenue gripping you tightly and holding you down, forcing you to witness the atrocities, which, whilst mostly played with nuance and style, are undeniably vile, with the revulsion pushed to the limit by the end of the film. This is a brutal, cold, unflinching and often breathtaking thriller, with awards-worthy work from actors Blunt and Del Toro, as well as covertly masterful cinematography from veteran Roger Deakins. If there's one flaw it's that, whilst Sicario may seep inside you as you watch, the wider point it makes about the situation in Mexico is rather unsubstantial if you consider it a few days later. No matter, this is pulse pounding thrill ride and any other cliché I could put here to close the review. It's good - watch it.

The excellently directed Sicario is something I haven't seen in some time. Blending an almost majestic quality to the scope and span of the lands between Mexico and the US, which in simple terms for Sicario, the entrance to hell. The three lead performances of Josh Brolin, Emily Blunt and Benicio Del Toro are remarkable and mesmerizing to watch, with Blunt's traumatized protagonist leading us through a greenhorn's look at across the Mexican border and into a dark and violent world where law is forgotten and a distant idea. Brolin is likeable and charming as the commander of the squadron, Blunt is remarkable in her depiction of a woman thrust into a very real side of cruelty and injustice, but Del Toro steals the show with his as what I can only call the sicario, or hitman. His character's deeply troubled backstory adds to the disturbing nature of the somber and calm way he handles himself and commits atrocities, making you truly question what he stands for. The action scenes are incredibly thought out and the growing tension and suspense is Hitchcock level in how the scenes are set. The soundtrack adds a dark, ominous and thrilling atmosphere to an already chillingly grim and real movie.

Another taut and gripping film from "Prisoners" director Denis Villeneuve. Emily Blunt is on great form as Kate Macer, an FBI agent tasked to assist a special ops team on an escalating drugs war between the US and Mexico. Tension arises when one of the team members is a Colombian hitman or "Sicario", played brilliantly by a ruthless Benicio Del Toro and Kate has to deal with the complexities and conspiracies of the very side she is on. With good support from Josh Brolin, this is a very well made movie that is grounded in stark reality - only suffering in a slight lack of emotional investment with the characters (for me), due to cold and bleak nature of its story. Not quite the 5 star film some of the critics have said, but very close.

Denis Vilneuve is an expert in tension and atmosphere - this much I know. Sicario is a story highly worthy of being told. A very entertaining and flawlessly executed movie that made me hold my breath multiple times. Sometimes I felt so tense, that any little sound made me jump out of my seat. It's a gritty examination of Mexico's dire drug problem and its effects on the USA. Outstanding cinematography - of a landscape that is character in itself- and music that heightens the tension combine with Villeneuve's superb storytelling and intense performances especially by Emily Blunt- who holds her own in a tough male dominated world. Del Toro and Blunt both deliver outstanding performances, but Emily Blunt has an edge of steel. She brings off a mix of confidence, bewilderment and vulnerability. If you don't wanna watch this movie for its story, watch it for her. She ralmost knocks everyone else unconscious in this movie.
Sicario is the kind of drama/action movie you wanna (or should) see. The tension and emotions are present 110%. The whole time I could not stop asking myself the question ''Who will pull the trigger first?''. You don't really trust anyone except Kate (Emily Blunt) - who is not trusting anyone either. Every time an ally is met, that ally either dies or betrays someone. Sicario is a completely engrossing, beautifully shot, terrifically acted thriller that exceeds expectations. I won't give away the opening scene, but I'd find it hard to believe that you're bored after seeing that. It's ultimately disturbing, kind of dark in a way, but that's also one of the reason why it succeeds: it reaches out to the audience and plays with your emotions.
Villeneuve's taut direction, combined with beautiful cinematography, and an amazing score, make Sicario one of his best in his constantly growing filmography. The end result is a great movie that will hopefully get recognition at award season. A tense drama that is engaging yet leaves you feeling helpless at the end.

I found Sicario like a high-tech, action-packed, 2-hour Donald Trump ad. The film depicts a Mexico overrun with "bad hombres," with "wolves," spilling over and under an ever-present but never adequate border fence. Idealistic FBI agents like Emily Blunt and Daniel Kaluuya can't effectively prosecute this international crime: They're always too late, the violence keeps getting more horrific. Only ruthless, lawless, equally criminal strategies and tactics seem effective, where the corrupting influences of drug money and force spill out from an anarchic Latin America into the US. Josh Brolin's CIA squad and the Colombian-hired "sicario" or hitman, Benecio del Toro, need to mount an ambitious covert op. 

We Yanquis do come in for brief flourishes of rhetorical condemnation: A villain accuses the US of "showing" our neighbors how to be truly brutal; Brolin complains helplessly about the "20%" (?) of Americans buying Colombian cocaine. 

But these deflections don't pack anything like the visceral punch of the lawless violence, the decapitations, the sense of a spreading war zone conveyed in virtually every scene in the film. 

I just rolled my eyes when a character who's "seen to much" is advised to retreat from the advancing "wolves" to a "small town." There are small towns with drug epidemics, gangs, and corrupt cops, cabrÃ³n. And there are cities with more rule of law than those small towns, or the border hellscape painted here.

Enemy, Prisoners and now... Sicario; Denis Villeneuve proves once and for all that he is one of, if not, THE most talented new directors to hit our screens in quite some time. For me, Sicario is one of the most grounded and realistic films i've ever seen. Every gunshot, every stand off and every corpse you see feels tactile, has gravitas and feels important. Rather than a story about the "War on Drugs", Sicario is much more a comment on the war and american foreign policy in general which originally took me off guard but I believe offered a much more deep and rewarding narrative for a film of such defined scope. The direction by Villeneuve is remarkably immersive as you the audience are treated just like Kate (Emily Blunt's character) as you are thrown into the story, out of depth and unsure of what lies ahead trying to negotiate the morality of what you see before you. Emily Blunt and Josh Brolin are remarkable while Benecio Del Toro is simply superb and deserves a nomination for, what I feel, is a career defining role as the troubled and enigmatic Alejandro. The moody, steady paced and brooding tone of the picture is matched by Roger Deakins' signature flawless cinematography where images of the vast landscape of Juarez and El Paso flow like liquid and where nighttime shots ACTUALLY look like nighttime!!! The thumping composed score by Johann Johannsson feels like that of a horror movie and keeps tension as high as possible during gripping build ups to shootouts between the cartel and the FBI. To conclude... Sicario is a film where it's weight doesn't hit you until you step out of the screen and really contemplate what you've just witnessed. One of the best films of the year and a real treat.... GO SEE IT!!!!

Josh Brolin is very funny as the POS FBI guy, and Benicio is an absolute badass, like an Anton Chigurh with a heart of gold. I much prefer this portrayal of our police/military/intelligence communities to that of "Eye in the Sky" because the truth is that they are comprised of gradients of awful, murderous people. As Alejandro says, "You are not a wolf, and only wolves live here now." It has the occasional weak spots, but, overall, one of last year's best movies and I can't wait for the sequel.

Benicio del Toro represents the outcome with baggy eyed authority  whilst Josh Brolin's amoral character view represents the problem. As a cake, Sicario's ingredients are crude but it has an icing of great accomplishment.

SICARIO is a thrilling film that plays like a gradual punch of adrenaline; it is a master class in the control of tension as it places, lingers, and develops it in all the right places. This is achieved courtesy of not only Denis Villeneuve's bold direction but also the original score's strong presence and top-notch editorial and cinematographic execution. Not for the faint-hearted, this film truly aims to make viewers feel the weight of the scenes and is great in many ways once some glaring flaws are overlooked - flaws that include (1) a script that by the end isn't as expansive and fulfilling as initially indicated, and (2) some rushed and implausible moments of decision and protocol regarding our lead character (the entire third act is a bit iffy). With that said, SICARIO employs high stakes that effectively utilize the tools of cinema, and does so in a way that admirably and provocatively explores the conflict between morality and serviceability.

I suppose that this is illustrative of the film's insistence on realism and grittiness over contrivances and for that, I do applaud, but as a result, the downbeat and disconnected ending feels less than satisfying but maybe the gender unfairness is the point here?

Blunt exhibits Kate's weathering with dynamic devolution. She droops her already stale stare while an increasing reliance on cigarettes shine a growing fault in her armor. Yet Blunt moves with conviction and talks with adamant purpose despite knowing and being repeatedly told she's out of her element. Perhaps the most intriguing part of Kate's character, though, has nothing to do with Blunt. Whereas the majority of feminist films are concerned with building a strong female character, 'Sicario' rather tears its down. Kate is already atop the FBI, she's being asked to join a CIA op, and has displayed prowess in leading the aforementioned raid, and apprehending several other prominent cartel figures. In Mexico she's still surrounded by burley men and still taking orders from masculine superiors in Brolin and Del Toro's characters. Subconsciously we want to believe these conflicts are what empower her as a woman, but, the part being originally written for a male, we rather see Kate's strength where she's weakest. "I'm not a soldier," says Kate, and we believe her because the harassment, violence, and horrors she witnesses justify her loosing grasp on the law and make her human in a land of wolves.

FULL REVIEW HERE: http://indieadam.com/2015/10/04/sicario-review-indieadam/

Emily Blunt and Benicio del Toro put in two excellent performances in this thriller about the war on drugs between the US and Mexico. Directed by Denis Villeneuve (Prisoners) this is well executed film with some very tense set pieces.  

The story focuses on Kate Macy played by Emily Blunt, an FBI agent who has been hand picked to join an elite task force headed by Josh Brolin.  However Macy is kept mostly in the dark about what her job is and it is this separation that the audience also feels.  If Macy is the moral and righteous core on the flip-side you have Benicio Del Toro, who plays Alejandro, a Colombian consultant with some questionable methods of interrogation.  And like Del Toro must of the characters in the film are unapologetic about who they are and realistic about the situation they are in which just adds to the whole sense of alienation and griminess of the film.   

Although it is a film that very well made it isn't one that you'll instantly want to watch again.  However having said that you do feel that this part of something more epic.

It is unclear why this film was made except for Americans to beat off to yet another mindless action-adventure that the studio tried to make legitimate by including Emily Blunt in the film. The development of the characters in this film likely occurred in ten or twenty minutes with the screenwriter arguing with the director over a bologna sandwich. Matt is the typical brash but yet relaxed government agent of unknown origin, who is somehow made into a complete character here by giving him flip-flops so we can see his relaxed side. Alejandro has all the charisma of Frankenstein uttering lines that would make Tom Cruise blush, such as "You are asking me how a watch works. Just pay attention to the time." There is more drama and legitimacy in any episode of CSI or NCIS than this turd of a movie. We are supposed to believe that Blunt, who appears to have a passive and unnatural role in a kidnapping squad is brought into the inner circle of homeland security/CIA to tag along with special ops and so forth. In her work with the FBI she has likely used a gun once or twice and now is carrying a machine-gun down a tunnel into Mexico. I had to laugh when Alejandro brings Blunt's character a piece of paper at the end to sign to approve of what happened. Sure, sure, that's how it works, there is some piece of paper that CIA or special ops carries around and so long as it is signed, then everything is fine, and how convenient to create an ethical dilemma for the character. The comparisons here to Michael Mann are comedic -- this film is not worthy of the dirty toilet paper used on the set of a film like Heat. There are too many cliches in this film to count -- the slightly overweight slap-happy military types. The older bravado US Marshall types who are OK with joking about drinking to make your hand steady. The older White man Washington insider serious types. The field agent with more of an ethical awareness type who is brought into a world of greater moral ambiguity. The classic American bar scene where you get a couple of beers and have a honky tonk dance but be careful not to get double-crossed rape by border control agent gone rogue who happens to look like a Hispanic version of Bruce Springsteen with his nose broken. And how tragic that those little plastic-y wrist bracelets that everyone wears for cancer awareness and such can now apparently tip us off to anyone with a heart of evil. Josh Brolin steals a lot here from Jesse "the Body" Ventura's work in Predator I. How about the scene where Alejandro carefully folds his white linen jacket to add some complexity to his character. I can just imagine the director asking the writer to fill out the character a bit more and the writer comes up with idea of having him fold his jacket. If you want to see a Michael Mann movie, see a Michael Mann movie. If you want to see a two-hour version of CSI Mexico, then you might enjoy this.

I was looking forward to seeing this, due to its high ratings by both critics and audience, despite it having a bad trailer. But all I can say after watching it, is "why?". The characters were more of just robots than fleshed out people with interesting backstories. The main character was a naive punching-bag, and might as well have been and audience member who also had no idea what was going on. I might have cared about the story or the tension more if I cared in the slightest for any of the characters. The one character that was more than a guy who "does this" or is "Mr. I'm Mysterious", was Kate's friend who was at least funny and cared about her. To add on to that, there was never a moment where something went wrong. Everything went way too well through the entire movie. Not a single character offed, no unexpected mistakes made by the police, no plot-twists (if it can even be said to have one in the first place).

The "plot" follows an officer who decides to help out some people catch this cartel guy who is bombing places. She is left in the dark about everything, which could have been good if we actually knew anything. After all the shooting and proving that she doesn't know what she's doing in this corrupt place, it becomes a revenge story for the last fifth of the movie. After the "Revenge Guy" unsurprisingly kills off the "Cartel Guy"s family, the movie ends with solidifying how much of an ass all the other characters are to Kate and showing that she will just willingly take everything up the ass, like the rest of the film. No development, it didn't even feel like something changed by the end of the film, nothing felt different.

All I have to say about the good in this, is that the acting was good for what they had, the choice of audio was great, and they didn't rely on flashy action scenes when there was action. Maybe most people could self-insert themselves as Kate because the shock factor of having decapitated people and dead children did them in, but it's not that shocking. I saw this and thought, "Ok, just another day of brutal criminal activity in Mexico". It's not that different to the stuff that drowns throughout the news every day. This movie is relying too much on us for a reaction.

Overall, the characters are boring, the story is left a mystery as to what the point is, the acting is good but what it was used for was not, the effects and audio were great, and the mexican kid at the end was neither sad nor completely oblivious to the fact that his father is dead, which leaves the scene pretty pointless. If the point of this film was to show how big of a problem the cartel is, the entire story should have been surrounding how much Kate was against it and not waver from that. But in the end, she's just a wuss who just accepts the shit and doesn't really make the people watching it think that it is more than just another crime film.
While the screenwriter seems more interested in the wrong characters, all that is an afterthought when compared to the performances, atmosphere, and breathtaking cinematography.

Denis Villeneuve has made two amazing films in the past few years. Prisoners and Enemy were both on my top ten list for both 2013 and 2014. Sicario, is another fantastic accomplishment from Mr. Villeneuve. Sicario looks beautiful on the big screen and has an amazing, Oscar-worthy performance from Benicio Del Toro. This film is intense, shocking, and unpredictable. I had no clue what was going to happen. Each scene has a sense of dread, which, in this case, is a good thing, because it added to the suspense. Sicario is also beautifully shot by Roger Deakins. Sicario was ALMOST a masterpiece. But, then there's that one itsy-bitsy little flaw that keeps it from reaching that kind of status. And that flaw is our main heroine. Now, Emily Blunt gives a terrific performance, but, the character is just very irritating. She is constantly questioning and not following orders and it just really doesn't work. You can't connect with her. But, other than that, I had no problems with this film. Sicario is one of the best films of the year. I can't wait to see what Denis Villeneuve does with the new Blade Runner film.

Buttressed by competent performances all around, "Sicario" is most successful when it constructs tightly-wound action/suspense sequences and allows them to go their merry way.

Where it falls short is in its didactic attempt to address Important Issues. In this it is much like director Denis Villeneuve's previous film "Prisoners", which presented the post-Iraq world with Dick Cheney's torture dilemma; namely, if faced with a "ticking clock" scenario, is it ethically permissible to use whatever means necessary (torture) to beat the clock (terrorist attack, but in "Prisoners", a hostage scenario)? We the viewers are led to believe that this is an impossible, "Sophie's Choice"-type decision. But this is a nonsensical dilemma, as it is founded on false premises, namely, that torture is a reliable method for gathering accurate, "actionable" information. 

Similarly, "Sicario" presents its audience with quite a predicament: either we act outside the law (violating Mexico's sovereignty, torturing prisoners, assassinating cartel members on behalf of other cartels, using CIA operatives in domestic operations, etc), or else the flow of drugs across America's southern border will be unhindered! Left unanswered (or unasked, really) is the rather pertinent question "Why would that be a bad thing, exactly?" If "Sicario" weren't attempting to apply "Zero Dark Thirty" [sic] reasoning to the contemporary Mexican Drug Wars, one wouldn't think twice about the omission. But alas it does, and one does. "Sicario" nails its action/thriller/suspense aspects, but it's not nearly thoughtful enough (in contrast to, say, Soderbergh's "Traffic") to get away with lecturing any viewer with a functioning cerebellum.

This was definitely not 93% and 8.1/10 in my book. I give it a 70/100 and no more. We've seen all of this before, so it is not fresh and/or new. Emily Blunt reminded me of Sansa Stark, always emotional and sad, which she does fine, but her performance did not stand out from what one would expect in this role. Del Toro and Brolin gave better performances but they had more interesting characters. The movie was "mumbly" as well. In real life, we do not enunciate every sentence to make sure it is spoken clearly and easily understood. So, in that way it is realistic, but you also may miss a few lines. BBC's Sherlock also does this to my annoyance. The pacing was agonizingly, glacially slow. If you take a five star movie and add 15 minutes of non-essential material, it will lose a star. They advertised it as a thriller, but it dragged so much I stopped caring what was going to happen to anyone, and was yawning way more than I wanted to. Like The Hobbit, it would have been much better if it was edited more tightly. What also was annoying was the film focussed so much on the Emily Blunt character, but the real story is about the Del Toro character, which made the storytelling uneven. I was disappointed and I do not see what the critics or the 28K users who really liked it see.

In a world full of stories bursting with unnecessary details and pointless embellishments, it's nice to see a truly gripping story that doesn't waste any details and uses each character to advance the plot.

Director Denis Villeneuve is quickly becoming Canada's David Fincher in some ways, or in other ways, a relative to the Coen Brothers. That all being said, this was my least favorite of Villeneuve's films so far that I've seen of 3 (this, Prisoners, and Enemy). Comparisons aside this was easily one of the years best films and Villeneuve may very well get his first oscar nomination for this one or at least some of the cast at hand here. Especially Emily Blunt who has never been better than she is here. The atmosphere and everything about this film was quite unpredictable and you really never know what is going to happen. There is shock value here and realism that may turn off some viewers but all in all it's an incredibly rewarding experience for film lovers. This is one not to be missed but also not one for the faint of heart.

Drug movies have always been films of real intrigue for me. I don't know why but I just really get fascinated by how a drug system works or just a character or organizations stuggle in the midst of that dangerous world. Sicario is a brutal no holds barred picture that tackles the drug cartel in mexico but looks even deeper into  human psychology, motives and desires, and just shows a war on two fronts if you will. Emily Blunt, Benecio Del Toro and Josh Brolin lead in this impactful story directed by the man behind the Sinster prisoners flick Denis Villenueve. 
	Kate Macer is an Idealistic FBI Agent who is good at what she does. She is a woman agent in an intense and highly dangerous environment. She gets word that she will be placed on a special task force to find a drug kingpin who is elusive, and has been killing and selling drugs for the longest time. She meets Matt Garver and the mysterious Alejandro. As the film progresses and she goes into the field she witnesses that something fishy is going on and that the guys are going beyond the required jurisdiction.
This was just Gritty real and straight up hardcore. It's a film that challenges morality and what could very well shake your moral code. Nice directing from denies villeneuve his style from prisoners carries over here. Sound editing was superb here veeeery real
 Emily Blunt did a really good job here. Kate represents hope and a very idealized kind of individual almost the ideal FBI agent. Only problem I had was with her character development I kinda wished she was a bit stronger of a female character I mean I was kinda hoping she was more like linda Hamilton here and I was hoping she could be more mentally tough because she got broken down on both fronts for a good chunk of the film and it kinda disappointed me a bit but not to much she still did a very good acting job here. 
Josh Brolin did a fine job but the real highlight even beyond blunt is Benecio Del Toro. By the end of the film I came to reeeeally love Benecio del toro's anti hero character alejandro. He lost so much and in such a brutal fashion. He almost is like mirror to kate as they seem to have once been the same kind of person despite working different professions at the time. Del toro portrays such a cold character who has thrown his own morality out the window and is honed in on achieving his goal. He is like a wolf with rabbies that just needs to be pointed in the right direction. Wonder who would win in a fight whitey bulger or alejandro?
Despite the Emily blunt deal the writing was real neat it sort of a film that builds in excitement and intrigue. Lot of reaaly good shots cinematography wise. Great score too.

'Sicario' Misses the Target

'Sicario' is a U.S./Mexico border drama about...well...I'm not sure what it's about, and that's the main problem with the film. It lack coherence and focus. 

The film starts off centered on F.B.I. Agent Kate Macer and her desire for revenge. Then it becomes a film about the questionable morals of federal policing agencies on the border. Then it mutates into a revenge film about a completely different character. That might work if the plot was not so logically flawed. It might also work if we had more of a back-story on the characters. 

In one scene, Agent Macer takes home a Phoenix cop. It's clearly a set up, and we are expected to believe a trained F.B.I. agent would fall for such an obvious ploy. There is nothing to suggest that she is easily fooled or that the people behind it are that clever. Besides, the plan relies on coincidence and there is no guarantee that it would work. It is based on stereotypical notions of female weakness and illogic and clashes with the notion that Macer is a tough agent. If we knew she had made mistakes of judgement in the past, it might have been more credible. However, almost no backstory is provided for her character. 

Macer is a patsy, which is fine, but then why make her the main character? And if she is the main character, why move away from her entirely during a large portion of the film? It is because the film, for all its pretense at making a smart, complex drama is plot driven and the characters are secondary. Thus, the actions that the plot dictates don't make sense for who the characters are. 

Visually, the film looks flat. Certainly, part of that is because of the filming in low-light situations. I wonder if it is also because some of it was filmed in HD video, or was it?  The music is good, meaning, I didn't notice it. What holds this film together at all is the acting. Brolin, Blunt and Del Toro are as good a trio of actors as you can find in film, and they deliver. Too bad none of them are let off the reins so we can appreciate their talents. 

Critics are fond of discussing the film they wanted to see and then slamming films for not satisfying their preconceptions. So, here it goes. The film needed to focus on either agent Macer or Alejandro (Del Toro) and complete their tale of revenge. Neither of these characters' actions are clever and in fact, they are quite predictable. Good thing the drug lords are easily duped and overpowered.  

Rating: Rent it.

There is no reason to see this in the theater, except perhaps the beautiful overhead shots of the border between El Paso and Juarez. The film attempts to address large themes of betrayal, honor, corruption and revenged, but it misses the target.

If Steven Soderbergh's "Traffic" (2000) narrate the illegal drug trade from multiple points of view, then Denis Villeneuve's "Sicario" deliver you to the frontline of the US-involved Mexican drug war - tensely, grippingly and violently. Arguably one of the year's best flicks - and of course, Benicio del Toro is a true "sicario".

Can we get Denis Villeneuve to direct everything. He is definitely one of today's best directors, and he has yet to disappoint us. Sicario is another fantastic movie, while not as fantastic as Prisoners and Enemy. Emily Blunt is great, Josh Brolin is really good, and Benicio Del Toro is phenomenal. This movie starts out super intense, and you learn early on that Roger Deakin's cinematography is going to dominate the screen. After a crazy highway scene, the movie slows down and kinda bored me for a good 10 minutes. However, it picks back up and keeps my attention all the way through its fantastic second half. The last 20 minutes is some of the most intense directing I have seen all year, featuring one of the best endings of the year. Overall, Sicario is another great thriller from Denis Villeneuve, despite it's slow middle section. It ranks as a highlight of 2015. 9.25/10

Sicario is probably the most engrossing film I've seen from last year. It deals with morality, drug cartels in Mexico (specifically in Juarez, at the height of violence in 2010, not a mirror of it now) along with the conceptual theme of rape. Which is probably why it also made me feel extremely uncomfortable at the same time. The Taylor Sheridan penned screenplay with this subject matter as a theme, direction work of director Denis Villeneuve, and Johann Johannson's deservedly Oscar Nominated score add to the movie's brilliance (and why it is one of my Top Movies from 2015, at the moment).

Guess I've been spoiled by Breaking Bad, which actually shows you the intricacies of the real "underground" workings of a drug cartel world.) just when they get to the part where the prisoner gets tortured.. Bel Toro just stands there on top doing "no-thing"!! There's a lot of hurry up lets go here and let's go there... Rushing around in cars and jets. Big woop. Emily Blunt's character is so blah-zay about it all ... That it leads us to not care either.

Sicario is a slow burning film that rewards the audience's patience with a whopper of a finish and a curt philosophical message that cuts to the core of this drug land thriller.  There are no easy answers at the end of this film, only hard truths.  On the one hand we want to combat cartel violence and curb the import of drugs into the country, but how do we maintain stability when socio-economic realities dictate that many will try to fill that void?  When there are no perfect outcomes, we value order over chaos, and as long as there is a 20% drug usage rate among U.S. citizens there will always be a need for someone to maintain that order.

Director Denis Velleneuve brings us his latest thriller with the new film Sicario, an extremely well made film that boasts a great story with even greater performances. The last time we saw Vellenueve have a major release was in 2012?s Prisoners which took us to new depths of a kidnapping investigation and here he does it again with a very layered look at the cartels in Mexico. There are a lot of things that make this movie work but here there is a tag team of greatness between the writer Taylor Sheridan and Denis Vellenueve. Sheridan's writing here is beyond superb as we follow FBI agent Kate Macer who is asked to join a task force that delves deep in Juarez, Mexico as they attempt to take down a major cartel. However not everything is as it seems when a mysterious member of the team, named Alejandro, has an unusual influence over the investigation and Macer dives deeper and deeper into this world. This story has very deep layers of mystery and intrigue that dive into the very foundation of Macer and Alejandro and you just can't help but get caught up in how complex and meaningful these character's actions are and the dialogue actually serves a purpose rather than just having characters spout of lines of random dialogue. Vellenueve's direction of this film takes center stage and takes this fantastic script and shows us how violent these cartels are as well as how intimate these characters can be when dealing with these horrific realities. There is a sense of suspense that never falters and makes the more intense scenes more exciting as well as powerful. His eye for the sense of setting here is even more impressive with each scene being filled with the perfect amount of atmosphere that really makes us feel as if we are in Juarez while these events are taking place. The cast here is absolutely phenomenal with Emily Blunt as Kate Macer. Her delivery in this movie is nothing short of masterful and as the film progresses we get invested in her and we truly learn to understand her. We also get to see Josh Brolin deliver as the team coordinator and Victor Garber does great as Macer's boss at the FBI. However the real standout here is Benicio Del Toro as Alejandro. Del Toro gives one of his best performances to date here as his screen presence just makes scenes both suspenseful and exciting. His portrayal as Alejandro is so complex and deep that we hang on to every action he makes as well as every word he utters. Simply, Del Toro steals the show. While all these things are beyond great there is an issue that holds back the film and that is in the pacing. Some of these scenes really drag at times and the plot becomes a bit convoluted at times/ There are some points that could have been shorter or cut all together, but as it is Sicario is still a phenomenal film. This movie tells a truly deep story that is filled to the brim with realism as well as great character moments where we identify with nearly everyone in this film. Sheridan's script is amazing and Vellenueve's eye for filmmaking is second to none with this movie. I highly recommend this film, there are some pacing issues but they are made up for with the great cast and great characters. Sicario is simply a movie you have to see.

In Hollywood's Mexican drug war answer to the Steven Spielberg war epic Munich, the chance to castigate evildoers responsible for unspeakable atrocities yields for its idealistic main character an opaque path paved with deception, chaos and disregard for protocol. Emily Blunt is devastatingly magnificent as incorruptible, perhaps quixotic FBI agent Kate Macy. Not even a best actress Oscar nod would do her tortured performance justice. Take your opinion of her previous best work and multiply that by a million. Blunt scores with vulnerability in a harrowing, soul-crushing and impossible situation. However, even the esteemed actress cannot outshine a riveting, distressing turn by Benicio Del Toro. The truth of his character unravels inch by inch until the climax when he is terrifyingly naked with nothing else to lose. If he does not at least garner a best supporting actor nomination, you should boycott the Academy Awards. Josh Brolin also merits a mention for some superb acting. The gore is grotesque and the depiction of extremist cartel violence vomit inducing. If you want a feel good fall story, stay the bleep away from this film, which packs gut punch after gut punch with no apologies. Sicario leaves a haunting aftertaste that may linger forever.

I understand the praise this film has received up to a point. It's a very well-made and well-acted film, stylish and suspenseful and timely in a way that would suggest the possibility of valid insights into the dealings of the cartels in Mexico - the fact that it fails to deliver on that final point is the issue here.

I don't have a problem with the construction of this film at all; the substance is what's objectionable, a fundamentally misguided defense of unethical, illegal, and hyper-masculine actions in dealing with the cartels while simultaneously ignoring the larger context that would nullify this defense entirely. American domestic policy regarding the prohibition of drugs contributes significantly to the prevalence and pervasiveness of these cartels, creating an illegal system that allows these drug networks to thrive. The fact that the film condescends to those who it would perceive as being "weak" for not wanting to engage in the actions it portrays as necessary evils is baffling and supremely ignorant.

America is not the hero this film makes it out to be, one willing to get down and dirty in order to solve problems that idealists like Blunt's character can't handle (the fact that they've provided the moralistic, "weak" role the the film's only woman is a disappointingly sexist misstep); we are actively contributing to the problems that plague Mexican citizens, and people like Brolin's despicable character are not "strong" realists for engaging in their morally dubious actions while ignoring the larger picture. This fundamental problem seriously hinders what could've been an excellent political thriller, and its portrayal of torture as well as an indefensible rape joke thrown in among this misguided narrative only contributes to the bad aftertaste it all leaves in your mouth.

Villeneuve seems to have a serious conservative streak in him (Prisoners had similar issues with attempting to justify illegal, despicable violence by simply pointing to the existence of evil), and its holding him back from creating something truly great. His technical prowess is undeniable; if only his ideology wasn't so retrograde.

Blunt plays a taking-no-shit government operative called on to assist an investigation to nail a drug lord. She our doppelganger, our stand-in, who ushers us in into the horror of real life, the horror that horror is necessary. Once we are assured of her street worthiness and credibility - and she's plenty badass - we are then introduced to the real star of the film and the subject of its focus. The movies and their audiences (hey, that's us!) love the Myth Of The Double O's: sauve, debonair, lady killers who can handle themselves in a fight, in a car chase, in other countries, in other languages, with any weapon. Center stage in every scene. "Bond. James Bond." But what might such individuals be like in the real world, not in the movies, but in the world we live in and know? When we meet Del Toro as the secret agent he is most noticeable for his deliberate efforts not to be noticed. "I'm just sitting here. I'm just a regular joe. I'm just like you. Don't look at me." By the film's end we know that this MF is the MF other MFs have nightmares about, and if you notice him, if he is center stage then its already too late for you. A really good film, and with my highest recommendation: worth more than one viewing.

Movie Love! #Sicario

On Sunday the 11th of October 2015 at 11.55 AMC cinema Manchester I embarked on what was to be an epic and intense journey. That journey was called Sicario!

Sicario staring Emily Blunt, Josh Brolin and the immense Benicio Del Toro has easily made it into my top 10 films since the start of 2000. 

There are so many reasons why i think this but I refuse to name them all as i lack the imagination and English skills to do them any justice. But what I will say is from the Acting (everyone) stunning cinematography, musical score that builds the tension so much I could almost hear my arse tightening up! And also the plot and brutal story of the Mexican cartel gang world that just grips you by the throat, squeezes every ounce of air from your body and occasionally lets you breath gasps of air once each scene ends. 

This film was very much like my sex life, lasted around the 2 hour mark and yet felt like I had sat down, BLINKED, then I was told to leave. But with a great feeling that I have just been involved in something epic yet brutal.

Ps. Even after seeing mutilated bodies, drug lords and corrupt police officers I still want to visit Mexico and eat there food.

Very dark and gritty take on Mexican drug cartels. The is a little long overall, but it's very tense and you're never sure what exactly is happening until the end. Emily Blunt, Josh Brolin and Benicio del Toro are all excellent. Well worth a watch if you enjoy darker less black and white films.

Sicario is a grim tale of crime and murder that pulls no punches in the violence department and is bar none the most beautiful, dark-themed movie I've ever seen courtesy of the brilliant cinematographer, Roger Deakins. The acting is incredible with stellar work from Josh Brolin and powerful performances from Emily Blunt and Benicio Del Toro; the latter completely stealing the movie with his uncertain alliances and solemn demeanor. The film is helmed by mastermind director, Denis Villeneuve who gets right to the grit in the opening scene and sets the tone early that this is going to be a bumpy ride and it's beyond impressive. However, after the spellbinding first act that was non-stop tension, I found the story slowed way down and took a little bit too long to pick up again as what was happening in between wasn't all that interesting. I also take issue with the eventual reveal about Blunt's character who you realize didn't matter at all in the grand scheme of the plot and she's actually absent for most of the climax; which annoyed me as she was being built-up so well to be an amazing character. The climax is insanely well-done though beginning with a Zero Dark Thirty-esque night-vision raid that keeps escalating until Del Toro's character, Alejandro takes matters into his own hands and does what it takes to bring down the villains. I'm a bit mixed on the impact of the film because I believe the story wasn't all that remarkable, but it's undeniable that I was riveted through most of it, Roger Deakins can make the ugliest of scenes gorgeous, and the performances, especially from Del Toro, will keep you engaged until it's final moment.

Sicario: 9.5/10
This is the best movie to come out of Hollywood in 2015. It's my favourite movie to come out of Hollywood this year, at least.
It's the story of an idealistic FBI Agent Kate Macer (the gorgeous and brilliant Emily Blunt) getting sucked into a dangerous, drug cartel-busting assignment with Matt Graver (Josh Brolin, in what could be one of his career's finest performances) and the ice-cold man-with-a-death-stare Alejandro Gillick (the ever efficient Benicio Del Toro). And it begins on an ominous note, with the message: "Sicario is a word for zealots in ancient Jerusalem, who hunted down and killed Roman invaders. In Mexico, Sicario means hitman."
Giving away any more of the story is a disservice, because Sicario is a film that must be experienced. This is one of those non-sci-fi non-gimmicky films that ACTUALLY deserves to be screened in an IMAX theatre, so you can lose yourself in Roger Deakins' jaw-dropping, trance-inducing cinematography. That, coupled with the chilling, yet calming score of Johann Johannsson, makes this one of the finest cinematographer-music director collaborations, to help with Denis Villeneuve's brilliant direction.
It isn't flawless though. Sicario comes with a not-so-tight script that takes away from the experience. Denis Villeneuve is the man who's given us Incendies, Enemy, Prisoners, Polytechnique and the like. Compared to those, this feels like he's played a little safe with the script. The screenplay slows down in the middle, especially to the point of the intermission. But his direction still makes this an edge-of-the-seat experience. It makes all the slowness feel like a live, ticking bomb.
I also had a problem with Emily Blunt's character, Kate Macer. Throughout the movie I was expecting her to do things differently, and most of the times I was left disappointed. I wondered, 'why isn't she as strong as she can be? Why is Emily Blunt playing such a weak character?' But then, with wisdom from my friend Achyuth Sankar, I realised that Kate Macer is actually a reflection of the human race - given the same circumstances, we would react exactly the same way. And that is what pissed me off more than anything else - that in life, when you're powerless, you truly ARE powerless and there's nothing you can do.
Talking about the human race, there is someone who's not-so-human in our midst. How does Benicio Del Toro do it? How does this man straddle between English and Spanish with so much ease? How does he manage to be so ice-cold, almost Anton Chigurh-like, and yet make you root for him in a weird way? He has all the best lines in the film, especially these:
"Nothing will make sense to your American ears, and you will doubt everything that we do, but in the end you will understand."
"Finding this man is like finding a vaccine."
Moving on to the third important cog in this wheel, Josh Brolin. Right from turning up in the meeting room in flip flops to his wisecracks and quips at Emily Blunt, Brolin has had a ball of a time, and this might be one of his best performances.
Hey, you know what HBO? Cast Josh Brolin and Benicio Del Toro in a season of True Detective. Set it in the heart of Mexico, preferably Juarez. And get Cary Fukunaga to direct, with Roger Deakins as the cinematographer. OH YEAH.
All I'd like to say in the end is, well done Denis Villeneuve, Roger Deakins, Johann Johannsson, Emily Blunt, Benicio Del Toro and Josh Brolin.
Go and watch Sicario people. You should not miss this one in the theatres.
