Blend a bit of Traffic, Training Day and a pinch of Se7en and you're on your way to getting the vibe of this super-slick thriller.

Roger Deakins' cinematography contrasts the scorched, barren landscape of the U.S./Mexico border and the shady, midnight dealings of the FBI to great effect. The atmosphere created continues to ride a murky grey line between the two worlds, highlighting the conflicting attitudes of the central characters portrayed by Blunt and Del Toro.

The war on drugs theme gives you the sense of Soderbergh's Traffic, but the quandary suffered by central character Macy (Blunt) as she is thrust into the slimy world of Matt & Alejandro (Brolin and Del Toro) is very reminiscent of Training Day. There's the great acting of both those films, as well as the superb acting, but Sicario succeeds in having a female character that be considered both weak and strong.

Early on Blunt is shown to be a women just getting by in a man's world - always one step behind, having to ask questions and not quite in a powerful enough position to do anything about it. I thought it an illusion of a strong female character; portrayed to be strong because she's holding a gun, cussing and smoking. However, as the gripping story powered on it became clear that her strength came from still fighting for her ideals against a brick wall of secrecy and dirty deals.

Some of the set pieces are very taut and the whole piece is very well directed. However, I found a few times I predicted quite a few moments that were intended to be shocks. This should in no way take away from screenwriter Taylor Sheridan and director Denis Villeneuve, who have delivered a fine film, that kept my attention throughout, in an time where mediocrity is so easy. 

Benicio Del Toro hasn't been this good in years (with the exception of Che) and Blunt and co. add to the universally great performances.

In the film's opening, a title card explains "In Mexico, Sicario means hit-man", immediately setting a tense tone throughout the film. French-Canadian director Denis Villeneuve (Prisoners, Enemy), working from a dark and dangerous script by Taylor Sheridan, steps into the haunting world of America's war on drugs. The subject matter and this story in particular could have easily turned into a generic, fast-paced and dumbed down Hollywood production, but Villeneuve's execution makes the film stand tall as an exhilarating crime thriller. The film is set on either side of the U.S. - Mexico border, but in this narrative, the border is more conceptual than anything. It is a place of anxiety, violence and moral compass.

Kate Macer (Emily Blunt) is an FBI agent assigned to tracking down kidnapping victims of Mexican drug cartels in the American Southwest. Early on, it is suggested that she volunteer - she can't be officially assigned- for an interagency joint task force. She joins in hopes of making a bigger difference and quickly finds out nothing is as she was told it would be. Matt Graver (Josh Brolin) is a government agent of shadowy provenance, officially an "advisor," yet as a playful provocateur he seems to have vast resources at his disposal and free rein in the field. Alejandro (Benicio Del Toro) is introduced first by Graver as a "bird dog" but reveals himself to be much more than that. Moving freely back and forth between the U.S. and Mexico, the trio are trying to disrupt the flow of money and drugs in hopes of causing higher-ups in the Mexican cartel to make a mistake and reveal themselves.

Villeneuve, who stepped into similar moralities in Prisoners, maintains a masterful balance between the brutal and violent world of the story and deeper ethical ambiguity. The film is shot once again by the legendary cinematographer Roger Deakins (who worked with Villeneuve on Prisoners), and it is absolutely wonderful. The shots are steady and wide with beautiful colour pallets. It gives the film a fantastic sense of the world we are witnessing on the screen, the vicious and cruel world where morality seems to be lost forever. A haunting score by Johann Johannsson heightens the film's ominous mood and gives it a personality. This is the work of someone who has an opinion on this subject, and truly believes in his film which recalls Michael Mann's Heat and Steven Soderberg's Traffic. The pacing is slow and steady but the tension is endless with a smart script that manages to be simple enough to follow and plenty of surprises along the way. The film portrays the so-called war on drugs not as a battle to be won but as an existential minefield, something that changes people with the best of intentions and turns them into monsters. This is both a nail-biting action thriller and a social commentary on a world in which right or wrong have become essentially irrelevant.

The acting is superb across the board with Emily Blunt showcasing one of her best performances to-date. Her character is reactive and underwritten in some aspects, but her performance makes up for this problem. Her character is both emotionally affecting and athletically adept, ultimately becoming the movie's heart and soul in a story where having a moral conscious seems irrelevant. She manages to create some of the film's highlights including the nail-biting opening sequence and a slam-bang action highpoint in her apartment.  Benicio Del Toro is also fantastic as the mysterious Alejandro, who guides the team in their operations. His character is cold and brutal, making some of the tense moments even more watchable. Their chemistry is where this story truly shines because morally, they are polar opposites but they are circumstantially linked to the same world of crime and violence. Among the many things discussed in Sicario is the cyclical nature of violence and how feelings of hope and logic factor into its endless turmoil for better or worse. Alejandro is light years away from the idealism that Kate exhibits and how they try to unravel one another is an absolute joy to watch.


Sicario manages to do pretty much everything it sets up and rarely misses a step. This is a slow but tense thriller full of intriguing characters and scenes that would be remembered for a long time. The top-notch acting, a mesmerizing score and camera work that is surely among the year's very best, all make this a must-see for film lovers. The subject matter is also timely and relevant as an increasing number of Americans have come to realize that the war on drugs has corrupted everyone involved. The film's bleak and nihilistic ending offers no hope that it can ever be won, or that the corruption won't continue to win over. When Kate argues that the strike team's actions are legally out of bounds, a superior sets her straight: "The boundaries have been moved," he says. And will clearly continue to be.

Cops and cartels, midnight raids and public shootouts, blood vendettas and hidden agendas, and a whole lot of dead bodies literally walled up in a house of horrors. If you told me all of this sounds like it belongs in a trashy detective novel, I'd probably agree. If told me it all sounds like it belongs in a trashy movie I'd say, "Hold the phone! Who says the movie has to be trashy?"

And of course, it isn't. French-Canadian director Denis Villeneuve insinuates and executes all of these familiar genre tropes with hitman-like precision in Sicario, delivering one of the most cringe-inducing, butt-clenching, downright excruciating films of the year... And I mean every one of those in the best possible way.

Working from a twisty screenplay by actor-turned-writer Taylor Sheridan (Sons of Anarchy), Villeneuve has crafted an excellent thriller that's every bit as refined (if not more so) as the glossy biopics and period pieces that angle for adult dollars at the multiplex every fall. Along with 2012's Prisoners and last year's Enemy, Sicario further embosses his reputation as a filmmaker capable of elevating even the pulpiest story material with his surgical attention to form and construct.

Emily Blunt headlines as Kate Macer, a straight-laced federal agent caught in a crooked system. Frustrated that her Sisyphean campaign against the drug trade is going nowhere, she eagerly volunteers for a special task force designated to take the fight to the cartels.

Now under the direction of an unnervingly casual Dept. of Defense adviser (Josh Brolin) and his mysterious partner (Benicio Del Toro, quietly intense as ever), Kate can only hold on for dear life as she's thrust onto a whole new battlefield in the war on drugs; One made up of gargantuan, writhing border towns and dark, winding tunnels, where her enemies are hiding in plain sight.

An apt casting call for this highly physical role, Blunt exudes just as strong an action-movie presence as her Full Metal Bitch from Edge of Tomorrow. It's an unfortunate shortcoming that she's written less as an active participant in the story than as an audience surrogate, mostly watching it unfold while dodging bullets.

We are meant to be as nervous and appalled as she is by the unethical back channels and by the blind eyes of her superiors. "You are acting within bounds," insists her FBI boss (Victor Garber). "The boundary has been moved." But as Sicario spirals towards its bloody climax, it seems more and more that the boundary has been completely erased, leaving us to contemplate who are more monstrous; The traffickers or the feds?

Villeneuve is a master of mood, with a penchant for suspense that rivals Hitchcock. His timing of the film's first jump scare instills the viewer with an enduring dread of what sudden horror will startle us next; A dread which allows him to stretch the tension tighter than a drum for prolonged (practically agonizing) periods of time.

Master cinematographer Roger Deakins (probably en route to Oscar nomination #13) composes every frame with grace and grit. His camera shifts elegantly between POV to objective angles, sometimes within the same shot. When coupled with the atmosphere of Tim Ozanich's sound design - which superbly integrates Jóhann Jóhannsson's stealthily scary music - these images put the viewer square in the danger zone with the embattled narcs. You don't merely feel that they are unsafe. You feel unsafe.

It's more than enough to keep us perpetually rapt, even when the script goes sadistically dark. It's true that the morbidities of Sicario may well cross the line for what general audiences would consider "prestige drama", but a director of Villeneuve's caliber proves that great storytelling knows no genre. The boundary has been moved.

The thriller film Sicario, by Dennis Villenueve, had me at the edge of my seat in the opening act. Emily Blunt, who is a lead FBI agent, of the kid-nap response team in Arizona, has discovered an unusual case of kid-naps. Emily is not entirely sure what is going on after a gross, but sickening discovery of dead bodies found in the walls of an Arizona home. With confusion and anger, after a bomb explosion that lead to two agents dead, left Emily anxious for answers on who was responsible for so many murders.   
Josh Brolin, a drug enforcement chief recruits Emily for her outstanding experience in the field. She is misled and confused on what her actual position is with the narcotics team. She elaborates that she is a specialty in the field of abduction. But, with her shaky vibe of the recent discovery of over 20 dead bodies; she is determined to catch those responsible of those who caused the explosion and the death of two fellow co-workers. 
She meets with Benicio Del Toro, on a private jet provided by the agency, just some of the perks for working with the big guys. But, Benicio remains mysterious throughout the film. She is misled by thinking she is working on a case in El Paso, Texas. When on the jet, she is somewhat informed that she is actually going to work on a case in Juarez, Mexico. Emily is still confused on the purpose of her position on the case. Josh Brolin, reveals the necessity of Emily working with the drug enforcement team up until the near end of the film.
 Brolin and Del Toro are two sneaky individuals that show no remorse on their actual intensions. Brolin and Del Toro are two individuals that play the game their way. Jurisdiction is not a word in their vocabulary.
 The title of the film Sicario, means hitman in Mexico. It was difficult to make some connection with the title of the film, throughout the movie, up until the end of the film. Sicario had me wondering before the ending, on why the film was named Sicario. I love the structure of the film and the way it had me wondering throughout the film. 
Towards the end it was still unclear on what was behind Brolin's motive. Del Toro was later revealed as a character that explained the title of the film. Brolin was still a mysterious shot caller that never actually revealed himself and the reason for why he was willing to work with Del Toro. 
It would be nice if there was some clarity on who Brolin really is. I can say, the story line was clear and interesting. Emily's performance was utterly compelling; she played a victim in some sense, but was a scared agent overall. There is no error in the story line, but this film had a trailer focused on action. Sicario, was a film more on the suspenseful side with little action to relate to its trailer.

Sicario is a Spanish term for hitman. This was introduced to the audience at the beginning of the movie. The movie focuses on Kate, an FBI agent who volunteered herself to capture the people in charge of operating drug cartels in Mexico. As they arrived in El Juarez, Mexico, the agents faced reality of how drug traffickers took over the land. Dead bodies were hung by rope over a bridge and gangsters drove through the streets to patrol the area. The agents knew that they needed to act quickly in order to clean up the mess. 
	"Sicario" was a suspenseful movie where the director, Denis Villeneuve, did a wonderful job on tackling the relationship between the movie and reality. Portrayed by actress Emily Blunt, Kate joined a mission without knowledge of what was going on around her. She came from a background where she learned to be on top of every mission and knew exactly what happened in her surroundings. However, Kate struggled to follow the assignments given to her because she was not aware of the specifications of her duty and new endeavors to overcome. Higher authorities were often bribed to run deliveries, protect dealers, and hint information to cartel members.
	Denis Villeneuve attempted to portray accurate the views on state police members. When a dealer went through the tunnel and needed a ride, a state policeman was usually the one that gave him a ride. The corrupted officials often gave cartel members information on what was going on around the states. If any whistleblowers were to be caught, the cartel members would send people after their family. 
	This movie brought out the best in all the actors and actresses. From an audience member's point of view, each cast member acted out their roles perfectly. Cast members were able to depict their characters' lives, allowing the audience to truly understand the lifestyle in the movie. In addition, the cinematography captured every aspect of El Juarez to the smallest details.
	I did have a critique about the movie. If there were to be a change in the movie, I would suggest to add or remove the bar scene. Kate and her friend, Reggie, ran into one of Reggie's ex-coworker at the bar, who happens to be a state policeman. Kate decided to casually date him. Unfortunately, he ended up working for the cartel in which he tried to kill her when she found out. What I did not like about this scene was how it was a coincident for both Kate and the officer to hook up, as he ended up being a corrupted officer. Realistically, a good friend would not intentionally introduce someone to an individual that would cause harm. If Reggie were to invite him out on a separate occasion, this would have been a better scene than just running into each other at a specific bar.
	Overall, "Sicario" was wonderfully directed; I was captivated throughout the whole movie. It was full of suspense and never had a dull moment. Denis Villeneuve invoked emotion with each scene and connected it with real life situations. This movie was an eye opener to the audience because most people never understood how corrupted the state officials can be. Working within a cartel will never end well; members will either shoot or get shot at. With a movie this realistic, people will now understand the war against drug cartels.

Sicario: Everything about this taut thriller is on point - an intense, gritty story about an idealist FBI agent (Emily Blunt) fighting the Mexican drug cartels; outstanding acting across the board; and a bleak setting gripped by cutthroat brutally. While it isn't the first movie about the failed war on drug trafficking, Sicario captures it in a way that is brutal, morally conflicting and unforgettable. A+

Killing audiences like its Spanish namesake, tightly coiled thriller Sicario might be topical by proxy but boasts a white hot Who-Done-What at its red hot center. If Master of Suspense Alfred Hitchcock made a Mexican terrorism actioner, it would look a lot like this. Call it Crosstown Traffic, Steven Soderbergh's already timely drug drama made even timelier by an escalating narcotics war down south and framed with direction that's every bit as knowing and edgy. Though the set pieces stop your heart, your mind can't help but keep going at a feverish pace, always on the lookout for the next double cross or stray bullet. It constricts you from the get-go for a long con but Sicario's serpentine scheme never disappoints. 

In this R-rated thriller from director, an idealistic FBI agent (Blunt) gets enlisted by an elected government task force to aid in the escalating war against drugs along the U.S. and Mexico borders. 

Through the eyes of the sometimes naive but rarely helpless agent Kate (an ace and award-worthy performance by Emily Blunt), Taylor Sheridan's script pits filmgoers in the midst of a deadly war that oftentimes seems pointless but the drive of the characters keeps you fully bullet-proof vested. Josh Brolin and Benicio del Toro likewise give powerhouse performances, though the latter is inarguably the showier of the two. Denis Villenueve's taut atmospheric direction takes center stage, however. The Prisoners' helmer makes a Hitchcockian thriller without a Hitch. It's his own baby, killer turns and all. 

Bottom line: Wonder Drug

An idealistic FBI agent is enlisted by an elected government task force to aid in the escalating war against drugs at the border area between the U.S. and Mexico.

Sicario is another well crafted, tense thriller from director Denis Villeneuve, scripted by 'Sons of Anarchy' writer Taylor Sheridan, and shot beautifully by none other than Roger Deakins. It drags you, face first, into the raging drug war between US forces and Mexican cartels. South of the border, we see a house raid that uncovers dead bodies decaying behind walls. An explosion results in the deaths of several men belonging to Emily Blunt's team. It puts her on a mission to draw out one of the major drug lords responsible, with U.S. forces led by Josh Brolin, cooperating alongside the silent and mysterious Benicio del Toro.

Once into Juarez, Mexico, we see a disturbing scene of mutilated corpses hanging in the street. This is part of a 15 to 20 minute scene of pure tension that grips you from start to finish. Steady photography follows a police convoy through the streets and traffic. Ariel shots glide over the city and dry landscape. A haunting score with it's ominous deep rumbling is present throughout. The scene ends with a brutal shootout on a border crossing. It's the beginning of Blunt's journey into a mission that blurs the line between crime and justice.

The cast are all on top of their game. Emily Blunt has starred in a variety of roles in different genres, and here we see her tough yet vulnerable, a believer in justice and going by the book. Benicio del Toro becomes more important as the story progresses, his motivations unclear until the end, a frightening figure with a hunger for revenge. Josh Brolin is also great, a shady task force leader who knows everything about the brutal world he operates in. My one complaint was the little time given to the the drug lords who are only introduced towards the end.

With a runtime of two hours, the film never out stays it's welcome. The tone is consistent and rarely strays from the tense and grim style, with spots of humour here and there. The pace of the film ticks along nicely without over explaining or rushing important scenes. Again, the score by Johann Johannsson is fantastic with low rumblings that build into a wall of noise. 

Suspenseful, compelling and sophisticated on it's own terms, Sicario mostly side steps mainstream predictable expectations, and it's all the better for it.

"Don't ever point a gun at me again".

'Sicario' is a master-class in ramping up the tension. It's right up there with the best of them. Tense, twitchy scenes fit perfectly into the drug war story. Where something like 'Sabotage' failed (quite badly) 'Sicario' does it with ease. All film makers going for a similar plot with teh cartel, drugs DEA whatever link there is should look at this. Building the tension up, slowly twisting the screw and never really letting up completely - even when it comes to teh conclusion it still has you.

As many adverts have stated 'Sicario' means hitman in Mexico. Meaning the real central character is 'Alejandro' (Benicio Del Toro) but it's lead through the eyes of 'Kate' (Emily Blunt). Displaying her skills in the opening segment (which already starts to raise things) she tackles what is meant to be a kidnap operation only to discover more and be inducted into a special operation to take out the head of the Mexican cartel - headed by 'Matt' (Josh Brolin). By the end it's hard to judge what is the right thing to do and who is doing it. It's intentionally murky with its perception of good - there's revenge, pride and manipulation at every turn.

It's clichéd but the audience and 'Kate' know as much as each other. Her reaction to things synced pretty well with me, she may be part of the FBI but this is new territory for her. It's never clear what they're doing until it's already done. There's as much mystery about 'Matt' and his team as there is 'Alejandro' and his objectives. This could be tiresome and uninteresting but the intrigue and rising tension kept me glued to the film.

There's also what has to be the best use of night vision iv'e ever scene and one of if not the most tense thing Iv'e ever seen on screen. Watch out for that because it blows 'Zero Dark Thirty' out of the water. Despite all the sides involved, drug empires and secret government ops there isn't all that much action and it's all teh better for it. If you're expecting something with explosive set pieces you won't get them here. It's rather, littered with more intricate constructed moments.

Upping his game from 'Prisoners' 'Denis Villeneuve' has mastered his art. Where teh previous had some problems 'Sicario' never ever lets up the feeling of un-ease. Managing thanks to some clever camera work keep at a level even when there's nothing happening. 'Emily Blunt', 'Benicio Del Toro' and 'Josh Brolin' are all in excellent form here. Intense, startling and unflinchingly committed to being fair on all fronts, 'Sicario' is that rare thriller - very smart and very very good.

Sicario is without doubt the best film of the year beating the likes of Mad Max: Fury Road, Kingsman and Legend, and it ranks as one of my favourite films ever made. Emily Blunt and Josh Brolin give terrific performances with Blunt's character being the rookie by the book officer who's in way over her head and Blunt gives us something great to watch. The same can be said for Brolin's hard edged but very laid back character, he too clocks in a wonderful performance. But perhaps the best is Benicio Del Toro who is absolutely incredible, stealing the scene everytime he appears, his character is quiet but harbours something dark and he only reveals his true self until the end in what is one of the most intense shootout in film. The music is loud and brazen and it conveys horror whenever played, it never feels out of place and it fits the subject matter perfectly. And Roger Deakin's cinematography is outstanding, when it's dark it's dark, you can't see the character's faces and even that gives it such a realistic and gritty feel, it's Oscar worthy. Dennis Villeneuve has given us a perfect film, a film that doesn't glamourise or make the war on drugs seem cool, instead, he's offered us the most realistic take on it since Traffic. Everything is Oscar worthy and it's sure to be the most nominated movie this year. Sicario is just mesmerising, I love this film and I can't wait to watch it again.

I believe this is one of the first movies I have seen where the trailers lead you to believe 'action' movie, but instead, Sicario stands out as one of the best ghost stories of the year.

The mood.  The setting.  The characters.  The score.  The cinematography.  The direction.  The dialogue.  Everything about it comes together as more of a horror story than any action movie ever could.  In fact, everything is so tightly wound in every scene, sitting through this for two hours felt like walking through a haunted house.

The entire premise for director Denis Villeneuve, who directed Prison Break and Enemy...both excellent, is to place the audience in the shoes of Emily Blunt's Kate.  Just like her, you as a viewer are completely unaware of what is going on.  Who do you trust?  Who's the bad guy?  It's not only until the final stretch do you really get an idea, not even the whole truth, of what her purpose for being there is.  It's her most stoic performance yet and thrown up with the best of hers like Edge of Tomorrow.

Benicio Del Toro may steal the show, however.  His brooding silence.  His efficiency at his job.  His delivery of both dialogue and mannerisms.  He is the ghost you fear.  The way he and Josh Brolin play off each other leads you to believe its a symbiotic relationship, but quite frankly, there is a point in the film where even Brolin's character says to follow Del Toro's lead without question.  I mean...the movie's title is really about Del Toro's character anyway.  Sicario = hitman.  I've seen Brolin do some good acting before, but here he hammed up the stereotype of government lackey a bit too much with his snarky and loose attitude.

As far as direction goes, the car chase through Juarez must go down as one of the best sequences of the year.  What a brilliant idea to keep not only the pacing of the film consistent, but a chance to get a good drive by of what makes these cartel wars so violent.  There's no lingering for too long for fear you might not make it out alive.

Sicario stayed small in its scope by limiting everything to Arizona and the border around Juarez and El Paso.  It was a great look at how things are handled (though to a certain elevated extent most likely) without having to see Washington DC or the higher powers.  Del Toro and Blunt give masterful performances in one of the best ghost stories of the year.

Sicario comes at a time filled with promising cinematic features and yet manages to keep its head well above water and then waver to the top as one of the definitive films of a rather uneventful year in film so far.  To say the least, enough happens in the film's first tightly acted, edited, and directed 30 minutes to propel the intrigue of its premise and adrenaline of its execution throughout the film despite some uneven pacing.  

When Sicario succeeds, it succeeds at such a level that some of the shallow narrative flaws and minor issues can be pushed to the side.  You can feel the intensity, emotion, and dedication emanating from each scene because it's very easy to tell that this is exactly the project that director Denis Villeneuve has been building towards.  It is a story rooted deep within his own interests and heritage and a story of which he surely felt needed to be told, and he mostly succeeds in emulating his personal sense of urgency and importance unto the audience.  

The most fascinating part of Sicario is that it isn't too heavy-handed in its approach.  It manages to entertain in balanced doses while still finding a way to pass along some vital social commentary that manages to sit uncomfortably with even those of which aren't personally familiar with the events and settings being depicted.  I did take issue with certain aspects of the narrative, however, that I felt to be extraneous and perhaps even unnecessary, and to me these parts really got in the way of the otherwise smooth direction of the film.  I can't mention these narrative aspects specifically, but it should be clear as a good deal of time is given for these detracting subplot elements to unfold in a way that really interfered with my ability to stay focused on the central plot.  And to that end, Sicario doesn't really tell all that profound or unique of a story to begin with, but given the precise, calculated plotting, confident and bare-knuckle direction, and (of course) Roger Deakins' flawlessly detailed and complex cinematic abilities, it's easy to overlook this fact.  

The impeccable performances all around are worth mentioning just as well with a truly defining performance given by Benicio Del Toro who basically gave me the chills through his sheer confidence and obvious passion for the role.  Overall, Sicario marks itself as a notable entryway into the award season for films this year given its highly admirable round of qualities.  It isn't groundbreaking or really even that original but it is told in a way that certainly pins itself as one of the better movies of the year and, for many reasons, stands out as a rather memorable film.  Much more than your average entertainment fare.

With the plethora of popular fiction devoted to the doomed drug war, it's slightly hard to get excited about a movie retreading the same ground as Traffic or similar films in this genre. But Sicario is, for a lack of a better way to express this, pretty fucking great. The plot centers on a female FBI agent specializing in special tactical breach and clear missions who finds herself recruited by a shadowy team of DEA agents planning to go on the offensive against Mexican drug cartels across the border in Juarez. Emily Blunt subtly and emotionally plays this protagonist as she finds herself in over her head and struggling to maintain her moral compass amid the carnage. Josh Brolin plays a slimy CIA agent so easily that perhaps we should worry about what he does with his time when he's not acting. But it is Benicio Del Toro who steals the show. His icy, murderous double assassin acts as a sword of vengeance and a warning about those who fight monsters. Notably there is a dichotomy between the FBI characters who attempt to operate in civilian legal procedure with arrests, investigations, and public transparency, and the DEA/CIA team who are heavily militarized, use direct force, torture liberally, manipulate the criminal underworld, and engage in Special Forces style assaults.

Sicario is a notably beautiful looking film for being so riddled full of grotesque violence and it demands the viewer's attention. While others may find comparisons to Traffic, I personally feel it has more in common with Zero Dark Thirty, in terms of the strong female protagonist, the direction and cinematography, and final night vision fueled spec ops raids. Of course, where Zero Dark had an uplifting, bittersweet ending, Sicario makes a salient point about the failure and futility of the drug war. It's about as on the nose as you can get, but it doesn't prove to be a fatal artistic flaw. The cold, violent nature of this piece may deter some viewers, but the rest are in for a hellish but rewarding and entertaining journey into the heart of darkness.

This movie delves into the harsh realities of what's happening in our world. It explores the reality that we can't fight a war, in which our enemies are willing to do anything to win, without disregarding the moral confines that we are accustomed to. It also brings home the fact that we as a people are inherently selfish. What actions we consider to be business could create an enemy who views it as personal.
Benicio Del Toro is always awesome in every movie. He needs to win an award for this one. This is much better than his performance in Traffic. Emily Blunt plays the easily manipulated FBI agent who is bound to the U.S. laws whose naivete leaves her feeling accomplished and confused when she's introduced into the front lines by Josh Brolin. Brolin plays the enigmatic spook who controls the pawns on the board. Jon Bernthal is funny in this movie because of his brief close up moment in the movie (he is going to be Punisher?).
Narrative throws Emily Blunt's character into the shocking truth the moment the opening scene starts. This has to have been one of my favorite starts to a thriller. We then are introduced to the two other rabbits that pulls us into the carrel rabbit hole.

Has a nice opening 15 minutes and ends fairly well too, but the entire middle here offers very little substance. I can see why some might have really enjoyed this, but I also definitely now know why it was largely passed over in the Oscar nominations.
Great acting throughout.  Action kept you in the edge of your seat!
Hands down the best movie I've seen this year! Edge of your seat the entire time!
Heavy stuff. Benicio Del Toro is sneaky good.

This Dark-Drama-Movie show its tense from the beginning. Thank's to the music-mix and music-editing which makes the movie more intense. It really great movie with unusual point of view and story telling. Screenplay and cinematography of this movie also bring the experience of brutality to the audience.

Sicario is one of the best action thrillers I've seen in some time! I love movies about America and the war on drugs but this takes things to a new level. The plot is written so well and has nothing you'd expect. It makes you feed on every moment til it builds up into chaos. I've always thought Benicio Del Toro was underrated and he proved that he could be a great star in this film. Also there are many great and beautiful aerial shots in this film and the first person views in the action scenes are also great! The darkness of the film and how it progresses also is awesome!

A gritty, boots to the ground thriller with an honest look at the drug world.  One of the best, if not the best, drug trade films I've seen.  I love movies like Scarface and Savages, but Sicario feels so much more realistic without sacrificing the entertainment value.  It's gritty and entertaining at times and deeply unsettling at others.  The opening scene left me thinking to myself "holy shit so this is what I'm in for," but I think it should leave me with that reaction.  My only real gripes with this film are that it sometimes gets a little confusing and character roles and motivations become difficult to follow, but it's never too overwhelming, and it fits with the complicated nature of the world this film is showing.  Let me put it this way, if you like Breaking Bad, and maybe want a peak at that world further south of the border, I think you'll like Sicario.  Personally, I loved it.

This movie reminded me of the canceled early show on FX "The Bridge " which I seriously miss. From the director who brought you the movie "The Prisoner" brings you a crime drama of the drug war. Well casted and well directed throughout not leaving you bored . Strong 4 Stars out of 5

Sicario is a masterwork of filmmaking that gripped me in everything from the performances, direction, writing and action.  Directeor Denis Villeneuve has proven himself once again to be one of the best filmmakers in the business, creating a gorgeous world that I completely immersed myself in.  Its a very gritty and real film that looks absolutely beautiful in a way that you have to see to believe.  Emily Blunt just keeps getting better and better, with her performance here standing out as possibly her best.  Its a very emotional and dark role that she absolutely killed, showing new range in her talents.  Josh Brolin has only convinced me of his acting abilities in the past, but it's always nice to see him give another great performance.  He captures all the subtle characteristics about his character that make him unique, and we always get a feeling he is more than he appears.  Benicio Del Toro is the man who steals the show here, giving his best performance in years.  His dark, ghost-like performance is unnerving and took me completely by surprise.  Unraveling the puzzle of this man was a beautiful little mystery and his performance, and character, were the best in the film.  The writing was fantastic, giving us a great and layered story about the hunt for a cartel kingpin and the lengths these people will go to find him.  It was a great way to present its themes of morality, control, fear and more.  I will admit that sometimes the film could drag, but it was never boring.  Sicario is an excellent film and one of the best of the year, delivering a brilliantly styled and intense thrillers mixed with a fantastic

This movie starts out with a bang and does not let up. It is intense with gun fighting, chase scenes, and deep music to accompany the scenes. This was more gory than I thought but it showed a dark side of the drug war and I was not mad about it. Once you start watching hold on tight and enjoy the next 2 hours.

Sicario is the best film I've seen in theaters in 2015 thus far. Dennis Villeneuve returns once again with a complex, solid drama. This film calls upon a delicate balance between mainstream and art- house cinema, and is sure to hit a sweet spot with fans of either style. Benecio Del Toro knocks it out of the park with a dark performance that is striking in it's understated power. Emily Blunt proves solid as our lead character, who manages to give a fine performance despite having a slightly underdeveloped character. Josh Brolin proves himself great as always too, giving a charismatically unsettling performance. The cinematography in this film is gorgeous with Roger Deakins doing an (as per usual) fantastic job, particularly with his use of lighting in the nighttime scenes of the film. The soundtrack, by composer Jóhann Jóhannsson works well as the glue holding the film together, with perhaps his most haunting soundtrack to date. It cannot be understated, the soundtrack for this film is superb.This is a dark film, with an incredibly consistent tone which successfully evokes unease; haunting in it's elusiveness. Dennis Villeneuve has put forth yet another great film for us all to enjoy.

Powered by frighteningly intense set pieces and powerhouse performances by Emily Blunt and Benecio Del Toro, Sicario may just be the best Hollywood film yet focused on the ongoing war with Mexican drug cartels and the toll taken on those caught in its crossfire. Cleverly incorporating a number of alternative visual techniques to place audiences literally in the thick of some of the most dangerous situations imaginable, it's a harrowing, grisly journey down a rabbit hole of hidden agendas, half-truths, full-on deceptions and hollow rationalizations for levels of violence that are sure to make anyone question the very humanity of its perpetrators. It's a film that's full from beginning to end with a sense of dread, as though no matter how bad things on screen might be at the moment, audiences are only minutes away from it getting much, much worse. Thus, there's simply no possible way of taking your eyes off it, even for a second, once you're drawn in. (Read more: bit.ly/1KSidDx)

A tad 'slow' but gripping enough to keep you interested. I enjoyed it and I recommend it. Acting was spot on. All characters in the movie think and that was amazing. The context, thought and objective of each character was a joy to watch. It is a serious movie and should be watched with that intent.

In essence, Sicario is a haunting study of an unbeatable war and the poison it brings to the emotional and psychological composition of the people it touches. It is evocative, well-shot and magnificently acted out.
Amazing - this is a well made movie and perhaps the best action movie in a long time.

I already heard that Sicario was great. But I never knew it was that great. And I never knew that the scale was that massive. Denis Villeneuve brought up the best in him in this drug-trafficking thriller that full with ambiguity. The scope, the cinematography, the production design, the score, and especially the cast; were massively stunning.

Villeneuve was executing Taylor Sheridan's script (he's the actor from Sons of Anarchy and this was his debut script) with such precision. The blocking for every climax (owh yes, there were so many climax in this one) were immaculate. I especially loved the border ambush that involved thousands of cars and extras, and shot beatifully by veteran Roger Deakins. Jóhann Jóhannsson was giving another soul of this movie with his intense beat. While Joe Walker edited the film seamlessly.

Kudos for Emily Blunt for another strong leading role. And most kudos for Benicio del Toro for being one of the most subtle and ambiguous character in recent years. The subtlety and ambiguity which always been a trademark of Villeneuve's works.

And that was what made Sicario a strong movie with strong characters. It's a heart-thumping, mind-blowing, and intense cinematic experience with a strong execution full of great performances. Sicario surely one of the best and strongest movie I've watched this year. And for that, a deep bow for Villeneuve.
Intensely acted and grippingly directed.

Benicio del Toro carries this film with ruthless efficiency. Brolin brings snarky grit. Blunt  takes a believable turn as the chain smoking ingenue who has no idea of how things get done on the other side of the Rio Grande. Ciudad Juarez is the real star of the film. It looks just the way I remember it, complete with APVs in the streets, and big black SUV convoys zipping around. A must see.
Neat bit of violence and intrigue set around busting Mexican drug cartels by shady American law enforcement... engaging and entertaining...
Richly complex characters, beautifully shot, well acted. A rare film that is able to portray the brutality and nihilism of the war on drugs with emotional warmth.

Top-notch in every way, action, acting, suspense and thought-provoking.

"Sicario" is the true story of a U.S. Intelligence task force that was put together to investigate and sniff out cartel activity in Mexico. Emily Blunt is an F.B.I. Operative who is pulled into the fray by her cunning supervisor Benicio Tel Toro and his lackey played by Josh Brolin. Blunt quickly learns that this task force isn't what it purports to be. Though this film is violen perhaps unnecessarily so at times, I also applaud it for its realism. Mexico is a hostile country where nihilism abounds and its every man for himself. The movie conveys that ideology and shows that not everything in politics can be a pretty picture. Call it senseless if you will, but this film is ambitious and honest enough to accurately portray the dog eat dog world that the cartel run country is. Nothing is held back. Some may disagree but I see this as honest filmmaking and a rarity in modern cinema ------------------------------------------------- B+

Sicario draws a thin line between bad and worse, as it dives into the seedy underground of mexico's drug cartels. the trailers make it seem like they focus on blunt as a main character, but i have to say, the role was split between her and Del Toro, with a greater emphasis on Del Toro. the acting was really spot on, and if you love action films with crazy badass leads, you will love really this film. though i will say, if you can't handle brutality or gore, you might wanna stay away, because there are some messed up scenes in this movie.

Brilliant action-packed thriller about D.E.A agents battling the powerful drug cartels in Mexico will have you on the edge of your seat. The Genius here , the one who really knows what's going on is Alejandro , played by Benicio Del Toro. Is he a Hero? Is he an anti-hero? Is he a villain? We decide or maybe we don't decide. That is the greatness of this film. We just know the drug battles made him what he is. The cinematography is breathlessly good. And the scenes in which they ride in a motorcade through the streets of Juarez like it's a warzone is awesome filmmaking because you really feel like you are a part of it. A stupendous film.

"You are not a wolf. And this is the land of wolves now."

Director Denis Villeneuve has crafted a brilliant thriller that holds nothing back in showing the brutal world of the War on Drugs.

The stunning and beautiful cinematography by Roger Deakins greatly contrasts to the morally gray area the film operates in -- there is no black and white in a drug war that proves no winner, just the lesser of two evils that has left a path of collateral damage.

The score is equally brilliant and Benicio Del Toro gives a memorable Oscar-worthy performance.

10/10 -- 'Sicario' is mesmerizing. Starts with a punch to the chest that doesn't relent til its powerful closing shot. One of the year's best.

Sicario is an accomplished addition to the "war on drugs" sub-genre. Villeneuve's incredibly confident direction creates tension in the quieter moments as well as in the taut action sequences. All the performances are measured and believable. Roger Deakins' cinematography is beautifully crafted as ever and there's a truly menacing score from Johansson. Yet for me somehow Sicario isn't quite the sum of its parts. The story is nothing new. No one's winning the war; there are no good guys; the situation is bleak. Sheridan's script provides scarce little character development, leaving a fantastic cast with shallow archetypes (the morale compass, the evil drug baron, the man out for revenge) who strictly stick to form. There is none of the detailed character study of Traffic here, no real unforeseen twists, everything plays out exactly as you imagine. Despite some fantastic elements, Sicario left me surprisingly unengaged emotionally. As well made as it is, once the predictably bleak final act concludes I was left feeling Sicario had missed an opportunity and really had nothing new to say.
It is ok. It is the bases of the horror stories you hear about on the news about the border. Storyline not original. with out the Music it would have got a 2.

What I Really like about Sicario is what in the end makes me not love it. The third act really makes you question what you just witnessed as a film. Moral dilemmas and a female agent rising in a male dominated testosterone filled Law enforcement agency. Emily Blunt is brilliant in the role and you cheer for the character even when she makes obvious mistakes and at times seems to be hypocritical using her moral compass more like a suggestion box. The third act seems like a different movie and makes the narrative as a whole  seem confusing. Still I highly recommend this film and think that you recommend it to others.

ZFF 2015. 5/5
Sicario. Hitman. A drug cartel related story in the borderland between US and Mexico, CIA, FBI, local police, special forces, and all kinds of things in between. Gang members, dead and alive, smugglers, illegal immigrants, young and old. All in the violent and scary setting where death is never far. Nothing is black and white, it is all various shades of grey (more than 50, I am sure!) where things you thought were wrong are necessary and somehow just right. Emily Blunt has come far from the Devilish assistant and in addition, the film posts talent and eye candy in the form of Benicio del Toro and Josh Brolin.

To note, this director has done other super films, such as Prisoners and Incendies. Both highly recommended, maybe even more than this one. Especially Incendies has stayed in my mind. Not many films do!

On Thursday night I went to see the new film Sicario which opened wide this weekend. I've been anticipating this film since I heard about it. Not only did it look great but it has a stellar cast and a pretty great director. The film stars Emily Blunt, Benicio Del Toro, and Josh Brolin. The director, Denis Villeneuve, directed Prisoners back in 2013 which was one of my favorite films of that year and probably of all time. He also directed Enemy which came out last year and although I didn't love it like Prisoners it was still a film worth seeing and very interesting. Roger Deakins, who has worked on films such as Prisoners, Skyfall, and No Country For Old Men, is the Cinematographer for Sicario and it really shows, giving us many breath taking scenes.

I really can't say how glad I am that Sicario didn't disappoint. I loved this film. It's my favorite film of 2015 so far. The story was interesting and kept you on the edge of your seat the entire 2 hours. The cinematography was breathtaking. The directing was incredible. The acting was award worthy. The score was chilling. If you haven't seen this movie yet you need to go right away. I know a lot of people are seeing The Martian this weekend and while it might be good, Sicario is fucking great.

The three things that stood out the most to me in Sicario was the cinematography, the score, and Benicio Del Toro. The score by Jóhann Jóhannsson was absolutely amazing and definitely added so much to the film. Emily Blunt clearly plays the lead in this film and she is great but the actor/character that steals the show is Del Toro. His character is interesting and demands your attention while he's on screen. If he doesn't get an academy award nomination this year I'll not only be surprised but incredibly upset. Out of the films I've seen so far I would nominate Blunt for Best Actress as well but that could change as I see more movies during award season. Josh Brolin is also in this film and does great in his role.

Very interesting film. I don't know really. it's a bit nuts but crimson peak is still my favorite fall film. though we'll see how SvZ goes. but nuts and for sure worth a watch if you like Emily Blunt or Del Torro and a brutal murder movie. go for it.

Sicario is a great movie that reminds you how fucked up the whole war on drugs and the supporting system around it really are. There really are no good guys and bad guys - everyone is rotten to the core. From the leaders of the cartels to the buyers on the streets, the drug world is nasty, bloody and merciless. 

This movie is a good film that shows the inner workings of the ant-drug enforcement world. It shows how the system is littered with corruption, loopholes, dirty money and dead ends. 

No one wins in this movie. Whether it's the good guys in the FBI trying to do their job or the poor devils caught in the crossfire, everyone ultimately loses. 

This is really an excellent movie and i strongly recommend it to anyone that wants a good time and not end brain-dead.

While marketed as a high octane action thriller, Sicario is a slower suspenseful drama set against the war on drugs. The film shines the light on violence facing border towns on both sides which may or may not be publicized on daily basis. In addition it examines what is necessary to fight and win in this war.  Emily Blunt, Benicio Del Toro, and Josh Brolin give excellent performances respectively. Perhaps more disturbing than the visuals is the score which is the definition of foreboding and truly brings this film to life. This is a must see in theaters.

"You can't handle the truth!" That is the most famous line uttered in the film 'A Few Good Men,' by Jack Nicholson who played Colonel Nathan Jessup. If you asked Colonel Jessup to define the term 'necessary evil' in the context of defense of the United States, 'Sicario 'is the story he'd tell. Easily the best film of 2015 thus far. With tremendous acting by the triumvirate powerhouse cast of Blunt, Del Toro, and Brolin. The action sequences combined with the score, excellent pacing and cinematography, with have you peeling the upholstery off your armchair. Do yourself a favor and go see this movie, 4 stars outta 4

Mark it down now, Benicio Del Toro and Josh Brolin will be nominated for Best Supporting Actor for their roles in Sicario.  This movie is intense, well written, well acted and takes a look at the war on drugs from a different angle.  What makes this thing so good is that you don't get the whole picture until the end, and that's what the main character Emily Blunt is figuring out too.  The musical score is outstanding, and simply adds to the tension.  Del Toro and Brolin are really good and I was at the edge of my seat pretty much the entire movie. Sicario is by far the best film of the year with incredible performances from Emily Blunt and a stirring one from Benicio del Toro. Denis Villenueve is back in the director's chair and is back better than ever with the help of legendary cinematographer Roger Deakins whose visual style for this film is simply stunning and beautiful. All around, Sicario is one of the best if not the best film of the year. It is provocative, jaw-dropping, and massively entertaining. Don't miss this one film geeks, and also Johann Johannsson delivers once again on the score department.

Intense! A two-hour adrenaline rush that will invoke a fight or flight response from most viewers.  This drug cartel story isn't ripped from today's headlines.  No, it's bigger than that.  Much bigger. "Sicario" is an electrifying action thriller that enlightens and educates us on the violent crime that already exists-and operates-inside our southern border.

Emily Blunt ("Edge of Tomorrow") plays a naïve FBI agent and tops off a superb cast that includes Academy Award winner Benicio del Toro ("Traffic", 2000) as a government consultant, and Oscar-nominated Josh Brolin (for 2008's "Milk") as the leader of a U.S. clandestine unit.  The trio meet along the blurred desert border of corruption, deception and hitmen to fight drug lords and a jurisdiction system that still tilts in favor of the criminal minds.

The frustrated Blunt wants to play by the rule of law. Except the only U.S. move left is to flip the game board upside down--creating chaos and noise in a cartel family monopoly.

An astonishing cast and script is bookended by a spectacular music score.  A heart-pounding film experience on the frontlines, where rules get thrown aside without apology or trepidation.  "Sicario" is not about curbing the drug war by the time the credits roll. It's about savvy street smarts and keen instincts necessary in a dangerous environment where nothing is as it appears to be. One of the best films of 2015.

[10/3/15] Oh, boy. Where do I even begin? "Sicario" is a tense thriller that follows Emily Blunt as an FBI agent who volunteers to join, well, umm, we're not really sure and neither is she. Josh Brolin is this chill, laid-back dude who's forming a team with Benicio del Toro's character, but it becomes clear that there's more to both of their characters than what they say. At first, the operation seems simple based on the first 10 minutes: "okay, so these three are after some cartel in Juarez. Big deal." It's not nearly that simple. I'll repeat this again, we don't really know who's working with who and what the legal parameters of their actions are--is Blunt's character working with mercenaries, rogue agents, the DEA, the CIA, a different cartel, and at times, it seems like she's signed up to work alongside all of them. It's not a confusing plot [I'm typing that in case you're thinking, oh, it's one of those 'I'm not following this movie at all' type of films. No, it's just a lot of strings being pulled simultaneously]. "Sicario" touches a lot on the current situation in Mexico--since it's set in the border region--with the drug cartels and the violence, I mean, when you watch this you're literally getting a taste, just a taste, of what's going on down there. Every minute/hour/what have you. Of everyday. And at times, just the film's handling of the content is terrifying, terrifying because in the back of my mind I know that the cartel violence in real life is much worse. And for the people down there, that's their reality. Gunshots, torture, drugs, etc--that's some kid's lullaby to get him/her to sleep. To counter the more graphic content, the film gives us a few scenes where a character's relationship with his son is highlighted (because we find out that the father is delivering drugs). What I liked most about those father-son scenes is that it's a subtle way of saying "not everyone who works with the cartels does so because they're born evil. They're doing that to feed their families," doesn't make it right, sure, but it offers some perspective given the father's occupation. It hints at a greater message, I think, and I don't think the father would be involved at all if circumstances were different. If the country wasn't such a disaster. If his salary were better, etc. And I know I'm going off a tangent, the film is well-directed, it's well-acted, there's a few action scenes that put you right in the freakin' middle of all the chaos--it's great--and even if you're not completely impressed by the movie--"Sicario" definitely gets you thinking about the film and the Drug War in general. Take the fact that we get this really cool scene, sorry SPOILERS, in thermal vision as Brolin, del Toro, and Blunt's team sneaks into Mexico through a tunnel used by the cartels. Now we know that in real life, there IS cooperation between U.S Intelligence and the Mexican Government. Do events like those that unfold in the film happen [U.S forces going into Mexico to take down the cartels, in a way, committing acts of war] in reality? If it did, they'd probably have the approval of the Mexican government anyways. But what about all of that surveillance and technology that we're using on our side and also sending down the Mexicans, how are we not finding these big cartel leaders more easily? Should we even be getting involved, I mean, we already are, but should we be playing such a big role considering Mexico's infamy with corruption and bribery? Those are just some things I'd like to know. Perhaps the most thought-provoking part about the movie happens right at the end. There's a soccer game, we see the kids playing, the moms are there trying to forget about the environment's insanity...and then the gunshots start from a distance. One might say, "wait a minute, I want to see what's going on." The truth is we already saw what we needed to see. It's a giant question mark and it concerns the youth, which in turn, concerns the future. Right now, there are no answers or realistic solutions, and that's kind of how I'd describe "Sicario"--it's a film that makes you ask and ask ...but gives you no answers [per se].

After Prisoners and Enemy in back to back years, two of the more thought provoking films of the past few years, I have been awaiting Denis Villeneuve's next project.  Of course, Emily Blunt is my favorite actress right now, so in my mind the two of them were enough to get Sicario on my most anticipated list for 2015.  I can assure you, the film doesn't letdown.  Sicario is about an FBI agent, played by Blunt, who is brought along by a government task force to help on the border of Mexico and the U.S. as drug cartels rule the area.

One of the most chilling parts about Sicario is its realistic nature.  I had a Zero Dark Thirty vibe in that it doesn't hold back in its brutality.  They both have a brilliant female lead as well, although much different characters by motive.  Blunt is complemented by Benicio Del Toro and Josh Brolin as the main three agents.  Part of the greatness of Sicario is its cast but I think the marketing was a bit misleading.  We are led to believe that Blunt is the central focus of the story, but there is almost as much if not more of Del Toro than anyone else here.  It's both good and bad.  I was looking forward to seeing Blunt as the integral part of the story, but Del Toro was just as good.  

I think the real star of the film is Roger Deakins, the director of photography.  He once again gives an incredibly beautiful looking film through his award winning cinematography.  Even though this film may fail to get any acting nominations or any ofthe other big awards, I think it's safe to say that Deakins is a lock for cinematography.  It's his panning shots of the border along with Jóhann Jóhannsson's score that give the film an eerie and ominous feel.  

It's very difficult to talk about any details without spoiling anything, but I can say that it's a really good movie.  I was reading a review that talked about the intensity of a scene before the intensity really begins, if that makes sense.  It wasn't the gunshots or explosions that gave me chills.  It was the quiet calm scenes before the storm.  It's not the mind bender that Enemy was nor the shocker that was Prisoners, but Sicario is one of the most beautifully shot and well acted films this year.

There are a number of reasons to like Sicario. This movie has amazing cinematography. It puts you in the middle of everything that's going on. At the same time, the movie intentionally keeps you in the dark, putting you in the same company as the lead, Emily Blunt. It gets frustrating, but that's part of the movie. Sicario drew a fine line between very good movie and dud, but comes through toward the end to be a very good movie. This is a solid script and is well directed. It's incredibly violent, but not just for violence's sake. Blunt's character seems a bit too whiny in the beginning, but it ends up being necessary for the movie to work.

For people who have a solid idea of "good vs. evil," Sicario will seem like nothing more than Hollywood entertainment. The fact that there is a middle ground, or more people are on the "evil" side of things that one would think, could cause more people to think about what's going on and may be a catalyst for many a discussion on the reality of America's involvement in the illegal drug trade.

Emily Blunt is an entertaining actress, and Josh Brolin is on top of his game as the casual DoD agent. I firmly believe that Benicio Del Toro should be in every movie made, and he reinforces why in Sicario. 

Sicario is worth spending money on, whether you go to the theater or a rent.

Denis Villeneuve's powerful compelling dark drama about a naive FBI agent named Kate Macer, played brilliantly by Emily Blunt, in a physically demanding turn here that is filled with true grit, she is a real badass in the role. Kate is assigned to a special elite task force led by its leader Matt, played superbly by Josh Brolin, to help in the never ending bloody battles against the insidious Mexican drug cartels, she crosses into Mexico on a clandestine mission into a lawless border area where headless corpses of murdered victims dangle from highway overpasses, with her mysterious mostly silent team companion Alejandro, a special "consultant" with a tragic past, played terrifically by a scene-stealing Benicio Del Toro. Kate will find soon question everything she believes in and her faith will be tested as the operation continues, in a land where anyone is a potential target or perpetrator. To say anymore about this film is to betray its sense of paranoia. Astute direction by Villeneuve, with magnificent pulse-pounding action-set pieces that are brutally intense and memorable. A taut script by Taylor Sheridan, Roger Deakin's ravishing sun-parched cinematography is very impressive, and Johann Johannsson's grandiose haunting score is superb. "Sicario" which means "hitman" in Spanish is a most remarkable motion picture in every sense of the word. Highly Recommended.

Denis Villeneuve is perhaps one of the most exciting directors to come into a more public eye; not that Villeneuve is a new director as he's directed several films already, but his growing popularity is getting him better and better jobs. Villeneuve has now taken on the drug trade of all things and has turned what could've been just a have been a great thriller film and has turned it into something more, he has us question the moralities of law enforcement not so much as a good cop vs bad cop but rather as the one who does it the "right" way and the one who breaks the rules willingly and regularly in order to get better results. Which is right? Which is better? Sicario isn't so much about answering it but portraying both sides and asking us to question what's right, and then threatens you with reality. Emily Blunt's Kate's crisis of morality and personal belief is brought out by Blunt's fantastic work, it's not the kind of performance that gives you grand scenes to quote, but an embodiment of a person and losing yourself to the role. Benicio Del Toro's almost polar opposite Alejandro shows the other side and is brought on by one of the veteran actor's best performances in years. His calm, cold, tactile demeanor and dead eyes convey more to us than even the most wordy of main characters. These two performances rocket Sicario's questions of morality into frame and never let up even at the end it's not entirely clear, but it's left up for the viewer to decide. It's a film that is so beautifully directed and equally haunting in it's content that it creates a brilliant contrast of beautiful horrors that actually could make Sicario one of the best horror films of this year. So utterly disturbing and yet for everything that we are more aware of and think of, it's almost like the film's just scratching the surface but we ourselves have to see how much is under that scratch itself. The result is one of the absolute best films so far this year, simply unmissable, even if it will make your ethics boil and your stomach churn

Sicario is Spanish for hitman. In film lingo that makes it sensational viewing, a gripping and action-packed foray into America's War on Drugs. French-Canadan filmmaker Denis Villeneuve (Incendies, Prisoners), working from a dense, heart-shattering script from Taylor Sheridan, is out to fry your nerves. Mission accomplished.

The film starts off a little opaque and convoluted but hang on. Just follow along with audience surrogate Kate Macer, played by a killer good Emily Blunt. Macer is an FBI field agent and Blunt gives her a tough core that is unforgettable. If Edge of Tomorrow didn't convince you of Blunt's inherent badass-ness, Sicario should.

We first meet Kate in Arizona, raiding a hideout run by a Mexican drug cartel, a house with decomposing corpses stuffed into the walls. Kate is largely unflappable till she's essentially ordered to volunteer for an agency-merging task force that seeks to pit one drug lord against another.

Sound confusing? Just sit back and absorb, basically the same advice Kate gets from operations chief Matt Graver (a stellar, smarmy Josh Brolin), a laid-back man of manipulations clad in sandals who claims to be working a defense contract but in all likelihood is CIA. His associate Alejandro (Benicio Del Toro) is an ex-Mexican-prosecutor-turned-assassin who may have a larger personal agenda. You can basically see it in his intense stare. Oscar-winner Del Toro is tremendous here, giving off a toxic mix of smoldering cool and menace that throws even Kate off her game.

Sicario is all build-up for a stunning climax set in a world where right and wrong, good and bad, are no longer absolutes. As Kate fights to stand her moral ground as the ground beneath her perpetually shifts, Villeneuve expertly stages on gut-wrenching action scene after another, all set to a mirthful, jittery score by Johan Johannsson. All praise as well to cinematographer Roger Deakins whose aerial shots of a white-knuckle border crossing stands in vivid contrast with a tense tunnel chase. It's a visual knockout. But the real miracles of the film are all written on Blunt's expressive face. It's pure poetry and it's dark. You won't know what hit you.

Director Denis Villeneuve is not one to shy away from the darkest aspects of human nature. While far be it from me to call the plot of his films inconsequential, the setting is merely a catalyst to show what humans are capable of when pushed to the brink of their capabilities. He keeps his filmed honed and resolute, with minimal scoring, sparse and economical  characterization, and an unhurried narrative. It worked brilliantly for a movie like Prisoners, but for Sicario, the results are underwhelming. And due to the relaxed delivery of the story, it wasn't until the second act that I realized Sicario wasn't going to deliver on the narratives promises. My frustrations are centered on the screenplay. First time writer Taylor Sheridan made a name for himself as David Hale in Sons of Anarchy, a series which lasted 7 seasons and 95 episodes, so he isn't accustomed to concluding a story in just over two hours. And this is where Sicario falters; The script meanders along the narrative, which puts you in a relaxed mindset, but spontaneous bout of ultra-suspense, and a plot with too many webs to follow puts Sicario at odds with itself. It tries to be too many things; a character study, an expose on drug cartels, a nail-biting thriller, an unhurried arthouse film. The best films in history have been able to have multiple personalities, so this is not impossible, but Taylor Sheridan is too green of a screenwriter to pull it off. As a result, Sicario is decent at many things, but superb at nothing. If by some miracle this review reaches Taylor Sheridan, I have a lesson for him;  A story doesn't need to tie up all (or even any) of its loose ends as long as it has a point. The moral of your story is the driving principle - the lesson an audience takes away once the credits roll and the dust settles. 'Love conquers all', 'Teens often make bad decisions', 'Don't walk across the wood at night.' That kind of thing. Decide on the moral of your story and use it to drive the action. Be aware of the contract between you and your audience. Everything that happens must happen for a reason, and the more of a big deal you make of an event, the bigger the pay off must be.

What are the rules of engagement in fighting the Mexican drug cartels especially if US law enforcement agencies go into foreign territories where they have no jurisdiction; does the end justify any means? Denis Villeneuve's intense new film SICARIO (which means hit man in Spanish) takes us into the tactical underbelly of those cryptic individuals who carry out US policy decisions "from on high",  cloaked in legitimacy, though they are prohibited maneuvers that would be considered illegal in any court of law.

The atmosphere is beautifully filmed - either pale, washed out ochers depicting the long dusty border between US and Mexico, or the rich deep blues and blacks of the evening with night - vision goggles irradiating the world around them into skeletal images. Put a young, female FBI agent into this mix - Emily Blunt as Kate, a dedicated officer, former head of a kidnap-response unit based in Phoenix, who is forced to question all that she has practiced and been taught in the Bureau; her fiercely held personal values are turned upside down by the reality of being recruited into the midst of anti- cartel "warriors" who can behave as dark and dirty as their enemy - the drug lords that  control the populous by murdering and slaughtering men, women and children, stringing up body parts hanging them from electricity wires like abandoned baggage on clothes-lines.

Transporting, manufacturing,  shipping and controlling the wildly lucrative  drug industry necessitates making alliances - everyone is  corruptible from the dealers to the federales  and police on both sides of the border - all partaking of the spoils, while their interior sentiments become ghosts evaporating into the surroundings. "It is not personal" are words that exemplify the cool calculations of those in power whose humanity has been shredded, and who barricade themselves with bodyguards and fancy homes from the brutality that they inflict on nameless people.

Kate and her FBI partner ( a good performance by Daniel Kaluuya) are the two newcomers brought along on a mission that they were not briefed on - so the "fog of war" is indeed literally murky. Everything becomes clear with time, but meanwhile we in the audience are as mystified as the protagonists. We meet a team of hardened DEA operatives with Josh  Brolin as Matt - the wise-cracking, gum chewing leader who is a cipher, offhandedly refusing to respond with a straight answer to any question put before him. Despite his Cheshire-like grin, there is a man beneath the lumbering, impenetrable veneer who is callously determined to fulfill the U.S. government's calculated goals no matter the toll.

Benicio Del Toro is the "star" of SICARO, brilliant as the mercenary Alejandro - a person whose face reveals little, but whose eyes and body language betray a passionate resolve for revenge, and a history of incomparable  pain and suffering at the hands of the drug-lords becoming a person for hire with no longer a "soul" to lose. He is the "enforcer," expert at torture and killing, yet despite his horrific activities, every moment he is on the screen it is filled with his abundant presence and an acute sense of heartache. 


Kate's sojourn from an idealistic FBI agent to an awareness of the brutal realities of the contaminated policies used by the United States to combat the  "drug war" is a bit naive and inconclusive. We sense that she remains a staunch believer in the underlying principle of the "rule of law", but we know all-too-well that she is standing on shaky grounds.

First rate crime thriller thanks to a superb cast & gritty direction by Villeneuve.  The cast gives career best work, with Blunt continuing her streak as one of the best females in action movies while Brolin laid back cynicism hides a ruthless nature.  The standout, though, is Del Toro as Alejandro, a man of few words & all action, coming off as a walking predator.  He's someone who knows what he is and is okay with and is Del Toro's best performance since "Traffic" (in many ways, this is a spiritual sequel to that movie).  Behind the camera, Villeneuve directs Taylor Sheridan's gritty script to near-perfection, keeping the action moving while giving you enough character moments to make you care.  Plus, while not preached outright, there is a nice ant-drug war message in the sense that in order to fight monsters like the drug cartels, you'll have to employ a monster to do so, and if you don't like that, maybe this isn't a war worth fighting.  Overall, one of the best crime thrillers in years and one of the the best movies of 2015.

4.5/5* or 9/10
Have you ever wondered how people like Osama Bin Laden or El Chapo come to power, and become gang lords, and then are killed/arrested at a timely convince. Well Sicario has a theory of all things mentioned above, one may say its a conspiracy theory etc but like they say there is no smoke without a fire.But all withstanding, what I saw on screen felt like a true story, and it was thought provoking. Sicario is a dark, and eerie tale about what happens just a couple miles away from the American border in Mexico. Daily many innocents Mexicans die due to the cartel drug war. And Sicario highlights the cruel killings, and how one needs to combat the drug lords. 

Rarely do you see a film that from the first frame not only does it engage you but it takes you into the nail biting action which is happening on screen.Numerous times I had my heart pounding, and jaw on the ground from action and suspense unfolding on the screen. Simply put Sicario has the best performances, and dialogues I have seen in a film this year. Film of the year? Well its in contention for sure.

Story wise the film talks about the escalating drug war the Cartel are engaging in on American soil. After FBI agent Kate Macer invades a house in Arizona and finds about 40 dead bodies which are collateral from the Cartel drug war, she is recruited by the a government agency to take down the real players of the drug war. This agency is
lead by two men Matt Graver, and Alejandro a columbian man. These two men target Manuel Diaz because he can lead them to the kingpin of the cartel because he is right hand man of the kingpin( Diaz lives in the USA, and fronts as a business man). After arresting Diaz's brother Guillermo on Mexico soil in a operation, he leads them to a tunnel used to transport drugs from Mexico to the US.How this tunnel leads to Manuel, and his boss is what forms the rest of the plot.

Acting wise Benicio Del Toro is just mindblowing good, I thought Johnny Depp for Black Mass was the best performance of the year, but Del Toro gives him a good match. A oscar worthy performance for sure. Josh Brolin is superb. And Emily Blunt is fantastic, she shoulders the film at many junctions.

Its difficult to find any negatives in  Sicario, because even the smallest details have been dealt with beautifully. The films pacing is a bit slow, but the concluding 30-45 are adrenal pumping no stop thrill and action, so that makes up for any pacing issues. Sicario being such a great film has many positives them being the dialouges, espically the ones mouthes by Del Toro,two dialogues in particular where "time to meet god", and "the wolves are taking over, and you wont be able to live with wolves so leave"(in the context of the film, there are mind blowing). Secondly the films acting which i mentioned above. Finally the film is the definition of what a perfect action thriller must be, the film is extremely detailed, its has a dark atmosphere, the way the film highlights the cartel violence, and how the americans have a hand in the drug trade, is also handled perfectly. In short in Sicario content is king, and the script and screenplay are amazing. A special mention for the absolute amazing pre-climax sequence, i got my tickets worth in just those final minutes.

Overall over the years Denis Villenue has become one of my favourite directors, and with Sicario he only solidifies his title. The film is a must watch, because if you don't watch it now, you will after seeing its oscar nomination list because its just that good.
