I love films that don't just concentrate on telling a story, but also indulge in playing with cinematography - and Sicario is a film that would appear to be a love letter to film-making, with some very Kubrik-esque shots and some genuinely interesting composition - combine this with the constantly building and foreboding score, and you get something very dark and unsettling, but utterly beautiful to watch.
The Kubrik comparisons don't end there either, as the pacing and constant slow progression, are every bit as "Full Metal Jacket" as they can be. The heavy use of aerial shots, vehicle mounted cameras, thermal and night-vision cameras - all of these are combined to make you feel like a participant in both the tactical planning and the action of the film, and the building of tension throughout is brilliantly paced - never rushed. Even when there's no actual action in the action sequences, you still feel the danger building and driving forward into inevitable doom.
The story follows Emily Blunt's character, an FBI hostage rescue specialist, as she is seconded to a shady inter-agency team that appears to be following no procedure or rules of engagement in its war on drugs.
The film presents some good moral dark spots, but Blunt's character is both disappointingly toothless and staunchly lawful, so there's never any real resolution to the story - no crossing to the dark side, but no whistleblowing either. This is one of those stories that doesn't have a full conclusion as such, but is just designed to haunt you and make you think - very similar to "No country for Old Men".
The other thing the movie excels at, is making Mexico appear utterly inhospitable. If "No Escape" was considered xenophobic, then "Sicario" should be straight-up racist. This was definitely never approved by the Mexican board for Tourism, lets put it that way...
An excellent, dark, compelling movie - not an action thrill-ride as you might expect, but still a beautifully made work of art.

Denis Villeneuve's latest film is a riveting crime-drama that is lead by a duo of outstanding performances. Benicio del Toro and Emily Blunt are the most memorable, with Blunt giving a career best display. Sicario depicts the war on drugs in a new light, showcasing the brutality and the victimization of the inhabitants of the land. Corruption spreads like a plague, middle class families live in terror, and there is absolutely no hope for requiem. With Roger Deakins at the helm, Sicario is brilliantly filmed, especially the portions shot at night. It is definitely one of the best pictures of 2015.

If the first 40 minutes of Sicario set the tone for the rest of the movie, this would be an instant classic. Tense, tight and captivating.

But that is not the case. For the most part, Sicario disappoints because the build up is so incredible, but the second part does not deliver.

Benicio del Toro's character is the heart and soul of this film.

 Still, with its flaws, Sicario is a solid product from a very talented director.

A fantastically shot movie about a timely topic, Sicario further establishes Villeneuve's haunting directorial style. The score is slow-paced but unsettling, the cinematography bleak yet beautiful, the action set-pieces conventional yet satisfying. What I like the most, however, is the lack of a true hero, accompanied by an equal shortage of true antagonists: is there such a thing as a just war? Can a war be justified on the mere basis of cost-benefit analysis? It is indeed through questions like these that Mr. Villeneuve molds his latest film into "one of the last Westerns", which Anthony Lane of the New Yorker describes as "tense, forbidding, and trapped on the fringes of the nation, in a battle that cannot be won."

Sicario is directed by Denis Villeneuve who directed Prisoners and Enemy, two movies I absolutely adored. Sicario is a tense and pulsating action crime drama with great performances,gorgeous cinematography and examines how the US government is willing to partner up with a bad guy to  take out other supposedly worse enemies. The thing that impressed me most about this movie is its visuals. Every frame looks gorgeous and full credit must go to the masterful Roger Deakins. The opening immediately sets the grim and sombre mood with a thrilling rescue mission(Or so it seems) by the FBI. This is where we are introduced to FBI agent Emily Blunt. After a terrible turn of events she ends up volunteering to be part of an operation to take down a drug lord. Emily Blunt's character acts as a conduit for the audience as she is mostly clueless(Just like we are) about the shady things going around her. Just like Emily Blunt, we the audience get frustrated at points when she is confused about what exactly is happening in the mission. However, you are hooked in till the end because bits and pieces are dropped from time to time to keep you invested in what's going on. All the supporting actors are fantastic as well. My only real issue with Sicario is that there was a side plot which didn't really matter to the overall story and the fact that the middle section of the movie slows down in pace slightly compared to the first and last act. All in All, Sicario is a great crime drama that shows that the war against drugs might indeed be pointless. A-

Emily Blunt and Benicio del Toro offer well done performances but every second of Sicario feels like a preparation for a brilliant film that never arrives and pushes a very unsatisfying ending in audiences face.

With such a brilliantly talented cast at the helm of a critically acclaimed thriller, Sicario sounded like an exceptional thrill ride.

Sicario does not have the most in-depth story. Tackling the serious nature of the war on drugs and particularly the amount of crime in Juarez, the entire feature seems based predominantly on the concept of violence more than anything. It has very real themes which are tackles in a manner that is merciless without being excessive and emotionally intense without being pretentious, melodramatic or overly sentimental. The feature is a very atmospheric one which carries tenacious heft thanks to the firm direction of Denis Villeneuve, yet this comes at the expense of the intellectual potential of the narrative. 
The simplistic nature of the story ensures that it doesn't get convoluted in an attempt to fit an excess of characters, subplots or political themes into its narrative. Yet at the same time, it also leaves the film feeling empty at times. The story in Sicario is always on a progressive rate forwards and refuses to get distracted with unnecessary subplots or characters who aren't relevant to the story, but it moves along at a pace which is actually rather slow. Sicario is a film which takes time to develop its atmosphere, but it doesn't develop its characters all that well in the process. The story relies on the general ideas of its concept more than exploring its content, and as a result there is an absence of depth in the story. As a result the characters are turned into archetypes who experience interesting situations but lack any particular individuality to make them more valuable than simply what they represent. Sicario is a film with an interesting story that deals with its themes of violence very well, but it doesn't reach out to audiences in a manner which engages them with the characters.
With underdeveloped characters, the dialogue in the film only becomes relevant to the manner in which it characterizes the involvement the characters have in the events and not how it affects them on an emotional level. This causes Sicario to be a somewhat emotionally distant film, even though it maintains enough raw intensity to captivate audiences with shock value of a sophisticated standard. The film functions as a crime thriller which doesn't forsake its use of violence solely for the sake of creating memorable action scenes, but it fails to transcend many standards on any other dramatic levels. It's not necessarily generic, but it doesn't push for as much as it really could have.
Nevertheless, Sicario is successful at simply being a powerful crime thriller. Set in a relevant context and dealing with a theme often exploited solely for stylistic purposes in Hollywood, Sicario forces viewers to confront the brutal reality of contemporary crime. Viewers are subject to witnessing the way violence affects several different characters on a personal and professional level. There is a greater focus on exploring this theme within the story rather than purely through the use of bloody visuals, though there is still a powerful visual experience to the feature which is far from excessive. When the film is not capitalizing on Denis Villeneuve's keen eye for imagery there is a sense that the dialogue slows down the experience without enough emotional heft to justify it, but the language is real and the plot points to the story are interesting enough to keep audiences engaged. Sicario has a story which is easy to follow and thought provoking enough to go beyond the mere stylish virtues.
Sicario makes use of its western style extremely well. The scenery for the film is perfectly dry, as is the colour scheme that matches it. The cinematography is also effective as it is frequently placed in ideal atmospheric locations for the more intense moments while also capturing the grand scope of the scenery with wide shots in others. Sicario is a film shot with perfect precision, and the shots and sound effects are editing with brilliant timing. During the action scenes this all comes together to craft a well-shot and violent spectacle of technical expertise. And to top it off, Sicario makes use of an effective use of a silence much of the time as a means of letting the atmosphere develop tension through more natural means. There is a musical score in the film, but it is moderated in its usage as not to be an over-reliant source of dramatization in the narrative. Sicario has a relatively low budget but functions brilliantly well on a technical level.
And with a list of talented names at its helm, Sicario proves to be a powerfully acted film.
Emily Blunt leads Sicario with a very engaging performance. Without frequently having too much to say in Sicario, Emily Blunt leads the film with a very physical performance. From the beginning of the film we see her treading lightly with intense focus in her gaze which carries on for the entire film. She says everything about her character through her simple facial expressions, depicting an intense state of humane fear combined with determined intensity. She is very easily able to humanize the character Kate Macer without making her seem too vulnerable, keeping her as a strong protagonist who is as realistic as she is heroic. Emily Blunt delivers a thoroughly intense performance in Sicario, bringing a very sympathetic hero to the story and empowering her credibility as an actress.
But it's Benecio Del Toro who really steals the show in Sicario. A Mexican-set tale of the war on drugs is what earned Benecio Del Toro his Academy Award for Best Supporting Actor in Traffic (2001), so seeing his return to the same style of narrative is most welcoming. From the instant he comes on screen there is no telling what his motivations or intentions are. He is unpredictable, and his fearlessly blunt nature empowers him as a result. Benecio Del Toro brings a cold and merciless nature to his presence in Sicario and projects it onto every surrounding character through an intense refusal to submit to anyone around him. Benecio Del Toro commands the screen any time he is on it, and his chemistry with anyone who crosses his path merely serves as another chance to remind audiences of his elite acting strength.
Josh Brolin also contributes a powerful performance.

Sicario may rely on a simple story which is paced slowly and short on characterization, but with Denis Villeneuve's tenacious direction and brilliant performances from Benecio Del Toro and Emily Blunt, Sicario proves to be a very intense examination of violence with very relevant commentary.

Sicario is my movie of the year. An amazing cinematic masterpiece that has you laughing moments before you're on the edge of your seat. Slow pacing and intense characterisation form the main stable of actors, you are are drawn almost immediately into the world of this FBI/CIA? Homeland Security drama. Emily Blunt, an FBI agent who is determined to prove right from wrong establishes herself in a main stayer of the Oscar set in this career defining role, another in a long strong of successes. Josh Brolin and Benicio Del Toro (arguably this is his movie...) complete the leads of this hard and fast team tasked with an almost ridiculous mission. If this film doesn't garner Academy Award recognition.. I am not sure what film this year will!

This is a noir-crime movie. It is not a thriller but it does have some action. It is a thoughtful movie and so it slows down, at times -- a lot! The main female character is built up as a tough person from the very beginning so it is odd to see her as a total innocent in the second half of the movie This incong ruity mars the entire movie. It's like watching James Bond feel sad and cry because someone was mean to him. It just doesn't fit the character. But it is a revealing look into both sides of the drug-trade -- the cops and the robbers. It isn't the good guys against the bad guys. It's just bad guys against bad guys, except that one side breaks the law to enforce the law and the other side breaks the law just because it can.

Another film coming from the auteur Quebecois filmmaker Dennis Villeneuve is a technical powerhouse and slowburn film delving into world of the battle against narcotics, with new rockstar action actor Emily Blunt being the idealistic FBI agent brought into a new unit who crosses the border between the US and Mexico to try and shake things up and destabilize the Meixcan cartels and possibly other factions in the war against drugs. There is some decent tension and as always having Roger Deakins as your go to DOP brings some stellar cinematography work to the fore. All the acting is great and there are some decent jumps, but lacks a good twist ending as thinks wrapped up as you expect the no one is as they seem angle will play out. Otherwise looks like Villeneuve will continue to be a player on the other side as another Canuck made it through the grinder to make it in Hollywood.
"SICARIO" - The Mexican city of "Juarez" makes Compton look like Sesame St.

Until the script loses its cojones and the third act turns it into just another revenge thriller, this is a tense, visually stunning, action flick that also has something serious to say about the ambiguity and futility of the War on Drugs. The slightly over-the-top score heightens the sense of dread, Del Toro and Brolin are solid, but Blunt is underwritten and wasted.
This Indiewire review says it all: "Amazing to look at, amazing to listen to (...) 'Sicario' (...) is superlatively strong in every conceivable way except story." Couldn't agree more.

Loved Emily Blunt's work & character, Benicio's super strong in this, really intimidating, the story might seem familiar but the execution is flawless. Big up to Deakins and Jóhannsson on the camera and sound, Villeneuve's such a deliberate director, pacing is excellent. Really enjoyed it, recommended.

What a movie, It is second movie of Director Denis Villeneuve I have seen and both time i said the same. Perfect cast and breathtaking cinematography and background score. Emily Blunt starts the movie with stunning performance but its Del Toro to whom this movie actually belongs. Actor takes torture and perfect assassin to another level.
I did not expect any less from the director of Oscar Nominated Incendies and i was not disappointed.

4.25 stars.  I really enjoyed this movie.  I've always been a fan of Benicio Del Toro and he was great in this one.  Emily Blunt was also great.  A good story, makes me think if stuff like this really happens against the cartel in the war on drugs.  I highly recommend this one.

Sicario is a brutal and intense film masterfully directed by Denis Villenueve. I have been a big fan of him and this is another great film in his credentials. I loved Prisoners and Enemy, and I also loved Sicario. The performances in this film are top notch. Emily Blunt shines in the lead role. Josh Brolin also is very good in his role. But Benicio Del Toro steals the show in his very mysterious role. These three performances are great. The cinematography is gorgeous. Roger Deakins, as usual, brings beautiful cinematography. I especially loved the "tunnel" scene. This is a beautifully shot film that racks up a lot of tension from the opening scene. This is one not to be missed.

Truly well crafted direction by Denis Villeneuve and lens by legendary cinematographer Roger Deakin that the setup is so gritty, dark, tense, sweaty and dirty. Sicario starred brilliantly by  Emily Blunt, Josh Brolin  and Benicio del Toro mix with physical, subtle effect of facial expressions with minimal dialogue.

Sicario is an OK gritty crime drama centered around the Mexican Drug War.  The cinematography and editing are good, the score is tense and the actors do well.  However, I was disappointed with how irrelevant Kate Macy (Emily Blunt), our heroine, turned out to be.  I understand her role was to be the bewildered moral compass of the movie but ultimately, the point of the movie is morally ambiguous, and the mysterious Alejandro (Del Toro) proves to be a vastly more interesting character.  Alejandro has a harrowing back story thus rendering Kate to be a bystander in the grand scheme of things; a pawn in the war almost.  

What the film does well is hold you captive in suspense and keep you haunted with some disturbing imagery.  Overall, I'd say it's a less well-done Traffic, only Traffic had a sprawling scope while this movie's focus is kinda narrow.  The action scenes were good though.
Another creepy thriller from the director of "Prisoners." Almost as good as that one. This guy really knows how to create tension. Benicio del Toro, James Brolin and Emily Blunt are all fantastic.
Gripping, tense, methodical and compelling drug cartel drama with astounding performances by all the main player especially Benicio Del Toro and lead Emily Blunt.

Trailing his earlier thrillers, the gripping Prisoners (2013) and mindboggling Enemy (2013), into a claustrophobic series of labyrinthine tunnels, Denis Villeneuve shows no signs in stopping as he delivers another slickly directed thriller in the form of Sicario, the latest cinematic crime entry depicting the Mexican Drug War that equally shows no signs in stopping. Penned by screenwriting newcomer, Sons of Anarchy alum Taylor Sheridan, Sicario beats the usual tempos of the war against drug, most overtly being the not-so-surprising cloak and dagger twists involving cartels, governments and intelligence agencies, and where the writing falters, Villeneuve and the film's crew swoop in to the rescue.

That doesn't take away from Sheridan's creative decision in crafting the character of Kate Macer - and Villeneuve's supposed fight against the studio's attempts to change Macer's gender -, pitting the sensibilities of Macer against the trigger-happy male archetypes of her militaristic - or militia-esque - peers in the flip-flop wearing Matt Graver and quiet, yet dangerous Alejandro, and who better to play a role in deconstructing the femme fatale symbol than the actress that played one in Edge of Tomorrow (2014). Despite his character's association with Graver, Del Toro's initial appearance to the gradual character development sets Alejandro apart from "the boys", bringing the actor in at a close second to Macer's in sheer terrifying poignancy and depth; Brolin is the weakest of the trio, whose performance manages to overshadow the singular dimension of the aloof, headstrong Graver. In the hands of a lesser cast - and director -, Sicario would clearly have been yet another derivative drug tale, and one that would have certainly turned into a glorifying shoot 'em up. But thankfully, that certainly isn't the case; the spaced out, taut action set pieces - from a congested highway to a cramped tunnel - come with an air of deliberate intelligence, and a belief that less is more.

Returning from Prisoners and commanding the camera with virtuoso is Roger Deakins - clearly in the running for yet another Oscar snub with this film -, whose sense of space and colour bring ominous definition to Sicario; when the film isn't almost methodologically drumming up a sense of dread through sweeping establishing shots of Juarez, and a bird's eye view of the mortifying, skeletal landscape below, Deakins makes sure that the tight spaces, corridors and pathways are lighted, shot, treated as though death is waiting around the corner. Joining the Prisoners reunion is composer Jóhann Jóhannsson, whose foreboding theme bellows dramatically atop Deakins' visual spectacle and Villeneuve's bravura in molding brazen tension, all which turn Sicario into a white knuckled, edge of the seat orchestra.
Excellent thriller, Emily Blunt was brilliant in it.  Time went quickly so I must have enjoyed it!  Quite a suspenseful film.  R16 and fair enough for that rating in places.

Up and coming auteur Denis Villeneuve dropped his pretentious antics to deliver a bleak, grimy and harrowing tale about the vicious cycle of the war on drugs. As proven in Prisoners, Dennis is a master of setting tense sequences with a standout "family dinner scene". 

However, the ace in the hole of the film is non other than the magnificent Benicio Del Toro, I doubt anyone will find a cooler character than his this year. Ready your suit Benny, the Academy beckons. P.S Roger Deakins cinematography is to die for.

Mimicking a better movie (traffic), it's none-the-less incredibly suspenseful and well directed with two great performances from Brolin and Del Toro. Unfortunately Emily Blunt falls just short of a great performance, highlighted by the incredible work from her co-stars. The real hero of this movie is Roger Deakins, whose cinematography paints the desolate landscape of mexico as an eery decent into hellfire.

Not sure whether to give 4 or 3.5 stars, because there were some characters that I thought could've been fleshed out more and written better material for. But when a movie has a real impact on you, and really makes you think, it's worth more than 3.5 stars.

A taut and fulfilling action-thriller that's also one of the best films since Traffic to investigate the drug trade. Like any good crime story, Sicario has plenty of moral quandary in it, and while there are plenty of impressive action set-pieces, the real pay off comes in the character development. Taylor Sheridan's script takes ample time to explore the three leads (and minor characters) in a concise way, with all of the actors giving really believable performances. Denis Villeneuve also continues to prove that he's one of the most talented working film makers right now, as his style allows for the film to be equal parts exciting, grisly, and human, and it's safe to say that the Blade Runner sequel has its ideal director. One of the year's best.
Well acted with great thrills and unusual visuals.

While tense and well performed,Â  Sicario tries to set up a mystery that it can't quite pay off. Still entertaining however it doesn't reach the same level as Villeneuve's Prisoners for tension or intrigue.

Actually really enjoyed this! Same Director as Prisoners which got me really excited.I loved the story. Thought it moved along great. Maybe some slow parts but nothing crazy. Patriot Games meets No Country For Old Men. Slow, sparse, and brutal. Cinematography classes will be using this film a lot, in the future. Actors playing roles, both small and great, universally came through.

Plays into the moral equivocation trope, a  re-occuring theme in Hollywood, which is its one glaring flaw.
It's an effective enough War on Drugs crime-drama, but what's the point of even having Emily Blunt in this movie? She's not a character so much as she's a plot device.

SICARIO is a slow burn that while having some gruesome imagery is surprisingly low on the body count and violence... seriously, I don't think anyone saying it's got a "horror movie body count" even saw more than the trailer. Much of the more shocking elements are handled with a Hitchcockian touch. Meaning you don't always see the act, but  frequently will see the result and they really do seem all too few and far between. Very well done and worth the watch even-though it's a fairly straight forward  by the numbers, linear story. No surprise twists (well not to me anyways)  and no other real draw to see this in theaters, you'll be fine waiting for video and watching it at home.

Director Denis Villeneuve, cinematographer Roger Deakins and composer Johann Johannsson are a cinematic dream team. Blunt, Brolin and Del Toro deserve praise, but the trio behind the camera are the real stars of Sicario.

Among Hollywood's better products. This is puzzling, unfinished and interesting. In its style, I was reminded of "The Quiet American". The quality of the production is very good. I went into this movie with high hopes, but unfortunately, they were misplaced. I haven't seen a film with such a disjointed story line in some time. There was no mention of the events of the opening of the movie, at all. It was barely mentioned again, even though they were apparently going after whoever the hell was responsible. Also, was there really an assassin? I can't seem to truly find one. This movie tried to be new and fresh, but there was nothing new added to the already covered topic. Sicario could possibly be one of those movies that require a second viewing, as the first viewing failed to hit the spot for me. On the surface Sicario ticks all the right boxes but ultimately fails before its begun.

Talk about a thriller. "Sicario" was fascinatingly brutal: it was like watching "Zero Dark Thirty," but instead of hunting terrorists, the U.S. government is after a cartel boss in Mexico. Everything about this movie is flooring: the script is nail-biting, Denis Villenueve's direction is brilliant, and the performances from Emily Blunt, Josh Brolin, and Benicio Del Toro were stunning. Del Toro, in particular, was excellent: his magnificent brutality was at the heart of the movie and it really made the second half virtually perfect. "Sicario" is an excellent film: I'd recommend it to anyone that enjoys a good, violent seat-gripper.

Sicario is a stellar film with absolutely unimpeachable cinematography, editing, sound design and score, acting, etc. etc. The reason I couldn't possibly give it 5 stars is mainly to do with how very weak the main character is in her own film; she's used as bait, falls into a honeypot trap with her would-be hitman, is constantly impeding her unit's progress by being a stick in the mud, and generally not helping advance the plot in any meaningful way. I look forward to the sequel with this character removed, because the way she was written did her a SERIOUS disservice.
Beautiful cinematography, gritty reality and graphic violence.  An excellent look at the drug war at our border and the brutality of the cartels that control it.

One of this year's best thrillers

More visceral than Steven Soderbergh's "Traffic." SICARIO is about the cost to pay in a drug war and its merciless brutality. Masterfully shot, perfectly acted. This is a film that doesn't allow you to feel comfortable. With each passing moment, it crawls its way deeper and deeper into this world where death is its only end game.

Director Denis Villenuve reteams with master cinematographer Roger Deakins to take advantage of the desert, the weather, the landscape, the terrain, and use them as silent supporting characters that also serve to express the characters' inner demons. Deakins is a multiple Oscar-nominated DP that gets better with every work and in SICARIO, you will see that he once again experiments with even richer and newer ways of shooting, whether it's the night vision first person view or the angles to capture the intensity at the border, moments before weapons are drawn, it's like enrolling in another classroom taught by Deakins but with extra curriculums to learn. The man just knows how to leave his competition behind.

To me, what I think is impressive about Emily Blunt is that she is beauty and strength all in one. She can express torment and conflicted soul so effortlessly, she plays this FBI agent, Kate Macer who does things by the book, she always holds herself and others accountable for every detail, so when she volunteers to be a part of a black ops that practically throws the book out the window, her idealistic views are put to the test. And I think Emily Blunt does a nice job of executing that. It's somewhat of a fish out of water story where Blunt's Kate Macer knows she's being used but she wants to know what she's being used for.
Oscar winner, Benicio Del Toro has walked through this territory before in Steven Soderbergh's "Traffic" where he played a Tijuana police officer. In SICARIO, he plays a mysterious character, Alejandro, he's skilled, a man of a few words, soft spoken, but highly intense and has a sharp instinct. What has always been brilliant about Del Toro, in all of his works including SICARIO, is that he can say much without actually saying much at all. In the case of his character, Alejandro, there's a certain dark pain that's magnetic about him. It's all in the eyes.
Oscar nominee Josh Brolin plays the leader of the team, Matt Graver, he talks way too damn much but that is also a part of his game, his game of manipulating others.

I've never been to Juarez, I've heard horrible stories about that place, and SICARIO, though it wasn't exactly filmed in Juarez, does manage to put the fear of God in audiences' heart by showing Juarez for what it is, there's no sugar coating, there's no hiding that it's one of the murder capitals of the world. It's a deeply harrowing part that will stay with you long after you've done watching the film which in and of itself wrestles with questions of morality.SICARIO means 'hitman,' you'll come to wonder which of those three lead characters is the actual hitman but ultimately, what SICARIO gives you is this dilemma,... if somebody could finally solve the drug cartel and drug kingpin problems for the rest of us, would you really care that they did it by killing instead of bringing the perp to justice?

Ripped right out of today's headlines, this is the very gritty story of an idealistic FBI agent played by Emily Blunt who must learn from and trust Josh Brolin and Bernico Del Toro. Josh, maybe...Bernico, no way! This is the story of the drug wars on the U.S-Mexico border. The only thing missing is Donald Trump building a wall.
With it's narrative and characters being the main focus, Sicario manages to capture viewers attention with shocking themes, impressive cinematography, and often palpable tension throught.
a very intense movie.
Emily Blunt continues to be a great bad ass action hero.  This is a complex story about our ill waged war against drugs and the impact that war has had on the residents of the Mexican border.
A well put together movie. Strong cast & script couldn't have asked for a more real movie
Outstanding, not for the faint-hearted though
Beautifully shot and directed as expected, Del Torro and Emily Blunt are great and Josh Brolin is likeable. However the story is not as great as its craftsmanship.

I think this movie would be rated higher upon a second viewing. 
The movie explores the drug trade, and the war on drugs between Mexico and US.  It explore many different moral themes from different angles.
It's the movie that leaves you asking quesitons, and really wondering about things after the movie is over.  I think it's those kind of movies that are the real good ones. 
The narrative is somewhat complicated but not too difficult to follow.
The acting is of the highest order here.  Emily Blunt is fantastic and you truly believe her performance.  She is asked to join a task force to try and take down the highest members of a Mexican Cartel.  Yet she is uneasy at what her role truly is.

Josh Brolin is the leader of the team..a brash, cocky veteran of the biz who uses whatever tactics necessary.
The star to me was del Toro...when on screen he has a sense of mystery around him.  He is steady, no nonsense, and really hardcore.  He obviously has a difficult past and has bee morphed into a different kind of past.  His role is also unknown throughout the movie as we learn more as it goes.

The movie really asks questions about how the drug trade operates, the true purpose of the United States, and how corrupt things can be to maintain order.
It's an eye opening film featuring 3 fantastic performances.  There are scenes or extreme realism that is fueled by fantastic direction.  
The movie isn't really concerned with being an action piece, more of an eye opening piece.

Sicario is a flawless film, and my favorite film so far of 2015. Under the direction of Denis Vellenuve and seen through the lens of Roger Deakins, this film is visually mind blowing. I don't know how Roger Deakins does it, but he delivers such a realistic visual style. Sicario left me with a feeling I have never felt before while watching an action thriller. That feeling of tension, and suspense, but even more so, that feeling of impending dread. It became so tense that I would jump at certain gunshots, because of the exceptional filmmaking. The scary realism and tension that is carried throughout Sicario makes it one of the best films of the year, and certainly worth every single second.
One of the most nail-biting crime thrillers in recent years with award-worthy performances. Full review: http://bit.ly/1JazpTF

Given that Denis Villineuve is coming off of the heels of Prisoners and Enemy, I was excited for Sicario. I thought that the former was great and the latter was amazing, so if I had to rank Sicario in relation to those two, I'd probably say that it's my least favorite. That isn't saying a lot, though, since Sicario is still a really good movie. Some of its characters feel too underwritten or detached, but it's still well paced, wonderfully tense with great cinematography, and very well acted on everyone's behalf. What it lacks in its screenplay is mostly redeemed by its direction and cinematography, and even though it's imperfect, Sicario is still one of the better movies of the year. The first thing that talk about here is Villineuve's direction, which proves yet again that he knows how to create tension and mystery in understated situations. Aside from the opening, the first 80 minutes or so of Sicario are rather devoid of action, but it's still interesting at a consistent rate. It brings to mind Zero Dark Thirty in its tone and structure as well as in the tension of its final act, with a somewhat similar point of view in which the story is told. Villeneuve makes a great use of establishing shots to construct a bleak tone, and along with cinematography god Roger Deakins, he manages to get a lot of interesting visuals that make the town of Juarez a character in and of itself. Villeneuve also gets a lot out of his actors, namely Benicio del Toro and Emily Blunt. Del Tero creates what is easily the most interesting character of the movie, one that lends context to the story and has multiple layers to his personality. He may not be fully be an antagonist, but he's especially menacing. Emily Blunt acts as a nice conduit between the world of the film and the audience as both she and we learn about the situations at hand simultaneously. She walks a fine line of being a badass and legitimately vulnerable, and we even get to see a bit of her personal life, so no, it doesn't feel like she's "badass female action hero for the sake of being a badass female." There are a few moments where she almost slips into being a peripheral character, but she does a nice job at standing her ground in a rather populated cast. Josh Brolin may be the weakest link; he seems to only play the slightly weathered, smart-alecky man who knows his stuff really well. In regards to issues with Sicario, most of them stem from its script. In fact, most issues have already been mentioned--it just so happens that the director and actors tend to redeem the film of these issues. Most characters feel not understated or detached, but underwritten. They never breach stock character territory, but I found myself thinking several times that some of the characters must of had a least a little bit more to them, but it was mostly a case of "what you see is what you get." Again, Del Toro and Blunt have the most intriguing characters and they give the best performances, but the others begin to fall by the wayside and eventually feel simply like supporting characters. So athough I didn't find it to be as great as others did and I felt that Prisoners and Enemy were both better, richer experiences, Sicario is still thrilling at times, knowing when to show violence, when to cut away, when to be brutal, and when to slow down. Roger Deakins continues to prove how inane The Academy can be given the fact that he's never been given an Oscar for his work, and the actors never compete for the limelight. It could have done with a script revision, but Sicario is effective nonetheless, and bonus: this is a movie that actually has something to say. 8.2/10, really good, one thumb up, above average, etc.

Sicario is a film that benefits from a up and coming director and a very talented cast. Though the film has to build up before it really gets going it ends up being a satisfying if not exhilarating thriller. 

The film has a lot going for it. It's direction, cast, story, cinematography, and music are all top notch. Blunt and Brolin are both very well cast in their roles, but it is Del Toro who really steals the show, he is mesmerizing in his turn as a very complicated unsettling character. Villanueve is great at making suspenseful and exciting tension and the beautiful shots by Deakins and the brooding musical score by Johansson are all major components in what makes this a very good film.

On the other hand, the film is most definitely build up. It starts out slow in the beginning and gets better and better as it goes. It's second two acts are far more exciting compared to its first.

Overall Sicario is a very entertaining film, but the first act is less superior than the next ones. There is so live in this film especially Del Toro. Villanueve isn't on a roll and he has no signs of stopping.

Denis Villeneuve's latest venture, 'Sicario', is a knockout.  This dark, grisly thriller is haunting and heavily atmospheric, and said tone is all the more bolstered by some great performances.  It also has a fantastic score and stunning cinematography, and those shouldn't be overlooked.

A brutally honest film depicting the gruesome violence of the drug wars on both sides of the U.S.--Mexican border, this movie will keep you on the edge of your seat from beginning to end.  Benecio Del Toro brings a chilling, award worthy performance to the table and pairs wonderfully with the talented Emily Blunt for an action packed, gritty, and thought-provoking experience.

All I can say is wow. I left the theater with my mouth wide open. This movie gets under your skin and doesn't let go. The cinematography is amazing to the opening desert scene to the ending soccer game. The acting is so well done with an amazing cast of Benicio Del Toro, Josh Brolin, and Emily Blunt. The Score is fantastic with varieties of eerie whistling to intense drumming. The story does a great Job of putting us in the shoes of the main character and feeling the same type of mystery and confusion that she feels until the end when everything ties in together.  The tone and atmosphere that the director creates is perfect for this type of thriller. It's dark and stylish, I mean like it is DARK. There is literally no sense of hope what so ever in this film. I must admit it is hard to watch some scenes where it feels like the dead bodies are looking straight into your soul. There are some scenes that just leave you like "Did he just? Oh my..." But overall this movie is a great 9/10. This takes my number two spot for favorite movies with Interstellar still at one. If you are a fan of dark and mysterious movies I encourage you to watch this. This is probably the most well made movie of the year. Wow. I love it

Sicario tuvo su premier mundial en Cannes y actualmente se encuentra en Toronto, tomando fuerza para la temporada de premios 2016, en miras a conseguir nominaciones en las categorias principales. Aunque dirigida por el canadiense Denis Villeneuve, tiene la estructura de filmes revisionistas del tema militar/FBI/DEA de películas como Zero Dark Thirty y Hurt Locker, en donde basicamente hay una protagonista inexperta en el campo de acción, quien por sus logros de inteligencia, es asignada a un bloque de busqueda de un lider terrorista que impone mediate el uso de la violencia, el control sobre un territorio. Si sustituye a Jessica Chastain sobre Emily Blunt, a Mark Strong con Josh Brolin, a Jason Clarke con Benicio del Toro y cambia la accion de Afganistán a Juárez-Mexico, en la busqueda del jefe narco que controla el tráfico de estupefacientes en la frontera, estamos en esencia ante la misma película. Rescatable por la música del laureado Jóhann Jóhannsson, la cinematografia del reconocido Roger Deakins (asegurado junto con Villeneuve para la secuela de Blade Runner) y la actuacion de Benicio del Toro, quien aunque obtuvo un oscar por un papel similar en Traffic de Soderbergh, saca provecho en el tramo final, interpretando a un mercenario con una extraña interpretación de la ley del Talión.

When I first saw this film I was highly disappointed. Here I was expecting some action thriller because the previews I saw made it seem like the highway shootout scene would be epic. The entire time I saw it the first time I kept waiting for the big shootout totally taking myself out of the story. I'm not sure if this was my own fault or the marketing efforts of the motion picture companies who set these great expectations just to fill seats. However, after my initial review I kept hearing about how great this film was and people kept referencing it in their vlogs. Upon my second review I gained a newfound appreciation for this film. Not only is it's cinematography totally good looking (which I did notice the first time around) but the story takes a decent spin on how far the law will go to catch criminals. It also presents a uncomfortable feeling of how deeply insulated the cartels are in the justice systems and the extent they will go to catch someone they pose as a threat. I believe this film has definitely set a fine stage for a sequel and I'm interested to know how the story will continue.

There is something exceptionally startling about director Denis Villeneuve's approach to his rather subtle character examinations. Neither Prisoners or Enemy did anything to necessarily expand our minds to the way we work as humans, but they called often dismissed thoughts and qualities to the surface. With his latest, Sicario, the director is once again examining the human condition under the most stringent of circumstances and once again he puts our nerves through the ringer. Having more than enjoyed both of Villeneuve's previous studio efforts (I've yet to see Incendies, but clearly need to) and anticipating his latest if not based on his previous work, but for the trio of stellar actors he recruited to execute this feature I walked away from Sicario with a stunned respect for how what was being said was in fact stated. Brutal beyond measure, unflinching to a fault and featuring an extremely serious tone balanced by a slight comedic performance from Josh Brolin, Vileneuve has crafted a film that is not wholly concerned with plot as much as it is the examination of the complexities of these people who are trapped in a world convoluted beyond their comprehension that only continues to go around in circles. Sicario is by no means a masterpiece of the genre as it does tend to lose some of it's steam in it's middle section, but it more than makes up for it with a chilling conclusion and a tension throughout that is something akin to unshakable.

Sicario is the story of Kate Macer (Emily Blunt), an FBI kidnapping rescue specialist who is offered a chance to work with an operative from the CIA (Josh Brolin) and his partner Alejandro (Benicio del Toro). They work to stop drug trafficking and bring down a drug cartel on the Mexican-American border.

Things I Liked:

Emily Blunt. Blunt has an amazing amount of character in this movie. She walks this line between tough as nails and fragile as glass. She is someone out of her element and is trying to cope and has to do so in two ways. One which is to put up all her defenses and shut everything out. The other which is to come to terms with her plight and you see every emotion go across her face. It's marvelous to watch.

Benicio del Toro. Del Toro plays a similar way to Emily Blunt with the exception that he is in his element. He is being proactive not reactive. He shows moments where he is very stoic and very in control and very powerful, and then there are other moments where he drops his stoicism briefly and allows you to see his true colors, but he never drops his sense of power and control. He owns this movie and his performance stands out.

The Subtlety. This movie does an incredible job of showing, not telling. It uses quick visual moments to move the plot and develop the characters and gives you loads of information without having to use boring and out of place expository dialogue. It does this beautifully throughout the movie and allows you to take in information without even realizing it. By the time we get to any major dialogue scenes we feel we already know a great deal about these characters and this situation.

Things I Didn't Like:

The Movie is Gonna Make You Feel Icky. The movie is grim, it's gritty, it's rough. I walked out feeling like there was something wrong and harsh in the world. You see grisly images and it gives you a sense that there is little hope in the world. The movie wouldn't work without it but I think it is something that should be said before you head out and think this is a fun action film. It's not, it's dark and it will leave you thinking and feeling that the world is a bit grim at times.

Overall. Overall the movie is incredibly well put together, the story is interesting, the characters are dynamic and the performances are superb. The movie has a dark tone and it does so in a way that really makes you feel this dark morose world around you. But it uses that well in the context of the film. The movie is an incredible experience and one that stands out.

Sicario is one of the best movies of 2015. Great acting from Del Toro and Emily Blunt. And beautiful cinematography from Roger Deakins. Dennis Vellunueve has become one of the best directors working today.

Thought-provoking, sharp and violent, Sicario is a brutal action-thriler and gut-wrenching depiction of the narco-wars of which we have only heard. Slowly paced, but with a suspense that is meticulously built up, this is not the usual American story of fighting narco-cartels. It is a polarizing and realistic take on the "not winning" the war on drugs, which beautifully wrapped in amazing cinematography, delightful directing and Oscar-worthy performances. Undeservedly snubbed for the Oscars, Sicario deserved much more attention than its three technical nominations.

An exemplary FBI special agent Kate Macy ( Emily Blunt) is enlisted to a secret government anti-drugs task force led by Josh Brolin and consulted by the enigmatic Benicio Del Toro. The squad fights the drugs war in a totally different and unorthodox way that challenged Macy's understanding of rule of law, rules of engagement, ethics and moral. Every single day as part of this team she faces new things that will question everything she (and the audience) believes in. 

The story is being developed and revealed slowly and quite untypically for action-thrillers. The first half sets the overall atmosphere and the different environment in which Emily Blunt has to survive, while the second part unleashes the inconvenient truth about winning the war on the drugs. Denis Villeneuve's movie is complex, restrained and yet shocking. He allows his actors to fully get under the skin of their characters and Blunt, Brolin and Del Toro deliver what is expected from them. The performance of Del Toro is particularly impressive as the mysterious Alejandro. His mesmerizing presence, self-control and almost inhuman cool-blooded desire for personal revenge will make you think about his character long after the movie has ended.  

If the content and acting are at Oscar-worthy level, the same should be said for the technical part of the movie. The cinematography of Roger Deakins is hypnotizing; it is almost as if the whole movie is worth seeing only for the sunset scene of the squad. Sound edit, music and fighting sequences are as realistic as the story's end and fully contribute to the brilliant final result. 

In conclusion, there can be no doubt that Sicario is another splendid gem and a classic delivered by Denis Villeneuve. With another thought-provoking and attention-gripping movie after his Incendies, Prisoners and Enemy, he is definitely one of the directors to closely monitor, especially having in mind that he is directing the re-boot of Blade Runner. Sicario is a must see and a must have movie. It is simply one of the best releases of 2015 and certainly in the top 3 of best ever narco-cartels/war on drugs movies.

Exceptionally well crafted drama, intentionally dark in essence without being noir. A great character study of many different fronts involved in the violent and ruthless war against drugs. In a very well written story, the director takes you for a ride to "The Beast" or a.k.a Juarez Mexico, following this group of elite secret government agents, traveling through the crooked streets with the sound of bullets and a wonderful soundtrack that only adds more tension to an already tense trip. The hero of the story does everything but heroic things under modern standards and yet she pushes you to constantly question, where do we abandon our morals? Do the ends really justify the means? What would you do?

This was one of my most anticipated movies of 2015, since it was first announced and then when it premiered at Cannes this past May, everything of it looked great, and having a great cast and an excellent director it was only building up my excitement. And so the movie is if not everything you would expect, full of suspense and tension, shot beautifully and acted wonderfully. While watching this movie you could feel this was the type of movie that is considered art by just how beautiful every scene looked and it just had that feel about it, that you were lucky enough to watch this at a movie theater because it is very rare to be able to watch an art film this way nowadays. Also even though the story at times was dragging a little, the build up moments were extremely tense and suspenseful which literally had me on the edge of my seat for a couple of very crucial scenes. Something else I noticed was that although Emily Blunt seemed to be the lead, in a way Benicio Del Toro somehow took over the film in the end, and he was truly amazing which sadly out shined Blunt in the end, but still she was terrific and I would've loved to see her more and be the standout of the film. While Dennis Villeneuve did a fantastic job behind the camera, and that truly showed on screen really bringing everything front and center and not missing anything. Overall, it was a very tough movie, that treated a very important problem thats happening today, and without giving any solution to it, it showcased how inhuman and terrifying it is to live that. 
~October 1, 2015~

While it's not quite as good or original as some of the early buzz might have you believe, there's still a lot to like in Sicario, director Denis Villeneuve's followup to his (criminally underrated) 2013 thriller Prisoners. Though treading fairly familiar narrative ground, Villeneuve knows how to stage a suspense sequence as well as anyone, with two scenes in particular here ranking as among the tensest I've seen all year. Throw in a trio of great lead performances from Emily Blunt, Josh Brolin, and Benicio Del Toro, a pulsating score from Jóhann Jóhannsson, and cinematography from the ever-reliable Roger Deakins, and you've got a film that more than warrants two hours of your time.

Everyone it's in their top of their game in "Sicario", every performance stands out, the soundtrack its haunting, the sound mix and design its superb, the cinematography its glorious, the script takes turns and twists guiding our main characters through different emotional catharsis and dangerous challenges. Denis Villeneuve crafts a slow burn thriller, that stays with you long after you leave the theater.

I've seen around twenty movies in the theater this year, but I can say without a shadow of a doubt that "Sicario" is the very best film I've seen in 2015.

Being a huge fan of Villeneuve's prior two films, "Prisoners" and "Enemy", I've been anticipating this film for  what feels like a very long time. This may just be his finest work to date, but the beautiful thing is that I don't know if I can really say that, because each of his films are so distinctly different. While "Prisoners" was very direct and bleak, "Enemy" was much more nuisanced and cerebral. "Sicario" is a wonderful hybrid of them both, as well as being a brutal portrayal of the world we live in, and the one that most of us don't.

I judge the success or failure of a film based on the following elements: the consistency in pace and tone, the film's performances, visual elements (i.e., the cinematography), and the engagement of the story. This film succeeds in all of those areas in spades.

As far as the cast goes, the film's major standouts to me are, first and foremost, Emily Blunt who gives the very best performance of her career, Benicio Del Toro, who's good as always, Josh Brolin, who's always great as well, and a strong side performance from the criminally underrated Jeffrey Donovan.

However, my absolute favorite element of the film is the visual wizardry by the great Roger Deakins. Deakins, next to only Emmanuel Lubezki, is the greatest director of photography currently living, and the beautiful elements of this film are a distinct reflection of why that is. A shot in a film done by Roger Deakins isn't simply thrown together. He'll never just lock down a tripod and let her rip. Deakins has a sense of tone that supports the director, as well as a strong subtext to each shot. It's because of people like the lovely Roger Deakins that I've come to truly appreciate the power of an image.

Overall, this is a spectacular piece of thrilling filmmaking that soars under the guidance of a master craftsman. I was absolutely blown away by this film. This is a masterpiece that truly deserves to be seen by everyone.
Dry and dark and very good

A grim, yet incredible story sewn together with ungodly amounts of beautiful cinematography by Roger Deakins, soul crushing performance by Emily Blunt, and insane direction from Denis Villeneuve makes Sicario a suspense thriller that will not be matched this year, I guarantee it.

It's been a long time since I've felt a movie put an oppressive sense of tension on me as a viewer like this. From the start, this film is as tense as they come. It never lets up and keeps you, not in wonder, but in fear of what is going to happen next. This is a career best performance from Emily Blunt. Josh Brolin and Benicio De Toro are also fantastic. The latter actor is the film's wild card, as you can never quite figure out who's side he is on. He is a dog just waiting to get off the leash. The writing, directing, and photography will rank among the best of the year, but it is the film's score that will stick with me for a long time to come. It steals your nerve and never releases you from it's grip until it is done with you.

Sicario is a dark edgy crime thriller film that leaves the audience in an uncomfortable feeling and unsettling direction. Director Denis Villeneuve, which also did a crime film Prisoners and had that same feel of making the audience feeling unease. Well, he manages to keep this film, the same feeling around every single set piece the film goes too.

 The plot follows FBI agent Kate Macer (Emily Blunt) and her team that discovers plenty of corpses in a house after a drug raid and an incident that leaves some dead and her wounded. Kate joins an elite force led by Matt (Josh Brolin), who wants to track down the man responsible of the incident. Mattâ(TM)s partner that is aiding them on their mission Alejandro (Benicio del Toro) does leave Kate questioning their loyalties on which side they are actually on, as they travel to Juarez, Mexico where every corner they turn too, puts them a step closer to their criminal and putting themselves at risk.


 Sicario has some good moments of making you feel unease, the direction is handled well, were every set piece the characters are in, anything unpredictable can happen. Emily Bluntâ(TM)s character is placed into some heated areas, and she is left under the dark with Josh Brolinâ(TM)s elite group. She is clueless, about what their end game is in trying to go after the criminal, and the frustrations she has when Brolin does not give away much information about their plan. Bluntâ(TM)s character is vulnerable, the film shows the tension on Texas/Mexico borders as they are vulnerable to being attacked by the bad guys to Blunt having trust issues on everyoneâ(TM)s loyalties and unexpected assault in her hotel. Denis Villeneuve knows how to build the suspense and even including the music composer haunting score. Definitely, one of those films, were characters and their actions are unexpected in the grittiest way.


 Emily Blunt did a fantastic job, she is a great stunning actress, as she her characters motivation in taking down the criminal and going through deep territory. I have to say Benicio del Toro did a good job, and this is one of his better performances as a stone cold killer and having his own personal agenda during the mission. 


 There is a couple of things the film does lack in areas, like the film missed the opportunity to go in depth with the plot, instead of having agents go from set piece to another as it builds intensity but leaving a few things left open. Sicario is a fair thriller, and does well with its nerve wrecking direction but lacks in a paced story.

What a frustrating film to watch. A wonderful ensemble of actors all on screen not performing to their capabilities due to a lackluster script. Perhaps Benicio del Toro was the only one on his A game. 

The only positive I can think of is the photography. The SW portion of the US has some spectacular beauty, and the hyper - violent images of Mexico were thought-provoking, but not much else.

The film itself tried to be as provocative as its imagery, but it fell completely short. There seemed to be no real direction to this movie. The whole time I felt like it was a 2 hour anti-Mexico, PSA sponsored by Donald Trump.

The biggest disappointment was Emily Blunt by a long shot. After watching her kickass performance in Edge of Tomorrow, it was tough to comprehend why she would take a script that transformed her into a stereotypical, weepy, whiny white woman. The scenes she was in, were difficult to watch; and even inspired cheers for the cartel members to finally rid us of perhaps the most annoying character in the "story". I didn't expect one-armed pushups, but it would have been nice to feel like Emily's character wasn't a constant liability. 

In addition to her weak take on this role, a writing issue took place about 45-50 minutes in the movie. It is The Alien Effect. When you have a character make a statement that we "shouldn't be doing this" and the main character ignores that WITH a viable way out of the situation, THE MOVIE IS OVER. At that point, the character who actively participates after said warning should just die. Black guys gives warning, white person angrily ignores it, chaos ensues, is absolute cinematic nonsense. Fix that Hollywood. 

Overall, this is a movie with no real message, no real purpose. The action doesn't make up for the non-existent story. The dynamic cast doesn't satisfy the reality that the script was weak at best. Just a colossal letdown.
Phenomenal. Villeneuve crafts another perfect masterpiece that is nothing but tension

Deftly directed and superbly acted, Denis Villeneuve's "Sicario" takes an unflinching look at a brutal drug war. 

Emily Blunt's performance could be overlooked for its subtlety, but that's exactly what makes it powerful. In "Edge of Tomorrow," Blunt was an indomitable warrior; in "Sicario," she's Kate Macer, an FBI agent trying her best to be that warrior. Kate is steely and pragmatic, but thrust into a situation she has no control over, she's entirely vulnerable, and Blunt balances that resolve and helplessness brilliantly.       

Equally compelling, Benicio del Toro (the film's titular hitman) layers his ruthless mercenary with a rich complexity and humanity. His character, like others trapped in this morally grey world, cannot be readily defined as hero or villain; they are all victims of a corrupt and lawless system.

Sicario means hitman which is basically what its about. For the record, emily blunt is about as annoying as dakota fanning was in 2005s war of the worlds. Del toro is a tour de force and Brolin is equally good

Knew this was going to be one hell of a dark violent story, and I got more than I bargained for.  From the first house they took down in the opening minutes the cinematography was great, the acting was stunning, the script was good.  The fast pace kept it all on the move as they rises around to take down the main drug trafficker, not cutting any corners on the way.  Emily Blunt was great as Kate, the new idealistic women in the force who believe all their doing is wrong, even if it's the only way to get the mission completed.  The team is a bunch of badass soldiers from Afganistan, lead by Josh Brolins character, who has little emotion and can always get a laugh.  The Columbian on the team that Kate mistrusts is a super badass heartless hitman, after revenge on the man who killed his wife and daughter, the same man the team is tracking down. It's a dark movie, with beheaded and mutilated bodies hung naked off bridges, a house bad of dead people in the walls, people killed by being thrown into tubs of acid, not to mention those who are just shot. The battle scenes are well done brief, extremely intense and violent actions, where the teams guns down car loads of enemies, as in the case of the boarder crossing scene.  The ending was good, the hitman sitting calming at the table of the family that killed his own, after killing many others to get there unannounced.  Colder heartedly he dispatches them without flinching, without rush.  He is a main of a character as Kate, and they occupy two opposite sides of the force. Anyways it's a great movie, in all of it's violent, intense, realistic, and non withstanding scenes and plot.  A must see, and one I'll buy when it becomes available.

And that question is left to your own opinion.

Sicario was a bit slower than I thought it was going to be. It isn't bad, but man does the first half hour move at a snails pace. The film follows an FBI agent named Kate Macer (Emily Blunt). A by the books agent that is in charge of hostage situations. She is brought into a group led by Matt Graver (Josh Brolin) an elite government agent that doesn't always play by the rules. Graver is working with a mysterious man named Alejandro (Benicio Del Toro) who has a hidden agenda himself. Their task is to take down a drug lord through any means necessary. Macer sees things that haunt her and she questions what exactly is going on and who exactly are the people they are working for. The movie is well done and shot really well. Like i said previously it has a very slow start, but after the cogs get rolling the film has a lot of suspense and is a mystery in itself. Overall, it won't be for everyone, but if you like a slow burner thriller with a slight mystery give this one a look!

"Sicario" allows its ominousness to do most of it's talking for it, which makes so much more of an impact.  Villenuve's take on America's involvement in the war on drugs is pitch black, drenched in murky morals and alliances.  The performances are great all around, but it's Del Toro's show.

If you've seen Traffic you will walk out of Sicario feeling a sense of dejavu, just with a happier (sort of) ending and a different ensemble cast (save for a few familiar faces). That being said the film is still quite good and was released at a perfect time right on the back of the highly successful Netflix original series Narcos (both revolve around US agents and drug cartels). If you're really into this genre it's easily worth a movie theater viewing; otherwise give it a rent when it hits iTunes. I wouldn't be surprised if Sicario shows up during award season so look for that as well...

Sicario was one of the most anticipated films of 2015 for the reasons that Denis Villeneuve directed it, who directed films that I really appreciated like Prisoners and Enemy, and the cast. So after watching Sicario, it turns out to be a magnificent movie. While the story is basically standard, the movie takes advantage of it and adds in some new twists that make the narrative more interesting then what it could've been. Emily Blunt is great as a main role, and I haven't seen Benicio del Toro this fantastic in years. The score is very haunting to listen to, and it works well to some of the disturbing imagery that it shows in the movie, which makes it scarier than horror films nowadays. The cinematography by Roger Deakins is well shotted, and the direction is very well done. Josh Brolin is also really good, and their characters are very memorable thanks to the script by Taylor Sheridan. The action scenes are intense to watch, and it's really grim also with no sense of hope. It's a slow burn film which can get some viewers to lose their interests in it, but the filmmaking in this is expertly done that it really help elevate the movie that it's one of the best movies of 2015 for me.

Sicario, the third Denis Villeneuve feature film after the highly successful Prisoners and Enemy from 2013 and 2014 respectively. The movie stars Emily Blunt (Edge of Tomorrow), Josh Brolin (Everest and No Country for Old Men), and Benicio Del Toro (Escobar: Paradise Lost and Traffic) in a drug-fuelled action movie set along the US-Mexico Border. 

The movie is a cliche storyline with characters that have been seen before. But the way that the characters are played is what makes this movie stand out. It should be noted that the posters may show that the movie might be about Emily Blunt's character Kate, but the crucial performance is the performance by Del Toro in his portrayal of Alejandro. This is a performance that hasn't been seen from Del Toro in quite a while. I would have to say that a Best Actor Nomination should easily be coming towards Del Toro's way. An honorable mention to Josh Brolin, portraying the team leader Matt. His character brought comic relief to a movie that was disturbingly serious. 

Now the movie itself. The first thing to note is the cinematography. The movie is beautifully shot, which is not a surprise with Director of Photography Roger Deakins (No Country for Old Men and Skyfall) at the helm. The panning birds eye view shots of Ciudad Juarez along with street side shots showed the bleak circumstances that the people in Juarez were living in. 

The defining message from the film is the bleakness of the War on drugs in the Southern US. It shows how agencies have to "work together" just to have a shot at a cartel leader and even getting rid of a single cartel leader just means that another leader has already propped up and ends up being a never ending circle of massacre. 

It's not the story that contributes to the high mark it will get, it's the characters in the movie who you connect to immediately, with audiences most likely to latch onto Alejandro's story after his background is revealed. Sicario may not get a Best Picture nomination but might have at least 1 nomination for Best Actor. Sicario gets an A grade.

It depicts a savage version of America's war against drugs in Mexico. With some sinister characters that you can't decide wether what they are doing is good or bad. It all depends on how much brutality you can handle. If you can handle that then it can be an interesting way of looking at the plague that drugs have been brought to North America. There is some very nice landscape shots throughout the film.
Finally got around to watching this, one a riveting piece which depicts the cost to Mexico of the decades long cartel wars.

The dark world of the Mexican cartel running through the lines of Mexico and southern US. US agencies blurring the lines of right and wrong and playing by the rules of the cartel itself. 
noticing that by the book doesnt work anymore. 

Emily Blunt's character, a rookie and noticing the lines blurring throughout the movie with Del Toros Columbian cartel/DOD character along with Brolin blurring it. 

It is one dark, brutal, slow burn of a movie with intense one-on-one acting scenes and haunting score. Del toro's character serves as a low end supporting character for the first few minutes on screen but completely overshadows everyone else as the story progresses and completely steals it, subtly. 
I haven't liked Brolin since his role in No country for old men. 

but the story unfortunately isn't the strong point, it was one of the things I wished was fleshed out a little more.  4/5

Villeneuve, catches the real dirty and gritty side of Juarez, Mexico, and the realism of the Mexican Cartels. 5/5 stars, can't wait for Story of Our Life, and Blade Runner 2.

Blunt and Del Toro are incredible, the story is tense throughout with more than one memorable scene to think back on. Beautifully shot by Villeneuve, Sicario is a movie that makes you ask yourself how far is too far, and even if you cross that line, will it matter.

Subtlety and silence. Tools that director Denis Villeneuve utilizes to masterful effect in his latest film "Sicario". Together with these methods he paints a stark portrait of brutality and injustice present in modern-day Mexico. "Sicario" is the story of how far one American Special Agent is willing to go to put a stop to the drug trade coming out of Juarez, Mexico. Stars Emily Blunt, Benicio Del Toro, and Josh Brolin round out the bulk of the cast and they each bring their A-Game. "Sicario" isn't always an easy film to watch, but it is a necessary one.

A gritty look at the "war" along the border of the U.S. with Mexican Drug Cartels. She's mostly a pawn in Josh Brolin's operation to take out a Drug Kingpin. Benicio Del Toro is interesting as the mysterious Alejandro, but that's about it. There's a scene early on where the film takes on a war film identity but then it's over and everything slows down. I also liked the way they tried to show life in Juarez, but it slowed the plot down a little. Sicario could have been a really good action thriller, but instead it was simply a well acted picture with some great moments that don't about to much in terms of story.
