Why was Emily Blunt in this movie?  Would have better with just Brolin and BDT kicking ass and taking names. Blunt took up too much screen and story time. Could have been a 4+ star. Gets you hooked from the beginning.  Goes to shit quickly. Don't waste your money.

Beautifully shot, superbly acted, and GREAT tension. I really dug Josh Brolin for once. Emily blunt was amazing as usual. Though I didn't understand her hesitation at the end. And Benicio stole the entire show with his mysterious and completely ruthless badass character. I love this director and can't wait to see him take on Blade Runner 2!
The direction was perfect!

"Sicario is an excellent drug trade thriller featuring fantastic work from Emily Blunt and Benicio del Toro"
Movie Review: Sicario
Date Viewed: October 7 2015
Directed By Denis Villeneuve (Incendies, Enemy and Prisoners)
Written By Taylor Sheridan
Starring: Emily Blunt, Benicio del Toro, Josh Brolin, Victor Garber, Daniel Kaluuya, Maximiliano Hernandez, Jeffrey Donovan, Raoul Trujillo, Julio Cedillo and Jon Bernthal.

What does the word Sicario mean? In Mexico, it stands for hitman. The Mexican drug war has been talked about a lot from certain Republican presidential candidates (Donald Trump and Ben Carson) but "Sicario" doesn't sit down and tell you why the drug war is affecting the United States. It is an excellent drug trade thriller featuring fantastic work from Emily Blunt and Benicio del Toro.
"Sicario" is another dark thriller from Quebec's own Denis Villeneuve (Incendies, Enemy and Prisoners) who is now one of the most interesting filmmakers working today.
Sure, it's not as great as Steven Soderbergh's Oscar-winning film "Traffic" but it's still a heart-pounding thriller with two Oscar-worthy performances.

Emily Blunt plays Kate Macer, an idealistic FBI agent who gets enlisted by the U.S. government to track down a top Mexican drug lord. To stop him, the FBI has to work with a hitman in order to get closer to the drug kingpin. Leading the government task force is CIA officer Matt Graver (Josh Brolin) and his shadowy partner Alejandro Gillick (Benicio del Toro).

Kate and her partner Reggie (Daniel Kaluuya) have been struggling in this drug fight for some time. In the film's beginning, we see Kate and her task force raid a drug house in Chandler, Arizona. Not only does she find dozens of bodies hidden in the walls of the house, she also survives from a IED bomb hidden in the backyard shed. 

The drug war has also hit the U.S.-Mexico border as Kate and her FBI task force take out members of the cartel in the middle of a traffic jam. Kate is concerned about the operation because she didn't sign up to become a soldier, she wanted to take down the drug lord, not an entire cartel army.

When Kate decides to take time off and go to a bar, she meets a local cop named Ted (Jon Bernthal, who is in every movie these days). Just as the two begin to have sex, Kate discovers a rubber wristband, the same type of wristband that was used to bundle the drug lord's money. Ted nearly strangles Kate to death as he is stopped by Alejandro. She finds something mysterious about Alejandro and it turns out that he is a hitman who's seeking revenge for the deaths of his wife and daughter.

"Sicario" has an intelligent and tightly-wound script from Taylor Sheridan and the movie looks great thanks to Roger Deakins' beautiful cinematography. As you all know, Deakins worked with the Coen brothers a lot and he previously did cinematography for "Skyfall" and director Denis Villeneuve's own "Prisoners". It's time to give this guy an Oscar already. Villeneuve's dark and intense thriller also manages to avoid the cliches of the drug trafficking playbook. Emily Blunt is the real standout here, with "Edge of Tomorrow", "Looper" and this film, she is capable of sharing screen time with the big boys in an action thriller.

Benicio del Toro is absolutely engrossing as the mysterious Alejandro who has different intentions for the drug kingpin. Beautifully shot and well-acted, "Sicario" is a superb thriller that must be seen. I think it's going to have a spot on my Top 10 list.

Sicario was one of my most anticipated films of the year. Dennis Villeneuve is one of my absolute favourite working directors. Prisoners and Enemy are two of my all-time favourite films. Well, I'm happy to say that Sicario, though not perfect, is freaking fantastic!

The whole cast is amazing. Josh Brolin plays pretty much the same character as he did in Everest, and he nails it. Emily Blunt gives her BEST performance as the lead in this film. Her acting ability totally blew me away. My favourite performance though has to be Benicio Del Toro. This might be my favourite performance from him.

The directing and cinematography are some of the best I've seen in years. Roger Deakins proves yet again that he's the best cinematographer working today. There are so many shots that had me saying "wow" out loud in the theatre. 

My main issues with Sicario lie in the story and pacing. The story is fairly by-the-numbers and clichéd. They handle it well, but it seemed too familiar. Also, the first half of the movie is paced terribly. Unfortunately, it took me a while to get into the film. I was bored, yet still interested up until the 1 hour mark. If the pacing would have been tighter, I would have enjoyed it more. The musical score is also perfect for the super dark tone. 

Overall, Sicario is a fantastic film with good performances and breathtaking cinematography. Though the first half is very slow and the story is familiar, it's definitely worth seeing for film-buffs and fans of Dennis Villeneuve.

RATING: 8.5/10

Sicario is a disturbing, realistic depiction of the ongoing war between the U.S. and the Mexican drug cartels that should not be forgotten. Benicio Del Toro gives an Oscar-worthy performance alongside Emily Blunt and Josh Brolin, who both give excellent performances as well.

'Sicario' was a term used about the Zealots in Jerusalem who would attack the Romans who entered the homeland. I know this because of my studies and also because it states it at the beginning of the film.  This is director Denis Villeneuve's 3rd American/English (Prisoners, Enemy) film since his film and one of my personal favorites of all time 'Incendies' received a Best Foreign Language Film nod back in 2010.  He doesn't shy away from showing the gruesomeness that result from real issues (here drug trade/war). His films such as this one are heavy to take in, doesn't make light of human life and its cost.  The violence is not stylized but is necessary to the narrative.  The screenwriting, directing, and acting draws you in and keeps you on edge throughout.  This is a well-executed film which is starting to become a consistent trend for the director.
I enjoyed the build-up more than the payoff. B

Great 2 hour movie to finish off the slew of Drug themed movies and seeing Josh Brolin again from No Country for Old Men to Sicario. Story pacing was great. Emily Blunt playing as the straight arrow and bamf calm demeanor Benecio Del Toro. Recommend to watch.

Irascibly suspenseful, well-written, and bolstered by fantastical performances from Blunt, Brolin, and Del Toro, Sicario provides it's viewers with thrilling action sequences, a surprisingly high amount of resonance, as well as top-notch directing.

Sicario

An ethical FBI agent is recruited by a clandestine government task force to help fight the war on drugs on the U.S./Mexico border. 

Sicario is a riveting crime/drama/thriller that is reminiscent of films like Seven or Silence of the Lambs but with a drug war theme. Almost everything in this film is polished; the pacing, the acting, the look, even the "feel" of the film is well crafted. The only blemish would be the vague motivation of the main character played by Emily Blunt, but the driving force behind Benicio Del Toro's character, Alejandro, more than makes up for the slight deficiency.

Sicario is one of my favorite films of the year.

Grade:  A 

Big Al says see Sicario in the theatre.
Best dramatic crime story I've seen since watching "The Departed". Captivating from beginning to the end, could easily watch again

Benicio del Toro his usual menacing self, but really this movie is just ok. Too many holes in the plot, too many inconsistencies that I'm sure the director was hoping you would forget with all the razzle-dazzle guns and chases and suspense. Well, no.
I was lucky enough to see a private screening. Absolutely loved this film from start to finish.
One of the very best films of 2015 by far.

Sicario is one of a kind. This film evokes the terror and anarchy that happens at the Mexican-U.S. border and is blunt and brutal in its message. It is so uncomfortable at times that it makes you want to turn your head, but it is too exciting to miss a second. Benicio Del Toro was absolutely brilliant! One of his best performances ever. The film also ends with one of the most intense ending sequences I've ever witnessed on film. This is a must see!

Alejandro: You should move to a small town, somewhere the rule of law still exists. You will not survive here. You are not a wolf, and this is a land of wolves now.

Se podría decir que Sicario es la película más sutil que haya visto que lidia con el tema del narcotráfico. Estamos acostumbrados a ver explosiones, disparos y acción en cada toma dentro de este género. Sicario ahonda dentro del subconsciente de este mundo. Es sorprendentemente la película que más me ha impactado y logró articular el impacto del problema. La maldad sucede frente a nuestras narices, pero nos rehusamos a verlo. Dentro de la grandeza de la historia, Kate tampoco es capaz de verlo. Es alguien que se encuentra dormida ante la realidad. Es una oveja rodeada por lobos.

Sicario es una película que se toma su tiempo. Tal vez se enfoca en hacer de cada escena, una revelación, pero está llena de detalles donde poco a poco va revelando la historia sutilmente. Al mismo tiempo, la atmósfera va creando expectativa de que algo enorme está por suceder, y en vez de entregarnos un gran climax, Sicario nos entrega pequeños momentos llenos de significado si se presta suficiente atención. 

En Sicario no existe la esperanza. No hay luz al final del túnel. Recorre el día a día de estos personajes y las micro agresiones a las cuales se enfrentan. Acá no hay héroes. Todos, a pesar de tener las mejores intenciones se convierten en villanos. Inevitablemente cuando te sumerges a ese mundo, la moral y los valores que todos tenemos inherentemente, son destruídos.

El equipo detrás de esta película es de élite. Roger Deakins como cinematógrafo, Denis Villeneuve como director y Jóhann Jóhannsson encargado de la banda sonora. Es imposible reunir a un mejor equipo. La historia se ve elevada gracias a el trabajo de estos hombres. Técnicamente es una obra maestra. Las actuaciones son otro aspecto de el éxito de esta película, especialmente la de Benicio del Toro, que comanda la pantalla. Blunt y Brolin también logran un buen trabajo.

Sicario es una de esas películas las cuales es necesario verla una segunda vez y estoy segura que va a ser capaz de entregar una experiencia completamente distinta con nuevas facetas a la historia.
Sicario was brutal,sad and thrilling. It had one of the best performances from Emily Blunt and Benico Del Toro. It was really great watch it!!!!!

This exciting and crude adventure, manages to be smart enough in all of its little details, becoming both an action thriller and an emotional ride, carefully constructed with a beautiful cinematography and a solid direction.

This is definitely one of the best thrillers I've seen over the last few years. It treats its audience with respect and rewards accordingly. The film plays out like Heat and The Departed, setting a tone from the get go and refusing to let off until the bitter end. Superb cast and Blunt as the bridge to the audience is on top form, I'm a little shocked by the lack of award notice but if you miss this thriller you are missing out.
The best movie of 2015
One of the best films of the year.

Denis Villeneuve does it again With Sicario a crime thriller about the drug cartel, with a great cast, great direction, and a great score makes this one a must see. Denis Villeneuve keeps making great movies and has a promising future in film-making.

This is a solid thriller that has peaks and valleys of great moments and boring moments. When it wants to be a thriller, it really is thrilling but the quieter scenes just aren't all that captivating. Emily Blunt makes some of the more boring stuff worth while because she just is naturally a great actress to watch (and to the executive that wanted a man in this role, this movie would have been 10 times less engaging if a man was in her role). I also like how Blunt's character wasn't down your throat about "oh I'm a woman in a man's game" nor were the people around her undermining her because she was a woman. It was nice and refreshing to see that from a modern movie. Josh Brolin has been really winning be over these past few years as I was kind of meh about him in the past. He does a great job and Benicio Del Toro also has some good moments but he wasn't given as much to do with his character overall. If he had a few more scenes, he may have stolen the show. Jon Bernthal also has a great small part in this. I love the director Denis Villeneuve that made 2013's Prisoners and I think he did a good job directing this especially the climax. Roger Deakens' cinematography is really wonderful during the climax as well. Great sound design as well and some great thrills as I said. It's solid and worth seeing but you don't have to rush out to see it right this minute
Dont know how this got good rating boring movie which  has happened before

Slow paced, behind the times and surprisingly uninterested in utilizing its capable cast, Sicario is an out-of-touch waste from start to finish that has been propelled solely by undeserved pre-release hype.
1 word needed... Intense!

A tense but undoubtedly accurate story of the behind the scenes work of the FBI busting some of the major drug cartels on the US & Mexican Border.

You as the viewer are through the eyes of the Emily Blunt character who delivers a very naive but brilliant performance.

There are many great scenes in the film with some sensational camerawork but underrated DOP Roger Deakins. The scene at the dinner table at the end of the film is unforgettable.
started out great, slowly declined.  it's crazy knowing that this really happens though!
Excellent piece of work.

The movie maintains it's intensity level throughout the remainder of the film after its edge-of-the-seat, nerve-wracking opener. Excellently acted across the board by Blunt, Brolin, Del Toro, Sicario is about an FBI agent (Blunt) who gets pulled aside into a special team to help take down members of the Mexican drug cartelhuh, through not always "by-the-book" procedures. Featuring beautiful cinematography; a haunting score; and Oscar-worthy performances, directing, and Sound Mixing/Editing; Dennis Villeneuve has followed up Prisoners with a movie that demands its presence and commands your attention.
Didn't meet my medium expectation I had for it. Just need some more stuff to happened. Slow movie that never pays off.
Denis Villeneuve makes another great thriller film with great performances all around making it one of the best films of the year.    A
In my Top 3. Yes that good.

Now this is how you make a movie. I've said it before and I'll say it again, Denis Villeneuve is one of the finest directors ever and can do absolutely no wrong. Sicario proves that in the highest measure by taking a film with a relatively straight foward plotline and fashioning it in such a way that you're left speechless by the end. Not only does the film include some incredible set pieces (the bridge and tunnel scenes had me on the edge of my seat. And the final del Toro solo mission scene reminded me of a better filmed 'Zero Dark Thirty' bin Laden raid), but it showed a refreshing yet dour side of the drug trade -- specifically the flawed American role within it all. The enemy we know is better than the enemy we don't is very pertinent here. 

Overall, I have nothing bad to say about the film. It is incredibly ambitious and does really well to meet those ambitions with near perfect success. Very excited for part 2 even though Villenueve is not directing.

Perfectly acted, suspenseful as hell thanks to the director, and beautifully shot thanks to Roger Deakins. The story had a great twist at the end for Del Toro's character. All the characters were well fleshed ou the their own ways.

Another classic from Villeneuve. It doesn't top Prisoners for me but Sicario is still a very very good film. Led by outstanding performances by Blunt and Del Toro, Sicario builds and builds and builds tension all the way through it and leaves you at the edge of your seat. The ending was left a bit open and anti climatic but the tension that I spoke about earlier is at its peak. Definitely go see this film as it does not disappoint.

Denis Villeneuve is one of the best directors working today. and that is shown again with his new film, Sicario. Emily Blunt just keeps getting better and better every time I see her in a film. Benicio Del Toro killed it with his performance. he was brilliant and scary and you never really knew if you could trust him. Sicario is ridiculously intense, taut, exciting and nerve racking. the scene where they're in line at the border and they see some cartel members in a car a ways away, was honestly one of the most intense and cool things I have seen in any film in years. some scenes may have dragged a little but Sicario pulled me in with its beautiful cinematography, the vast landscapes of Mexico and hooked me with its stellar performances, intelligent script, and brilliant direction. one of the best films of the year.
Outstanding!  Finally a movie with great acting, story, action and characters that are believable.  This movie will hold you in your seat for the entire two hours.
Solid drug cartel/US/Mexico Law Enforcement movie. Beautiful cinematography! Great acting, script...should be a nod for academy award. Loved Emily, Josh and especially Benicio.

Alejandro: "You will not survive here, you are not a wolf. This is the land of wolves".

The story in Sicario is about an idealistic FBI agent is paired up with a consultant with a checkered past, she will have to learn the hard way that combating the new war on drugs sometimes means getting your hands dirty.

Sicario was my most anticipated movie of 2015, just because of the director, the cast and the magnificent cinematographer Roger Deakins was involved in making this movie. Denis Villeneuve has been non-stop impressing me recently with movies like: Enemy and Prisoners, so I was really looking forward to seeing Sicario and boy let me tell you that Denis Villeneuve did it again, because Sicario is one of the most intense and shocking film I've seen this year. Denis Villeneuve made another fantastic movie that's unsettling and brutal. The directing, cinematography and the performances from Emily Blunt and Benicio Del Toro were fantastic.

Not completly action packed, yet incredibly intense. Blunt is my fav actress, and I deff believe this was a scary thriller, and incredibly true film. Thats real life. its really happening. great film overall!

Wow! I honestly can't think of another movie I've seen that was more tense than this. The atmosphere created by the directing and music score was incredible. Gritty, raw and at times genuinely terrifying. By far the best movie I've seen in 2015!
Slowly paced but drenched in dark atmosphere and eerie suspense, Sicario features fine directing from Villeneuve, incredible work by Deakins, and breathaking performances by Blunt and Del Toro
Grim, achingly-suspenseful, and beautifully shot, Sicario is a masterpiece of thriller filmmaking with more on its mind than just the extremely compelling narrative it creates.

With a relevant topic, impeccable directing, a balanced story, ominous fitting music, and top-tier performances by Blunt, Brolin, and del Toro, this film marks its way as the best movie of the year.

A+

Unbelievable film.  Del Toro was remarkable as usual, as was Emily Blunt.  It's such a beautiful thing when two opposites, in this case - good and evil can somehow work together in harmony to achieve. And that's exactly what Del Toro and Blunt did, oh and there were some other players there too, i.e. Josh Brolin.  After seeing the movie, I have many questions, most pertaining to U.S foreign policy and interests.  But I guess the biggest would be what other CIA ventures do we not know about? 

But, aside from the incredible camerawork, special effects, beautiful shots, and intense realism; folks, go see this flick. You won't be sorry, if I had any power, this one would definitely have an Oscar nomination or two.
Zero Dark Thirty meets Traffic
Far from your clichÃ (C) film about drug cartels and narcotics, Sicario is a tight made film. The cast took their roles to the next level.

Just as the tall black border wall between Mexico and the U.S. snakes through the desert landscape, so too does Sicario act very snake like. Coiling tightly around your innards and unleashing wicked amounts of venom and violence when you least expect it in the most shocking and disturbing ways imaginable. An unbelievably tense, sinister tale of vicious creatures in vicious lands.

Sicario is a disturbing, gritty and great film. The acting is great from Emily Blunt who plays one of the strongest female characters of 2015, Josh Brolin is quite funny yet he is very commanding and gives a great peformance. Benicio Del Toro gives an amazing peformance and is the best character in the movie. He was also an absolute badass. The film is brilliantly directed by Denis Villenueve, the cinematography by Roger Deakins is amazing, the shot of the soldiers in the dark is one of the best shots I've ever seen. This film is also nail bitingly tense, the scene on the bridge is quite possibly the best part of the movie, the third act of the film is also extremely tense. I loved the opening, loved the ending and loved pretty much all of this film. However the pacing is a bit off in places. Also I feel Emily Blunt's character didn't have that much of a pay off and considering this film is mostly about her character, it's weird we end the film with Benicio Del Toro's character. However this is a great movie and one of the better movies of 2015. A-
Del Toro for the supporting Oscar!

Amazing movie. All the leads in this film gave great performances. Emily Blunt was great as an idealistic and tenacious FBI field agent who passively let herself used by parts of the U.S. government who are playing a bigger game than simply reacting to the drug war which has killed too many people. Josh Brolin never let the audience be fooled into thinking he was anything other than a dangerous and on the ball CIA SAD officer working with the DoD to stabilise the drug theatre in Central and South America by working with the devil they know?the Medellín Cartel, despite his introductory goofy clothing choices. del Toro was very much convincing as a prosecutor turned Medellín hitman with a dark past working with the U.S. government.

The film, despite its few intense and suspenseful action scenes, can get dry at times, but that feeling is greatly offset by the great performances and a stark realisation that regular law enforcement is not going to change the game, only top-level policy, or in this film, trying to replace a greater evil with a lesser one, will have the best chance of succeeding.
Disappointing. Had high hopes as love Emily Blunt.

Movies about the drug wars are becoming quite popular, what separates Sicario from some of the others is how well executed this film truly is. I already expected greatness from Denis Villeneuve, the director, given that I admired his two previous films, "Prisoners" & "Enemy." The cinematography is exceptional, it is a great piece of cinema. The performances are first-rate, as expected from this cast. Benicio Del Toro in particular is outstanding. The great set pieces do a good job in portraying the brutality and the horrors in the cartel world.
cynical, yet comes correct.

Wow. Just...wow, holy shit.
Sicario: a dark, tense, cerebral thriller that satisfies immensely on so many levels. The slow burn of this thought provoking story keeps the blood pumping from start to finish, as we're swept into the underworld of the cartel through the canvas of the Mexican border; the cinematography is truly breathtaking. 
Everything having to do with the development between Blunt, Brolin, and Del Toro's characters was handled so well, it's refreshing having all the many moral choices and consequences to dissect by the end of this film. It succeeds brilliantly well in commentating on our country's excessive use of force in the world, and the good & evil that can come from it. 
This is definitely going to be one of the best to beat by the end of the year; Sicario is just excellent, plain and simple. If he keeps producing such intelligent, masterfully crafted thrillers, Denis Villenue is sure to become one of this generation's most valuable directors. Take that to the bank.

Sicario was probably one of the most intense and scariest films I've seen lately!! The saddest part is this film is speaking out loud to what's is currently happening underground between my countries and its very sad and scary!
Fantastic. Emily Blunt killed it, but I think Benicio del Toro was the true stand out. Also Roger Deakins' cinematography -- holy crap.
Great film. Benicio Del Toro was fantastic.

Dennis Villeneuve hits again with one of the most gripping, intense and powerful political thrillers in years. While it suffers a little on the plot side towards the ending, strong performances by Emily Blunt and Benicio Del Toro, the (as usual) brilliant cinematography by Roger Deakins and the bold, confident vision of one of the most exciting directors working in Hollywood right now, deliver a must see, very needed thriller.
Brilliant suspense thriller.  Brilliant cinematography and score.  Brilliant technique and acting....I'd expect nothing less from the best director in the business right now.

Emily Blunt packed a huge punch, and Del Toro was amazing, with great support from Brolin. The character matchup was great, from naive America(Blunt), to a great pairing of American sleezy government(Brolin) and corrupt south of the border hit man(Del Toro). The characterization alone said a lot about the story, without saying anything at all. 
The sound and score was the next most amazing part of this film. It hit you at weird moments, and only seemed to augment the craziness of the situation, or morbid sensation you already had from the visual the director presented to you. 
Overall though, I am going to have to go back, and watch it again. I was hoping for something a bit more fresh to it(with its 93% rating... and I'd expected a bit of the "weird" from Villeneuve) and didn't have that feeling while I watched it. For some reason, the cause and effect conflict wasn't enough for me. It seemed as though we just floated along, unsure what was going on, just like Blunts character(but again, I will definitely give this film another watch).
But for everything said; 
-acting was superb(A+)
-cinematography(B+)
-production design(A)
-story(B)

one of the best so far and a serious Oscar contender.

Sicario is another pulse pounding thriller from Dennis Villeneuve, serving up brutally shot violence, strong performances by Emily Blunt and Benicio del toro as well as bringing up stirring political and moral ethics

With amazing performances by the cast, especially Del Toro, Sicario is an honest and realistic film about drugs and cartels. It's a deliberately joyless action piece, designed to haunt the audience more than thrill them and to get them lost in darkness with the film's "hero" rather than see her find the light. The film is also poised to be seriously misunderstood (although, given how clearly it's themes are underlined I can't imagine how) by those who either think the story is meant to glorify the US' role in the drug war or those who (shudder) think the terrifying Brolin and Del Toro characters are cool.
Emily Blunt is beyond terrific in Dennis Villineuve's gripping, thought-provoking, and relentlessly bleak new thriller "Sicario". One of the very best films of 2015. It's a masterpiece.

There was so much hype about Emily Blunt playing this strong female role. However her character always seems out of her element in these risky drug task force missions. She also fights a losing battle with a rapist in one scene and is only saved by a male co-worker. Carries on the themes of Soderbergh's Traffic with Benicio Del Toro again in a major enigmatic role. I definitely don't think this is cinematographer Roger Deakins best work. Villeneuve after the big success of Prisoners last year does not succeed in making this story add up to much.
This film is beyond amazing, it is astonishing. To quote a review I read "This is the Apocalypse Now of drug war films." The 2nd best film I've seen this year, behind Cobain: Montage of Heck.
